comment: "the guitar and bottle kings of Kenya"--sometimes charming, sometimes too charming ("Esiesi Siolle," "Elira Yesu Ndayanza")
a career downhill--hear Martin Fry turn into the disco whore he begins by parodying so lovingly ("The Look of Love," "S.O.S.")
Klezmatic David Krakauer lures JB Fred Wesley into hip-hop fusion for midlife crisis survivors ("Tweet Tweet," "Abe Inc Techno Mix").
In love with a suicide in a world controlled by forces he can't quite grasp, half-blind autodidact retains more brain if not reason than the average black hippy ("Closure," "Sapiosexual")
Sound effects, emotional affects, he's got 'em all ("Note to Self: Don't Die," "This Is It")
Nine songs per disc, evenly divided good-dull-OK, only the first disc--he's full of surprises--is stronger ("Easy Plateau," "Beautiful Sorta").
Still just a teenager, a practical romantic gets by without acting cheeky ("Daydreamer," "Tired").
LA "surf-punk" unit tops off medium-catchy full-length with Ramones-worthy scene chant and mock-escapist teen dream. ("Silverlake Goths," "Suburban Girlfriend")
Fathomless beats an adventure, impenetrable lyrics a drag ("Babies With Guns," "Limelighters").
doesn't know the Prince of Darkness as well as he thinks he does ("Double Day," "Going to Town")
Already de facto soundtrack, they didn't need a real movie to distract them from meaning something ("Ghost Song," "Dirty Trip").
Has his head screwed on better than most professionally overwrought young men ("Sometime Around Midnight," "Gasoline").
Thrown out of whack by bad romance and worse social media, she's no longer so clever about putting up a front or hiding behind a tune, but don't assume it's permanent--not yet ("Three," "My One")
autumnal Austin ("Peggy Legg," "Crisis Site 13")
color them goodd ("I Swear," "The Bomb")
selves-made prefab ("Trapped," "If You Want To Party").
This is who they are, and it remains a heroic story, but extra synth wash cannot disguise what an awkward time it is to put a Malian stamp on feel-good dance-pop ("Bofou Safou, "La Confusion")
normal don't suit him ("Tuck It In," "Umbabarauma")
Aided by his godson John Rich, he achieves "funky country" once again--but not when he puts it that way ("Brown Liquor," "A Woman Knows").
in Juilliard-style postmodern artsong, "can't sing" is perhaps an advantage ("Slip Away," "The Island Where I Come From")

album: My Songs Are the House I Live In
comment: Reports from an inquiring mind and the Texas plain that benefit from the judicious application of irony and drum machine ("Encyclopedia," "Johnny's Gone Driving")
Really good at sex, and not only that--also really really good at sex ("I Miss That Whip," "Drugs")
"The other side of takeout is mildew on rice" convinced me that they Know Life--but then I started to wonder again ("Peacebone," "Cuckoo Cuckoo").
Sunny down snuff they're all right with the heroes and villains ("My Girls," "Brother Sport").
She can't be saying "greatest tits"--she's just too thin ("Chewing Gum," "Greatest Hit").
Mostly instrumentals, and no longer do they fade into nothingness up against Fela ("Indictment," "Obanla'e").
at long last rock-a-roll--by which I mainly mean a handful of decent songs, honest ("Hands Down," "Graveyard")
Their beats are as abstract and chewy as their rap, and how good that is is up to you ("Rinseflow," "Your World Is Flat").
best of the Powerpuff Girls plus collectibles ("Heroes and Villains," "Signal in the Sky [produced version]")
buy the EP, then see the show ("Nostalgia," "Audiowhore")
we will, we will shoot you ("Don't Be Scared," "Hey World")
in her search for love may she record forever ("True Love," "Weak Woman")
shallow orgasms aren't bad orgasms, but she could probably do better with her own hand ("Foolish," "Rescue")
Ambient Arabized dub ethnotechno, for chilling out without altogether forgetting you have a body ("Scientism," "Rajamatshitan")
like the Squirrel Nut Zippers only older, funnier, and named after a Texan Candy Barr ("Mama Don't Allow," "Chinatown")
only one auteur here, and his success has gone to his songs ("Chinese Bakery," "Lenny Valentino")
Remixed 1996 DIY EP plus more Kool Keith and atmospherics ("Buck Buck," "King of NY").
Victims of the folkie fallacy that unambiguous lyrics require unadorned instrumentation ("Die Die Die," "The Ballad of Love and Hate").
Neapolitan saxophonist, Calabrian percussionists, and world-music luminaries exert their goodwill ("Porto Alegre," "O Munno Se Move").
P-Funk with Bill Laswell's sense of humor, God help us ("Free-Bass [Godzillatron Cush]," "Orbitron Attack")
how we all like our conscious--with a sense of humor ("Imma RMX," "No Lexus")
needs a whole lot less of Jesus and a lot more rock and roll ("Man's Tight Vest," "In the Morning")
Parisians concoct polyglot Gypsy ska for peace and justice ("Dances of Resistance," "Warlord").
live 1987, when skank-wise hyperkinesis was still a cultural mission ("Day Tripper/She's a Rainbow," "At the Movies")
life still sucks ("21st Century (Digital Boy)")
in lieu of the future, they'll accept nice neighbors and the occasional stroll ("Too Much To Ask," "Generator")
keeping the bad faith ("Incomplete," "Hooray for Me")
now actually the Greg Graffin Group, as you can tell with a scorecard ("Punk Rock Song," "One in Twenty Ten")
for one thing, Billie didn't write her own material ("Rimshot," "Afro")
Some hard times come again, others never leave ("Palestine II," "Cotton").
Hey--a Nashville Taylor Swift surrogate who literally grew up in Tennessee (listening to Britney and Xtina). ("Dibs," "Second Hand Smoke")

album: The Best of the Band Volume II
comment: Pretty fair country bar group/cover band ("Blind Willie McTell," "Atlantic City").
Echoed melisma and felt folk-rock drones for Generation Sad ("First Song," "Weed Party").
In a year you'll still remember most of these tunes, and you'll still wish it didn't take 34 minutes to get through 10 of them ("No One's Gonna Love You," "Cigarettes, Wedding Bands").
"a little classical music my friends, 'Cheating, Lying, Stealing' . . ." ("Cheating, Lying, Stealing," "Red Shift")
Kind of charming, with two songs so cute they should be sung by Cyndi Lauper and Paul Westerberg, respectively ("Chinese Children," "I Feel Just Like a Child").
praise Jah--neither "Wicked Act" nor "If Loving Was a Crime" bats boys of any sort ("Wicked Act," "Deportees [Things Change]")

artist: Blue Lu Barker, Wee Bea Booze, and Baby Dee
comment: half a century later, sex as pleasure, respite, gift, medium of exchange, and cliche ("Don't You Feel My Leg," "Buy Me Some Juice," "I Feel Like Laying in Another Woman's Husband's Arms")
The best of these songs are so perfectly put they thrive solo acoustic--but could still use a band ("Ballad of Bitter Honey," "I Wasn't Really Drunk").
"True freedom from all earthly constraints" is a chimera, right, but Clem Snide's greatest melody helps you forget it ("I Love the Unknown," "Could Be Worse," "Apocalyptic Friend").
Brit boychiks go pseudo-American, not sussing how old jeans and guitars have gotten in mall-land, which is a relief ("Unpredictable," "Ghost of You and Me")
Teeny-weeny dreamy-themey pokey-wokey tune-a-rooney ("Lover of Mine," "Norway").
Next stop AA ("Dumb," "Your Father and I").
his greatest hit, an album demo, and two-for-three prime odds and ends ("Fume," "Alcohol")
his one-offs top Calvin Johnson's keepers ("He's a Mighty Good Leader," "Asshole")
Does eventually get funky, if anybody cares but me ("Pressure Zone," "Peaches & Cream," "Debra").
His cynicism turned melancholy, rich rock star warns, "Better not get cozy with your trophy life" ("Circus Money," "God's Eye View").
Working things out for herself within the severe constraints of pop form ("These Words," "Unwritten").

album: Fold Your Hands Child, You Walk Like a Peasant
comment: Palette expanded, pigment thinned ("Women's Realm," "The Model").
Whilst pursuing life, always remember: Their weedy wimpery was more original, and elegant, than their pop mastery ("The Blues Are Still Blue," "Funny Little Frog").
when you joke around, perfect aim is all ("Chick Singers," "Monica")
weird dreams for justice ("God Said No," "Thanksgiving Day Parade")
as life goes on, his lyrics follow it everywhere ("Eve," "Graceland")
With her daddy, the bonus cut reveals--as if we didn't know ("Yes," "Baby Boy").
Nashville pros' punk kids prove their parents are hipsters like musicians anywhere ("Damn Damn Leash").
Talismanic ax hews neo-iconic songs out of neoplatonic bluesman ("Turning Pages," "Rocking Chair").
Foraging among competing styles and mannerisms, glitch-ambient mixmeister finds chipmunk voices a pick-me-up ("S'Vive," "Lovers' Carvings").
Claims hip-hop, represents r&b, ends up neither here nor there ("Apple of My Eye," "She Hates Me")
Perky new pop record rides articulately rapped leads, favor-banked star power, a stanza for Colin Kaepernick, and refurbished wares from the sexist metaphor store ("Made Man," "Overthunk")
Major-label debut asks the musical question, Who's pimping who ("If I Fall," "Hydroplaning," "Praying Man")
"Boy, have we been keeping busy! Hope we see you real soon!" ("Thy Name Is Woman," "France").

album: Keep an Eye on the Sky
comment: After three CDs of collectorama, Disc 4 documents a 1973 show mere admirers might try to isolate ("Hot Burrito #2," "Slut").
Fragile, noisy images of a love perpetually out of reach ("Masterpiece," "Paul")
Mr. Sunshine Meets the End of the World--in 1978 ("World in Confusion")
Buck 65 declares his ineffable love for Joï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½lle Phuong Minh Lï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿"Always I Will Miss You, Always You," "Lazarus Phenomenon").

album: Don't Let the Bossman Get You Down!
comment: Mr. Entertainment ("My Whiskey Head Buddies," "Soul Food")
(Folksy) (University of) Chicago bluesman holds onto his chops--also his wits, except about the internet ("Everybody's in the Same Boat," "Let Your Woman Have Her Way")
but with a gooey center, yum ("Ganja," "Six States Away")
I always thought she was too lifelike for him anyway ("Stonemilker," "Atom Dance")
the silliest Pixie ("Fu Manchu," "I Heard Ramona Sing")
Still recites beautifully ("I Ran All the Way Home," "Andrew Ridgley").
At long last Larry Kirwan finds a subject it's impossible to overdo--or anyway, almost impossible ("Battle of Fallujah," "Downtown Baghdad Blues").

album: It's Great When You're Straight, Yeah
comment: frat-rock for the apocalypse (what apocalypse?)("Reverend Black Grape," "Kelly's Heroes")

Three clattering dissonant songs (or tracks) establishing their right to record yet more clattering dissonant songs (or tracks)-not that anything could stop them ("Song About a . . . ," "A Truth Quietly Told").
Keeping it simple, but for once not too simple ("Next Girl," "The Go Getter").
With advice from Master of All Soundscapes Danger Mouse, they construct a loud blooze-rawk one, complete with song outlines ("Lonely Boy," "Run Right Back")
actually, they seem to enjoy life more than Jesus and Mary Chain--not that that's so hard ("Red Eyes and Tears," "Spread Your Love")
democratic opinion ina bacchanal style ("All Saints Road," "Nation of Importers")
real is not enough, but attached to the right voice it's something to build on ("Sweet Thing," "Real Love")
no samba, no ska, 14 songs, 26 minutes ("No Pistols Reunion," "In Love With a Junkie")
Alt-rock leapfrogs alt-country into country-rock--rock as tuneful pastoral escape ("Fire and Fast Bullets," "Black River Killer").
Dubious albeit arresting title track justified by six warm, likable, nicely unfinished folk-rock tunes ("Shoulder Full of You," "Preacher's Sister's Boy").
Zulu prog beats Chicano prog, but then again, Ladysmith's angels beat prog's angel ("Banna Ba Modimo," "Molalatladi").
Benetton boys adrift on Tony Blair's morass of neoliberal compromise ("Helicopter," "Pioneer").

album: Baby, They Told Us We'd Rise Again
comment: Half Allmans sans virtuosos, half Truckers sans storytellers ("Heavy With Child," "Little Margarita").

artist: Blues Anatomy With Jef Lee Johnson
comment: Singing much raunchier and playing a little rougher than the jazziest classic bluesman ("Careless Love," "6/88 Glide").

So much cuter when his voice is a high pitch in the soundscape rather than a conveyor of putative verbal content ("666[bent downward arrow or else some emoji I'm too uncool to recognize]," "21 MOON WATER")
true, disposable, pop deeelite ("Doin' the Do," "Where Are You Baby?")
Surf-inflected Balkan worldbeat inna Hebrew, avec rent-a-singers ("Ushest," "Marylyn Jones").
Cheeky boy-os grow up, concoct tunes to match ("Forget Me," "Fade to Black")
Naked islanders sing their savage songs ("I'll Make You Come," "Broko")

"If I could be a little bit younger/If I could be a little bit older/If I could be a little bit friendlier/If I could be a little bit colder/Then I could be a little bit better" ("Zoysia," "Middle Man").
utopian militance, Haitian worldbeats, soulful vocalizing, near-pop song sense ("Ganga," "Zan'j Yo")
Bootsy meets Hendrix meets Watson meets Blood, and let us not forget Dru Lombar ("Toxic Your Love")
When you can parse lyrics that convey no identity, figure they also don't mean much to the catchy, basic fellas who aren't putting them across ("Two Shocks," "Worry About It Later").
As mixed up and unapologetically Southern as the title says, another voice improves with age ("Love the One You're With," "I'm Confessin'").
Trilingual rhythmically, quadrilingual verbally, and they make it all stick ("Pussy," "Homme").
Sisters in stick-to-itiveness address or at least mention black lung, Edgar Allan Poe, and heroin use in and around the Parthenon ("Blues at the Acropolis," "Nervous Mary")

album: The Unbroken Circle: Songs of the West Virginia Coalfields
comment: Entering new songs in the musical-historical record--without, unfortunately, the bitter jokes I bet they tell there to this day ("Union Miner," "The Longest Darkest Day").
Punk is eternal, snot not ("Killed by Ants," "Destroy the USA")

album: Digital Ash in a Digital Urn
comment: Noised these up because he's nervous about them ("Arc of Time," "Hit the Switch").
they aim their hostility where it belongs--at cops, you, me, and the next fella ("Who's Da Gangsta?," "Youth Gone Mad")

"Hard Workin' M[e]n" tell "Honky Tonk Truth" inna Nashville-songsmith-with-big-drum-sound stylee ("She's Not the Cheatin' Kind," "Boot Scootin' Boogie," "Lost and Found")
still hungry after all that platinum ("Big Money," "Pushing Up Daisies")
No longer poor but still righteous "preacher" and "luckiest son of a bitch that ever lived" asks band for soul and takes the corn he's a sucker for ("House Keys," "Slippin' Away").

album: The Best of the Joe Gibbs Years
comment: Loving rocker in the conscious '70s ("Coming Home Tonight," "Black Liberation Time").
regrets, she's got a few ("Na Na Be Like," "Candy")

album: The Greatest Hits of the Fourth Decade
comment: yes, he did have a synth-funk phase ("Get Up Offa That Thing/Dr. Detroit")
Blacklisted elder statesman boosts his daughter, who sounds fine in her way and who needs it ("Bird to Word--Billie's Bounce," "Young Jazz")
Bypassing Kenny Chesney to return escapist country to its spicier, riskier source--Jimmy Buffett ("Toes," "Sic 'Em on a Chicken").

album: Sir Dark Invader vs. the Fanglord
comment: Langford kids Buckner into taking it easy, which for Buckner is a species of grace, and takes it easy himself to be a good sport, which for him is a kind of slackness ("The Inca Princess," "Nothing to Show")
Richard Terfry gives his fans a mixtape ("Track One," "Track Two").
Maybe it's me--well, almost definitely it's me--but I like him better on baseball than on romance and on album than on EP ("Joey Bats," "Legendary")
guitarist-producer intrusive, son worse, music mild, geezers grand ("Chan Chan," "Candela")
ah sweet mystery of youth, extracting form from chaos and candy from dirt ("Nowhere Nothin' Fuckup," "Three Years Ago Today")
Clean grunge dynamics times messy romantic complexities equals marginally compelling restatements of stuff many evolving punks before her have come to terms with ("Blame," "Not the Way")
the punk joke fully grasped, at least by the jokers ("Watch What You Say," "I Wanna Be Famous")
Pimp C . . . he dead ("Damn I'm Cold," "If It Was Up II Me").
Maybe he figured get your beats working first and later for humanism--or maybe he still had a ways to go in the humanity department ("Southern Comfort," "Broken Home").
they don't explode, they just pound, and pretty hard too ("Alice Mae")

artist: Charlie Burton & the Dorothy Lynch Mob
comment: Repatriated Nebraskan jokes around for love (or lack thereof) ("I Wonder: Is Propecia Right for Me?" "Apples & Oranges").
mooning his love life, mooning the world ("Without My Woman . . . ," "Anyone I Know?)
Not only does his speed-rapping evoke both Sparks and Conlon Nancarrow, he may even know who they are ("Me-Time (With the Pulmonary Palimpsest)," "I've Always Known").
beyond noisome ("Lonesome Bulldog")
callow punk alienation as reliable folk wisdom ("Friends," "Lester Sands")
four songs boasting three cocomposers, and not necessarily better for the collective effort ("Fake Karaoke Machine," "Out West")
Second-generation Alberta rapper (savor that phrase) knows a lot about, well, rapping--and avant-electro beats ("Tattoos [And What They Really Feel Like]," "In Search of the Youth Crew").
Yes, children, there is rap after Prozac ("Fat Kids Need an Anthem," "Beat Kids").
unambiguity from the near side of cool ("Rock'N'Roll Lifestyle," "Jesus Wrote a Blank Check")
Latin Playboys as conceived by an Anglo--too artistic, genuinely literary, lyrical enough to haunt you some ("Sunken Waltz," "Black Heart")
cheese steaks from the Peach State, no more and no less ("It Ain't Easy," "The Cut Song")
not funny enough ("Word Up," "Single Life")
more is less ("Pop a Top," "Mind Over Matter")
cheap sensationalism has its own rewards ("Feels Good," "Me, My Moms & Jimmy," "The Wrong Ones")
Musicality covers over only so much gunrunning and sexual exploitation, though more than I would have figured ("Girls," "Get Down").
ecumenical morality tales from hip hop imam ("Mrs. Manley," "Currency Exchange")
Prophets of slackness beware ("Danger Zone," "Bun Dung Dreddie").
"Wu-Tang Productions Presents" ("Milk the Cow," "Run").
With a hit on their rï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½sumï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï"Paralyzed," "Do You Believe").
She'll love you as long as the chorus lasts, and if you're good the verse too--a period that lengthens as she gets older ("For What It's Worth," "And Then You Kissed Me").
acceding to local custom, they beef up their party with horns, guitar solos, and the appropriate frat-rock faves ("Hey Joe," "96 Tears (Every Woman I Know)")

Jazz guys seeking avant move cover alt-rock demigods ("Here," "Summer Babe").
"If I can't make these songs my own, they don't belong," say the notes, which always belong ("Mean Eyed Cat," "I Never Picked Cotton")
The songs her dad told her to master are too familiar, but give her time and she'll open most of them up pretty good ("Motherless Children," "I'm Movin' On").
Melodies strong, vocals intent, arrangements deft, lyrics worked, impact minimal despite it all ("World of Strange Design," "50,000 Watts")

album: The Best of the Jimmy Castor Bunch
comment: Not a one-joke band--a two-joke band ("Troglodyte [Cave Man]," "Bertha Butt Boogie," "Hey Leroy, Your Mama's Callin' You").
With the Hodges brothers keeping her together, she might actually pick you up at the methadone clinic like she said she would ("Could We," "Love and Communication").
live, he sometimes resembles late Steel Pulse more than you'd figure--also the Mighty Mighty Bosstones ("Welcome to Tijuana," "Bongo Bong")
Breakup album about a musician who up and died on her ("Big Lonesome," "I Love Everybody")
first live recording with his big band, which gets in the way ("Alexander's Ragtime Band," "Bye Bye Love")
"a little early but thanks anyway" (I think) ("Get Up on It Like This")
nostalgic--for futurism past, yet--at, what, 29? ("Hey Boy Hey Girl," "Let Forever Be")
Long-ago hipster-funk ingenue reclaims her avant-garde roots ("Out of the Black," "Spit Three Times")
the cliches tuneful, the jokes better, it was ever thus ("Old Flames Have New Names," "Bubba Shot the Jukebox")
Electropunks attempt garage guitar, which beats careers in equity management by quite a bit ("Left Brain," "Drugs and Sunshine").
Kiss-off songs softened by R&B nice guy de jour Ne-Yo and roughened by the once and future neosoul belter he fails to escort to Hitsville ("Blame It on Me," "Porcelain Doll").
faux-slick truths about real world horror ("All in Vain," "Don't Pass Go")
Branching out, muscling up, writing from the heart, and otherwise diluting the formal command that just barely salvages this follow-up ("Where She Told Me to Go," "Those I've Loved").
the theory is, if Minneapolis produced a Prince, so can Toronto ("Who Will Be Your Man," "Shake It Off")
If this hottie next door believes she's moving on up toward "I'm Just Me" and "I Found Myself," I want to know why they're not the singles (yet) ("That's Right," "Like a Boy").
making the most of a legacy and an ad hoc band ("Homegrown Tomatoes," "Let Him Roll")
Striving to master the popular art of enacting humongous feelings in lieu of comprehending them or conveying them ("My Life Would Suck Without You," "I Do Not Hook Up").
if not clinical, definitely formal ("Pet Eunoch," "Welcome")
If Bryan Ferry was a theoretical dandy, which was hard, then John Petkovic is a theoretical theoretical dandy, which is harder--and he's also John Petkovic ("Conflict," "One Step Away From Myself").
Five knowledgeable songs about the old in-out--with a groove, such as it is, to match ("Eating Disorder," "Magic Wand").

album: A Rush of Blood to the Head
comment: let Green Eyes dump him for real and we'll see how long he hums in the void ("Green Eyes," "In My Place")

album: Viva la Vida or Death and All His Friends
comment: Applying all his powers, Chris Martin successfully dilutes Radiohead, with--what else?--pleasant results ("Viva la Vida," "42").
Full of the kind of good intentions the road to irrelevance is paved with ("Wet Dreamz," "Love Yourz")
So dweeby he's got balls about it, and you gotta love two of the most domestic love songs in a hip hop canon guaranteed to ignore them ("Foldin Clothes," "She's Mine Pt 2")
Well, maybe not exactly like you ("Let It Go," "Just Like You").
Her complaisant act is as sexy as she wants when it works, but she doesn't take to it that well ("Make Me Over," "Oh-Oh, Yeah-Yea").
Torontopian goduncle shucks arty confessional for something faster, homier, friendlier--songcraft, figure, or maybe bandcraft ("High Summer," "The Slowest Dance").
"We just stick to what you want to hear" ("I Wanna Sex You Up," "All 4 Love")
Conscious rappers use their words--lots of them ("Every Last One," "Re-Fresh").
Having fun with Ira, Georgia, and James in . . . the laundry room of their apartment building? ("Gudbuy T'Jane," "Dog Meat").
industrial for the oppressed masses ("This Is a Collective," "Dysfunctional Relationship")
two women singers/songwriters--why didn't the Band think of this after Robbie left? (wait, don't tell me) ("Get Over It," "Mixed Messages")

A 101 fever, a coupla kids, and a few more Jon Tiven songs short of a genuine red-hot mama ("If He Moves His Lips," "Steamy Windows").
Fourth-generation-and-counting blueswoman finds her voice, aka some decent songwriters ("Born a Penny," "Limousine").
nice Liverpool lads--very enthusiastic, bit confused ("Waiting for the Heartaches," "Skeleton Key")
New traditionalism as regular traditionalism, and there'll be plenty more ("The Way Love Looks," "Roll With It").
Neko Case and friend sing country songs--authentic and simulated, live and acoustic, 1998 ("Too Many Pills," "Corn on the Cob").
the band articulates complexities the words gloss over ("Mojo 96," "Taking the Blues Back Home")
You know the drill--if the B-52's had gotten big, this girl-group version of the Fleshtones would have gotten signed "(How to Keep Your) Husband Happy," "Dancin' Lesson").
fussy as Streisand, ugly as sin, touched with grace ("London's Brilliant Parade," "My Science Fiction Twin")
gangstas never, criminals when they deem it necessary ("Fat Cats, Bigger Fish," "Takin' These")
All any nonsophomore need know of a minor popster, major wiseass, and great lost indie-rocker ("Teen Angst [What the World Needs Now]," "Mr. Wrong").
T-Bone Walker as Jerry Butler, only not as good ("There's Nothing Wrong," "What About Me").
Eric Bachmann describes degradation as if he wants you to avoid it like a plague ("Broken Man," "She Spread Her Legs and Flew Away").

artist: Bing Crosby With Bob Scobey's Frisco Jazz Band
comment: Dixieland swing, which in 1957 still qualified as jazz ("Exactly Like You," "Dream a Little Dream of Me").
thank not just Alanis but Tchad ("The Book," "Home")
the most sensible tunes in pop today ("It Don't Hurt," "My Favorite Mistake")
The only sure way to convince fools just how good Elvis was ("That's All Right," "My Baby Left Me").
ital keybs, natural percussion ("Armageddon")
with a bang, a whimper, a yowl, and a hook you can take with you ("The Great Decay," "Sink to the Beat")
Know more about complicity than anyone else in emo, know more about punk than anybody who thinks calling them emo will put them in their place ("In the Now," "Mama, I'm Satan").
imagine a band whose formative philosophical experience was Ralph Molina's drums ("All Your Money," "Drinking Again")
porno for heteros--a spoken, whispered, groaned, and grunted word recording (Bunny Buckskin & Carrington McDuffie, "Pink Sweatboxes"; John Bailiff, "Dirty Fare")
The Black Eyed Peas they ain't ("Lose Yourself to Dance," "Get Lucky")
Ibadan circa 1963--a quiet revolution in a language you don't understand ("Omo Lanke")
What they get for assuming psychedelia, futurism, and the drone are the same thing ("Down Like Disco," "All the Money or the Simple Life Honey").
Still droning drily enough if you give them more chances than they deserve, but note these famous last words: "I'm too old for this shit" ("Pope Reverend Jim," "You Are Killing Me")
They mean their hard-rock candy and Mercury posing, but they also mean their readme sheet and their funniest heroin song ever ("Givin' Up," "Friday Night").
deep funk versus jibber-jabber, dick versus diarrhea ("They Want EFX," "Looseys")

album: A Mark, a Mission, a Brand, a Scar
comment: His band, plus maybe his numbers, hone the jagged edge off his desperation ("Hands Down," "Carry This Picture").
punk, rap, dub--from an avant-jazz perspective, it's all one music ("Misbehaving," "Hands in the Pants")
lounge as Jackie Cain and Roy Kral, not Martin Denny, and why don't you know the reference? ("I'll Never Read Trollope Again," "Once Had a Woman")
Credible neosoul man glances nervously back toward 2step, saying hi with "Let's Dance" ("6 of 1 Thing," "Friday Night").
Post/anti-EDM electronica contextualizes honed feminist spoken-word ("Work It," "The Tunnel")
slide is beautiful ("Rock," "CeDell's Boogie")

Pretty lively for socialist moralists with no sense of humor ("Mind Sex," "It's Bigger Than Hip-Hop").
Know less about history (and literature) than they think they do, but more than their students ("16 Military Wives," "On the Bus Mall").
Recognized for well-dressed poesy, remembered for well-camouflaged hooks ("The Perfect Crime No. 2," "Summersong").
In their bad dream, life never stops, so they take the easy way out and fix it up a little ("Never Stops," "Nothing Ever Happened").
John Joseph McCauley III and friends feel the red dirt Other's pain without quite making it their own ("Mange," "Christ Jesus").
Po'-boy bluegrass rock makes some noise out there ("Working Class," "Real Slow")
self-appointed griot ("Fa Sho Shot," "God Complex")

the shock horror! the shock horror! ("Earth People," "Wild and Crazy," "Introduction")

synths, koras, whatever--it's slow, it's impassioned, it's pop, it's from Mali ("Galoya")

Providence organizer organizes blistering, sax-fed political punk for people who believe Bernie can conjure single payer just by wanting it so much ("Break a Few Eggs," "Poder Elegir," "Dancing in the Dark")

the boys in the band listen like it's their last chance ("Bad Blood," "School Days")

excellent songs pronounced with gratifying clarity ("Knockin' on Heaven's Door," "Dignity")
Funnier than the Chipmunks, give him that ("Must Be Santa," "Winter Wonderland").

album: 1965-1966: The Best of the Cutting Edge
comment: Scoff at Bootleg Series hype though you may (and should), you'll want to check and recheck Vol. 12's outtakes from his most amped-up period, only to conclude that the standard versions rool every goddamn time pre-Blonde on Blonde, when slowing it down a little turned out to have its downside ("Visions of Johanna," "Leopard-Skin Pill-Box Hat")
Smooth alt-country lifer writes his own songs without creating his own identity ("Where I've Been," "Black Jesus")

More songs about mortal struggle and mortal struggle--which can be beautiful, he's decided ("Down Here Below," "City of Immigrants").

Hootenannies, they useta call 'em ("Walls of Red Wing," "Me and Billy the Kid").
dystopia is hard, and El Producto will flog you with it if he has to ("Stepfather Factory," "Tuned Mass Damper")

comment: Not as mad as he says he is ("The Good Witch of the North," "Rock Star").

Especially abilities ("One Twenty," "Kept")

indefatigable-uh ("British People in Hot Weather")
great original sound ("Spoilt Victorian Child")

comment: Aesop Rock's beats elevate Slug and Murs' highly ancillary side project, which in turn gives his beats a lift ("Like You," "Permanent Standby").

Catchier when he's articulating his ill-informed politics than when he's making nice to the big bad record company he doesn't actually defy, now does he? ("All Black Everything," "Words I Never Said")

Darker and more socially conscious than their escapist admirers or their ideological detractors are equipped to notice ("Helplessness Blues," "Someone You Admire")

as comforting as an old pair of jeans, and as apt to fall apart ("Insinuation," "Pole Position")

artist: Juan Formell y Los Van Van
comment: stretching out now ("Te pone le cabaza mala," "Ni bombones ni caramelos")

drum 'n' bass lives--no doot (DJ Slip, "Ease Yourself"; Freaky Flow, "Here We Go")

potbelly beats, empty threats ("Bow Wow Wow," "Doobie to the Head")

comment: Dark-hued, technically inspired keybsy-Carsy punk-pop hooktunes as fashionable as a skinny tie ("Not I," "Anthropomorphic").

New Yorkers to the Slavic bone ("Greencard Husband," "God-Like")

easy-going racist-sexist motherfucker ("Lickshot")

three (more) CDs from their Fillmore East heyday ("China Cat Sunflower," "That's It for the Other One")

what pros ("Don't Damn Me")

selflessly serving the song for 17 years ("Queen of the Silver Dollar," "I'll Be Your San Antone Rose")

like Taj Mahal up and rose from the dead--only Taj is still alive ("When I Was a Cowboy [Western Plain]," "That Kate Adams Jive")

last of the independents ("There Stands the Glass," "Big Things")

they are family ("Blackman Know Yourself")

Like most expressions of childish pleasure, charming until it turns annoying ("We're From Barcelona," "Glasses").

always sincere, never wimpy, can write some ("Miss Williams' Guitar," "Ten Little Kids")

country blues in a wired world ("Diggin Mommas Tatters," "Nobody but You")

"It's Chitlin' Time"
