Less miserable than bitter, as he's always better off admitting ("First of the Gang to Die," "I Have Forgiven Jesus")
eternal rage ("Bad Religion")
but it's really great shtick ("On Your Feet or on Your Knees," "Born To Raise Hell")
sole great song-sound off latest go-it-alone plus three crisply creditable outtakes equals one decent EP ("Egoverride")
jump, jump, jump, jump, don't OD, bingo, yo mama ("Jump!," "B.I.N.G.O.")
r&b as self-induced dementia ("Power to the People," "Money Talks")
could be (even) cuter ("Would You Like to Swing on a Star," "The Circus Song," "Never Swat a Fly")

album: Meet Me Where They Play the Blues
comment: Last of the red hot mamas ("Soothe Me," "It Ain't the Meat, It's the Motion").
Blue blues and educational double entendres, New Orleans-style ("One Hour Mama," "Down Home Blues").
Icelandic mood music, you know, only with that elvish charm thing down ("Green Grass of Tunnel," "The Land Between Solar Systems")
howling for their supper ("That's What You Get," "364 Days");
you say you're really sick and tired of waiting for that Lucinda Williams record? ("Scorpio Tequila," "She Belongs to Me")
Nine lachrymose redemption songs in 52 minutes have more wit than you'd expect, more impact too, and less than Murry hopes in the way of "soul" ("The Ballad of the Pajama Kid," "Penny Nails")
"We're not gonna be yelling and screaming about ignorant shit" ("Dark Skinned White Girls," "Yesterday, Today").
How about vice principal of a small Afrocentric high school? ("The Science," "You Think You Know Me").
A Somalian with a parlor trick--making Danes sound Ethiopian ("Qax," "Fejigno").
Nice girl makes nicer--uh-oh ("Family Is Family," "Late to the Party")
Howlin' Wolf as gangsta psychopath/boogeyman ("Y'All Ain't Ready Yet," "Here I Go")
Right, they do Coldplay better than they did Weezer ("Inside of Love," "Blizzard of '77").
Ambivalent tunes about love and death that deserve the full title "Just Lucky, I Guess" ("Whose Authority," "The Film Did Not Go 'Round").
direct from the BET cartoon series to you ("Sholiz," "Po' Folks")
Bringing the knowledge, mixing in the sophistry, and dropping a laugh line he knows the boss can't top: "Everybody's saying my humility's infectious," what a card ("Cops Shot the Kid," "Everything")

album: Fire at Keaton's Bar and Grill
comment: The saloon of dreams goes up in smoke ("Bar Stool Paradise," "Jazz Night at Keaton's").
Narrative with jazz, jazz as narrative ("By the Page," "It's Alright").
Produced by Bob Marley's former and his own current sideman Tyrone Downie, his reggae sounds a mite mechanical, with tama drum touches reminding us what might be ("Don't Walk Away," "Bamba").

artist: Youssou N'Dour et le Super Etoile de Dakar
comment: Live in Athens 1987 by the grace of internationalist sponsor Peter Gabriel, who clunks him up musically as usual and oversees an encore where N'Dour sings backup. ("Immigrï¿½ï" "Nelson Mandela")
Tricky in Unwonderland, achieving the stasis true Tricky albums only play with ("Together Now," "Children's Story")
Prefer XTC to Love and love to ecstasy ("Come Down Now," "Mahnsanto").
Representing for treating women decent ("Paradise," "My Place").
10 standards--six Nelson, four ASCAP--meet more orchestral instruments than you can shake a stick at ("Night Life," "There Are Worse Things Than Being Alone")
Truth to tell, blues isn't his mï¿½ï¿½ï¿"Fools Paradise," "Texas Flood").
Now he knows--if he wants somebody who can't stop writing songs, better Harlan Howard than Ryan Adams ("Hallelujah," "$1000 Wedding").

album: Let's Face the Music and Dance
comment: Not his dance album, silly, this is Willie Nelson--just one of his after-80-you-get-to-sing-whatever-you-want albums ("Let's Face the Music and Dance," "I Can't Give You Anything but Love")

album: For the Good Times: A Tribute to Ray Price
comment: 83-year-old Country Icon Who (Supposedly) Had No Voice honors his stentorian elder loud and clear ("Heartaches by the Number," "Invitation to the Blues")
Having invented outlaw, he long ago elected to transcend it ("Still Not Dead," "I Made a Mistake")
Casually expert interpretations that say more about Sinatra's ingrained gravitas than Nelson's practiced ease ("A Foggy Day," "Summer Wind")
nonpareil miniatures ("Single Bed," "Casa Nova")
Moderately catchy-punky pop-rockers beat the crap out of Legs McNeill ("Let Them All Talk," "8 Track [I'm Coming Back]")

album: Walkin' in the Shadow of Life
comment: Funk meets junk in the real nitty gritty ("Kingdom Come," "Rivers of Babylon").
like taking a bath in the Gowanus Canal ("Paradise Don't Come Cheap," "Kickin' Like Bruce Lee")
Mix winning sincerity with formal nostalgia, much like the Cuban franchise holder (Cyrille Neville, "This Is My Country"; John Boutt "Why").
Never actually a "supergroup," now clearly a side project ("Crash Years," "Up in the Dark").
Weary blues from trying ("Talk to Me Baby," "End of the Summer")
A generation late, South Africa gets its postcolonial neotraditionalist ("Isothothobala," "Yekanini").

album: The Best of NG La Banda
comment: Virtuosic dance music con production values, part writing, and other things it doesn't necessarily need ("Papa Chango," "Cienfuegos").
soukous after the storm ("Roger Lino," "Mody")
hip hop's pop dream--living large, acting nice, staying smooth ("Let's All Get Down," "Save the Children")
Rilo Kiley great Jenny Lewis and two lesser grrrl-groupers try playfully to croon-chant their way into the alt-rock heart ("Guns," "Runaway")
Brooklyn DJ imagines a pan-subtropicalia stretching from the Caribbean all the way to India, and makes it happen ("N'Dini," "Sun Children").

album: Timespace: The Best of Stevie Nicks
comment: not a diva--a transgendered arena-rock god in all his/her grand self-regard ("I Can't Wait," "Has Anyone Ever Written Anything for You")
All pretense of deeper meaning worn into shtick, he's left with the aggro mood music that was always his calling ("Getting Smaller," "With Teeth").
Nigerian soul expat whose idea of poetry is "What is a song without a melody" smartens up when her songs have beats ("Kangpe," "Africans").
Great idea for instrumental funk--Afrika 70 meets Detroit 00 ("Nu Tunes," "New Song").
Right, their best song is by Champion Jack Dupree--who never played this hot and strong in his long life ("Eaglebird," "Soldier").
Retro-futurist Peruvian salsa, freshest at its most dub ("Kumana," "Se Me Van").
the beats their statement, the ballads their way of life ("I Thought She Knew," "It Makes Me Ill")
they survive "writing their own songs," and they positively enjoy their bells and whistles ("Selfish," "Do Your Thing")
not soukous paradise--just a sweet stopover ("Anicet")

artist: Sally Nyolo and the Original Bands of Yaoundï¿½ï
comment: Zap Mama grad conducts nationwide talent hunt (Bidjoï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½"Chantal"; Sally Nyolo, "Bikoutsi").
Sixties Schmixties--back when they were a tribute band they were the Diamond Dogs ("Rock 'n' Roll Star," "Slide Away")
Bluesman-as-songster bolsters exclamatory originals with Bill Withers and David Essex covers ("Trying to Get to You!" "You're Wrong for That!").
Ambient hip-hop, all shadowy soundscape and free-floating intelligence ("Reallocated Resources," "Galapagos Four").
Don't worry--he isn't really as sad as he makes his bindle sound ("No Key, No Plan," "Missing Children").
Will Sheff's voice and temperament sweeten as his career finds its own level ("Famous Tracheotomies," "Don't Move Back to LA")
soundtrack to the horror movie in your dumb young mind--with band name to match ("Outlive")
If you'd been doing this since 1994, wouldn't you front-load volume one? ("No Simple Machine," "Visiting Hours")
Never convinces me her melodramatic manner reflects deep pain as opposed to raw aesthetic self-regard ("Intern," "Never Be Mine")
avant-minimalist and pop-simplistic, Japanese and English, old and new--all is one ("I'm Not Getting Enough," "Rise II")
Middle-class Nigerian mystery man lays down charming 1975-1985 Afrodisco catalogue before trading in the material world for his Lord and Savior Jesus Christ ("Atomic Bomb," "Love Is Blind")
Basque percussionists meet Saharans, Adivasi, Sami and most notably Mongols for shamanistic background music and documentary film ("Lauhazka," "Saapmi").
Brooklyn DJs remix William Parker-Hamid Drake jazz for groove, mood, and tiny profit ("Gold Weave," "All Be[Tween]")
"The band formerly known as the Time" are shocked that you should believe time is real--but of course, it is ("Condensate," "One Step")
better Exene in band than Exene with backup, but the X factor was a Y chromosome ("Who's Laughin' Now," "River City")
sincere SWF, enjoys tunes on acoustic guitar, likes technology and musos with glasses ("She Cries Your Name," "How Far")
So she wasn't techno after all--glad we got that straight ("Stolen Car," "Central Reservation [Original Version]").
senior moments of an aginger sex bomb ("I Can't Remember Not Loving You," "Neva Sawyer")
Argentinian pianist thinks classical but feels tango, only then his mind wins ("Danza," "Globalizacion")
fatback hip house plus handle of the year ("I Like It")
Not-so-stealth Democrat respectfully requests that Nashville let him back in the frat ("Shattered Glass," "High Life")
"We're the buttfuckers of rock and roll/We want to sock it to your hole" ("Bunnies," "The Cocksucker Club")
Hayley girl--it's OK to rock, it's OK to agonize, but you really don't have to yell so much ("Careful," "Ignorance").
Speed-freek noiseniks kick it into gear behind mad new drummer ("Vision of Repair," "The Gold We're Digging").
An hour of foreplay and he's ready for more ("The One for Me," "So Hot").
completists' advisory--two good otherwise unavailables, eight bucks ("Westie Can Drum," "Winner of the")
slowly winning a heartwarming battle against constitutional melancholia ("Mankind," "Around the Bend")
Rock as inner struggle, eternally externalized ("Of the Girl," "Insignificance").
masters of their own audio, with soft spots where their emotions can go ("Save You," "Bushleaguer")
Two discs worth of the Baobab of Benin, or so 'twas claimed--a little too dependent on Other People's Clave, I'd say ("Las Melodias," "Atimawuin Dagamasi")
postpunk as likable litterateur, band as predictable support ("Story of My Life," "Kathleen")
"yeah, is a good joke" ("Open Door," "Jungle Safari")
grant him this--he's a hooky sumbitch ("Into the Great Wide Open," "Two Gunslingers)
channeling Patsy Cline, Edith Piaf, Memphis Minnie, and Jill Corey through Queen Billie herself ("Walkin' After Midnight," "Was I?," "Always a Use")
Not a good sign when the skits stand out and your old demos are a welcome add-on ("Bang! Bang!" "White Babies")
Keeping the conscious faith for seven years in the corporate wilderness, he remained relevant by leapfrogging bling and ringtone imperatives altogether ("Push," "Hold On").

"Our revolutionaries want Grammys and Oscars/Making a mockery of the music to be pop stars," so this revolutionary makes a sermon of it instead, which doesn't work either until Jean Grae adds her mojo ("Assassins," "Haile Selassie Karate")
fading tunefully to wan ("Lost in Future Ruins," "Surrounded")
give her some chiliasm, all she wants is some chiliasm ("Baby I Can't Please You," "I Need Love")

album: The Kids We Used to Be
comment: Memories of a Dutchess County puberty ("Come Back to Peekskill," "The Bros. of Summer")
Brian Peter George St. John le Baptiste de la Salle Phoenix, if anything ("Lisztomania," "Rome").

album: Beating Back the Claws of the Cold
comment: Weedy vocals, flowering tunes, imagery from God's great material world ("Poor Old Ra," "Hope, Was Not a Smith Family Tradition").

album: Thirteen Tales of Love and Revenge
comment: Two wicked sisters harmonize the arch, melodic lowdown on the wine-bar set ("Ruin," "Go to Heaven").
After a last fling with Eminem, she does prove, eventually, that schlock can't bring her down ("Revenge," "Better Life")
from a dynamite soul singer, these would be dynamite soul ballads ("Teach Me to Breathe," "Faces and Names")
Articulating anxieties not necessarily their own since 1996 ("Bright Lights," "The Never-Ending Why").
gonna give you every inch of my erectile dysfunction ("One More Cup of Coffee," "Darkness, Darkness")
how dark can it be if it's so full of guitars? ("Fractured [Like Chandeliers]," "Every Holy Shroud")
irony-pop gone hermeneutic--with nothing to say ("That Was the Greatest Song," "Sugar Baby")
Sade for androids ("Sour Times," "Wandering Star")
"I don't want to think about it I just want to get down," only neither turns out to be in his control ("Fuck Your Stuff," "Weird Friends [We Don't Even Live Here]")
Spiffy new bratmobile fully equipped with monotone, invective, and unguarded pride ("The Gap," "Wishlist")
"A boy inside the body of a man" spitting his father's rock and roll readymades--or more likely his uncle's ("Respect Me," "Death of a Rolling Stone").

album: The Presidents of the United States of America
artist: The Presidents of the United States of America
comment: younger fresher fellows ("Lump," "We Are Not Going To Make It," "Kitty")
Honky tonk Iglesias ("Crazy Arms," "City Lights").
Modest band posits small solutions for young women pursuing busy lives ("You've Got a Million," "Bronte Blues")
Don Knotts Jr. joins the Minutemen ("Mr. Knowitall," "Spegetti Western")
Our greatest composer-performer of romantic nu-funk erotica wakes up 40 years later wishing he was Janelle Monae ("Breakfast Can Wait," "Funknroll")
you know he's a cornball at heart, and you know some of these songs, but if you're as Yule-friendly as he is you won't care ("Silent Night All Day Long")
smack them up, they deserve it, but they still got the beats ("Mindfields," "Funky Shit")
Noticeably alive even backed by blues bros at folk fest, he could be live-er still ("Big Chief," "Got My Mojo Workin'")
Finding the tuneful poetry in a moment when most punks are well-meaning dorks going through a phase ("Happiness Is All the Rage," "Living Around").
Things are so bad out there that the Amerindie old-timer ups and writes "political songs for non-political people" ("ýýýýLet Freedom Ring!" "Hot Talk").

I'd fret more about how set in its ways their Public Enemy-Rage Against the Machine alliance is if the machinery of American capitalism had loosened up even a little in the decades since they began their railing ("Living on the 110," "Smashit")
Life is more macaroni than cheese for a rapper girl fronting alt beats ("The Living," "Peanuts").
Hating playas is fine, hating play amn't ("41:19," "What What").
Pained, somewhat congealed, they soldier on ("Give Peace a Damn," "Mine Again")

There was always Peter Hammill guff behind the punk guff, and as long as Rotten-Lydon is excoriating busted toilets or corporate capital it's amusing enough--but not, please Jesus, when he's roaming the "Big Blue Sky" for eight minutes ("Corporate," "Double Trouble")
Spoken-word documentary with stirring musical accompaniment honors the life and death of the Welsh coal industry ("Mother of the Village," "They Gave Me a Lamp")
Displaced soprano asks musical question: is this home or exile? ("Ungirthed," "Lofticries")

album: King Push: Darkest Before Dawn--The Prelude
comment: Well-bent Timbeats back the usual easy coca lies/hard coca truths and are docked a notch for arrogating Freddie Gray and Public Enemy into the kind of protest rap I thought he was too real for. ("Crutches, Crosses, Caskets," "Retribution")
Sexier than your average prefab sexpots, but no fabber ("Wait a Minute," "Beep").
If jazz lite it must be, by all means, rap on top ("Shaka," "Official").
Rhythm experiments, and later for the improvisation experiments ("Black Boy," "I Got Rhythm").
Conscious reggae with a woman's touch, not that you'd always know it from her timbre ("Yad to the East," "Daddy").
for 16 songs in 36 minutes, they [heart] Ramones and rhyme with "beers" ("Ursula Finally Has Tits," "Fuck the World")

album: I Might Be Wrong: Live Recordings
comment: four from Kid A, three from they forget, and one minor new love song add up to a slightly unhinged live remix album ("National Anthem," "Everything in Its Right Place")
See: No Hope Radio.
Less excitable now that they've gotten used to the money--funny how that happens ("Do Yoga," "Real Chill")
Two hours of generic sui generis hip-hop so easy on the ears you might think they never got the chance to utter the word "bitch" once--but you'd be very wrong ("Up in My Cocina," "Keep God First")
metal for rap-lovers--and opera-haters ("Wake Up," "Know Your Enemy")
If only it promised as much for the future of rock leftism as for the future of rock guitar ("Calm Like a Bomb," "War Within a Breath").
"Let's take their bail money/Make it hair and nail money" ("Imperial," "Do the Ladies Run This . . . ").

Most great schlock transcends petty boundaries of language and culture, and most great schlock is lifted by a touch of strange--when it's not swamped by gobs of gentility ("Rang De Basanti," "Barso Re").
Having fun with the human beatbox (and friends) in the studio (and on stage) ("Southern Girl," "Night Riders").
Multiculti utopianism as posited by bedreaded Israeli and his Ethiopian, Arab, and Surinamese countrymen ("Be'Yom Shabbat," "Mi'Ma'amakim").
steam-powered industrial ("In My Face")
sui generis after all these years ("Don't Be Mean," "No One's Little Girl")
She learns to sing love-songs-with-backup and indie boys think she's regressed (even though she's still pretentious!) ("Ears Ring," "The Awful Truth of Loving").
The classicism that had better be its own reward ("Strong Island," "When I B on Tha Mic").
Essential things his specialty ("Holy Are You," "Dedicated").

album: Advice From a Father to a Son
comment: Better on road safety than on wimmin, but not altogether devoid of second-line wisdom either way ("Advice From a Father to a Son," "More Than One Flavor")
pretty funny, especially if you can't get enough jokes about classical music ("Speilhur," "Links")
hippiedom as punk ("My Back Pages," "Have You Ever Seen the Rain")
"Liberated Woman" plus Mad Professor ("Kill the Police Bill")
crossover beats, crossover 'tude--hey, "You do me and I do you" ("Ram Dancehall," "Let's Get It On")
Having waited years to unload her wisdom, she does go on about it ("Believe Me [9th Wonder HaHaHaHa Remix Mix]," "Celebration")
dance single of the year plus the usual ("Work the Walls")

Pere Ubu synthmaster concocts instrumental evocations of the historical period preceding not the bomb we're waiting for now, but the bomb they were waiting for in the '50s, which had the decency never to arrive ("If Only There Was More Time," "Day Shift")
If they don't open when the Fall hit Chicago, Skull Kontrol died in vain ("Milk Crate," "Go-Go Girls").
New Age fuck fiends ("Scar Tissue," "Purple Stain").

artist: The Red Krayola With Art & Language
comment: The visages of Wile E. Coyote, George W. Bush, Jimmy Carter, John Wayne, and Ad Reinhardt rendered in detailed words sung-spoken over thematic background and Mayo Thompson weirdness--now that's what I call art-rock ("President George W. Bush," "Ad Reinhardt").
Chronic alcoholism as radical insecurity, outspokenly antiracist yet most educational at its most unideological ("Four Part Cure," "Stars")
The best in retro roil, and when I picked my faves I alighted as if by magic on two of the four they didn't write ("You Got Me Hummin'," "Uptight Tonight").
takes his rock so straight he could almost make you believe it ("Hip Hop Thighs #17," "Last Night")
Whatever it signifies, it's the second and less musically pointed of two linked mini-albums that translates "arrow," where the first is "bow" ("Ritmo de Moï¿½ï¿½" "Se Amanhence")
something to suck on while you dream of Lauryn ("Golden Boys," "Ice King")
AOR country gets a life ("Life Changes," "Sixteen")
Kanye homeboy proves who his friends are by rapping all over their mixtape ("All They Do Is Dis," "Devil's Pie").

True politics, true musicianship, and true diversity, with barely an anthem or fight song to be heard ("John Brown [Feat. Fay Victor]," "Knock That Statue Down [Feat. Mark Ribot & Syd Straw]," "Ain't Gonna Let Them Turn Us Around [Feat. Steve Earle & Tift Merritt]")

album: Having a Party With Jonathan Richman
comment: confessions of a reluctant grownup ("Monologue About Bermuda," "The Girl Stands Up to Me Now")
Honestly monikered Warped Tour vets demonstrate the continued compatibility of blues chords, rock rebellion and cunnilingus ("All Night," "Naughty Corner").
his pain flows like whiskey, and he just wants to moan the blues about it ("Love Is Just a Gamble," "Crying the Blues")
From the '70s vaults, Quiet Storm as per the Gershwins, Cole Porter, and similars who sound even better ("I'm in the Mood for Love," "You Go to My Head").
from the lucky doghouse, Jack Ingram, Bruce Robison, and the leader of the pack, his big brother Charlie (Charlie Robison, "My Hometown," "Sunset Boulevard")
Deena Shoshekes throws Cucumbers fans a curveball ("I Feel My Sex," "Test Drive").
plays great slide, rides catchy rhythms, writes decent songs ("Built for Comfort," "For the Love of a Woman")
still know how to construct, play, and--sometimes--sing a song ("You Don't Have To Mean It," "Flip the Switch")
tribute to the modern art-song, country-folk division ("Western Wall," "1917")
"Appalachian wildflower" cracks wise as craftily as she speaks her heart--more craftily, in fact ("Alimony," "Rattlesnake in the Road")
US indie-rocker turned UK singer-songwriter, "ginny-mick courage" intact ("Still in the Family," "Party Dress")
badder than you know, but not than you wish ("Badder Than You," "Casabank Queen")
The Kate Bush of PJ Harvey ("Into My Blood," "Lacuna")
Lady bartender's brother reports jocularly from southernmost North Carolina ("Wall Street Pirate," "21st Century American Farmer").

artist: Roswell Rudd & the Mongolian Buryat Band
comment: Weird trombone vocalism, weird Tuvan vocalism, Arctic ingenue ("Gathering Light," "Four Mountains").
Beats ain't black or white, hard ain't black or white, sexism ain't black or white, etc. ("A Christmas Fucking Miracle," "She's Mine Pt 2")
Nusrat is Nusrat, these guys straight qawwali, and more fun with saxophones by me ("Ya Mustapha")
another loungecore alternative ("Hang On to Your Love," "No Ordinary Love")
I'm glad she finally put some beats on her sang-froid, but by the time she gets around to setting Ghost up with a 16 he'll probably be out of the life ("Soldier of Love," "Babyfather").
flute zouk ("Roulï¿½" "Soldat papillon")
Polyphonic Spree spin-off indulges her long-thwarted fondness for crystalline melody and fetching enunciation ("Laughing With a Mouth of Blood," "Black Rainbow").

album: Dancing With Bad Grammar: The Director's Cut
comment: Genteelly verbose Anglo-Nigerian singer-strophewriter hangs looser and longer--and a few times meaner, which turns him into a motherfucker ("Loosley on My Mind," "Day to Day [For Six Days a Week]")
Brazilian reed player embraces classical canon without betraying his rhythmic schooling ("Seven Days," "Somewhat Frevo").

Four raw, jamlike, folkloric Mande songs from Mali--one lead singer and three backups playing two ngonis, a scraper, and a shaker, hypnotically but perhaps also forbiddingly ("Fakoli 'Blacksmith Tribe'")
Fellow record nerds rejoice--first singer-songwriter ever to devote verse-and-chorus to The Penguin Guide to Jazz on CD ("Cook and Morton," "Song About 'Soul Finger'")
The double-disc sprawl makes Max Bemis seem less pretentious, not more--as if he can't be bothered to pretend he's not a mess ("Sorry, Dudes. My Bad," "Retarded in Love").
cocaine slanger as around-the-way G--paranoid, self-righteous, public-spirited, so downhome ("Safe," "On My Block")
Fourth World Vol. V: Possible Technopangaea ("Blur," "Anonymous Shark")
NPR stalwart, EP folkie, student of Donne ("The Party Line," "Urban Friends")
They tried the country and they tried the city, but speed was the only thing that made them feel better--as bluegrass and punk, respectively ("Rumspringa," "Professional").

I await the blessed day when Vincent Vazquez or Angel Del Villar II taps this wellspring of comfy hooks in the service of a rhyme about butter almond ice cream or improving our city parks. ("90210," "3500")
The premise isn't "I'm new here," it's "I'm not dead," and he strains mightily to get 28 spare minutes out of it ("Me and the Devil," "On Coming From a Broken Home [Part 1]").
their grim, unpretentious, personal best ("Good Under Pressure," "The Garden Path")
a good old-fashioned cry ("Dying Days," "Traveler")
A warm, subtly serrated instrument normally disabled by cryogenic material and production, which these American classics ain't, so eat it ("Here I Am [Come and Take Me]," "Knock on Wood").

album: Candy Licker: The Sex & Soul of Marvin Sease
comment: Chitlin' king bowdlerized--where where where is "The Bitch Git It All"? ("I'm Mr. Jody," "Do You Need a Licker?").
their girlfriends would be very proud if they weren't so pissed off ("Freed Pig," "Truly Great Thing")
angry three-headed wimp on the long hard road to love ("Soul and Fire," "Sister")
Intelligently, uncomfortably, ex-boho singer-songwriter excavates his generational malaise ("Bless Her Insecurity," "Darlin' I'm Not Earning Enough")
High-generic son, pretty much like you-know-who, except I'll take rough-voiced eightysomething Pï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½"Oye Como Sena," "Llore Como Llore").
The rapping telephone booth repairman goes on tour with his good buddy guy Anders Holm ("Tanya T," "Tickled Pink")
Frantic salsa con reggae from, er, Paris--autï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿"Jumpi," "Si yo llego, yo llego").
They didn't predict the crash--too busy. ("Liquid Meat [Into a Form]," "Keep the Babies Warm").

album: The Road to Kesan: Turkish Rom and Regional Music of Thrace
comment: Gypsy intensity from Greco-Bulgarian Turkey, artist uncredited on cover, somebody sample that daire drum, or is it a darbuka? ("Kiremit/Nasti usava," "Tulum")

album: Esoteric vs. Japan: Pterodactyl Takes Tokyo
comment: Action-figure manga-rap at its most toon ("Mecha Mecha," "Gigantor Says Anything").
tough broads, hard rock ("Miss Understood," "The History of My Future")
.667 ("Joltin' Joe DiMaggio," "The Ballad of Denny McLain")
postpunk cute, folk-rock homely, dream-pop barely there ("S.F. Sorrow," "Ipecac")

It is what it is, ambient and arty and alien and amusing all at once--random (??) talk in a language you don't understand overlaid with guitar improv to divert cab drivers in a Cairo traffic jam ("Music for the Egyptians," "The Enemy of My Enemy")
the saddest sound he ever heard ("Old Men," "One Thin Dime")
The saxophonist's Ribs and Brisket Revue scarfs Borscht Belt blues and coffee-colored bagels-a-rooney ("Essen," "A Bissel Bop").
a little skronk, a little tune, some weird vocal overlay, and voila--cable soundtrack fusion ("Hit Single," "Ghost Planet National Anthem")
You'll wonder: Is Zooey Deschanel homier than Feist, or just a good actress? ("I Should Have Known Better," "Sentimental Heart").
Committed to clichï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½"The More I Drink," "I Don't Care").
Strong-drawlin' gal freshens up themes that ain't dead yet ("I Ain't Dead Yet," "Regular Joe").
plays better blues readymades than he writes, writes better blues readymades than his front man sings ("Born With a Broken Heart," "I'm Leaving You [Commit a Crime]")
Pretty is hard, but that doesn't make it signify ("Weird Divide," "New Slang").
For no discernible reason, blues and Spanglish bring out the irreverence in her ("La Cantina," "Mouth of the Mississippi").

album: Soon There Will Be Shooting at Unarmed Men
comment: "Hey, hey, doesn't matter what you say" and other pissed-off disillusions ("Taking Care of Business," "Four-Eyed McClayvie").
Note that in nominally socialist Sweden, simple pop emotions remain a spiritual possibility ("The Comeback," "Very Loud").
Delving the progressively more familiar truths of the four-minute pop song ("Show Me Something New," "1999").
Cary Ann Hearst and helpmate/partner penetrate the South's musical mythos ("Birmingham," "Kemba's Got the Cabbage Moth Blues")
Hookmeister with a voice too big and/or a vocal style too self-regarding to keep things light--and now, one stone masterpiece in her kit ("Chandelier," "Elastic Heart")
Finesses the distinction between Latin lovely and Latin schlock, only not when the guy in charge takes the lead ("Fuego Que Te Llama," "Come See Us Play")
Scared straight enough to rap about being paranoid ("I Can't Go On This Way," "Feel It in the Air").
Quite possibly the most assiduous Jay-Z impressions you'll ever hear ("No Hook," "The Reunion")
listen to the originals, keep the covers ("Let's Take Some Drugs and Drive Around," "I'm Straight")
Noise-tune simplified for baritone monotone ("Random Rules," "Night Society").

album: Sounds From a Bygone Age: Vol. 3
comment: Falsetto fanciers will effervesce ("Cine Are Fata Mare," "Lelita, Floare").

album: Music in My Bones: The Best of Joe Simon
comment: He did teen, he did soul, he did country, he did disco, and after the hits stopped coming he hit the pulpit ("Moon Walk Part 1," "The Chokin' Kind").
his life in the bush of a fully-formed middle-class music scene more sophisticated than he'll ever be ("The Obvious Child," "The Coast")
64-year-old liberal singer-songwriter reveals unanticipated knack for soundscaping ("Beautiful," "Outrageous").
while they merely lionized the obliging Mick Hucknall, we fell for the odious Michael Bolton, which ought to scare the Anglophobia out of anyone ("Money's Too Tight To Mention," "So Beautiful")
stupid, funky ("Jump on It," "Bark Like You Want It")
Make that 83 love songs-these 14 delicately rendered when you're in the mood, preciously undercut when you're not ("You You You You You," "Waltzing Me All the Way Home").
After 10 years of hard labor, gadje neatniks lively it up Gypsy brass style ("Pavketov Stakato," "Sancti Petri").
praise the Lord--I can hardly understand a word they're singing ("Hell Awaits")

The message being that only those ready to give up the transient pleasure of a good tune are ready to confront the meaninglessness of their neoliberal-capitalist lives ("Giddy on the Ciggies," "Face to Faces")
as sexy as their last song("Delicious," "Inbetweener")
The aging Smalls lacks the chops to put his jokes across, leaving Steve Vai and Joe Satriani with funnier lines ("Gummin the Gash," "When Men Did Rock")
if you can dig art-rock fantasia--and hey, why not?--this has a nice witchy wail to it ("Rhinoceros")
he could too be popular--he just doesn't want to be, that's all ("Rose Parade," "Say Yes")
high tune, low affect ("Waltz #2 [XO]," "Everybody Cares, Everybody Understands")
Good thing she's still a little nuts, because funny's beyond or beneath her ("Whirl Away," "Memento Mori").
With more chops, heart, and brains than most 17-year-olds who think they're indie, she remains very 17, which is nice ("Boy," "A Reason")
No new songs, but the foot-stomping is exceedingly polysyllabic ("The Devil's Real," "Link of Chain").
DIY Pylon miniaturizers squeeze 10 songs into 14 minutes for the ADD demographic ("No Problem," "This Is")
The fun rock and roll record his memoir says he's craved all century, only the memoir is more fun--I Never Met a Story I Didn't Like, buy it ("Hey Pretty Boy," "Come On Up")
the anger of the long-distance runner ("Story of My Life," "Ring of Fire")
Post-rock special--prog as credible jazz, with Robert Wyatt long gone and Hugh Hopper saying goodbye ("Down the Road," "Gesolreut").

album: The Destroyed Room: B-Sides and Rarities
comment: Washing Machine having cheaped out on "The Diamond Sea" at 19:35, they concoct an instrumental album to introduce the 25:48 version ("Fire Engine Dream," "Queen Anne Chair").
gongs, factories, and radio transmissions, on the moon and under the sea
Like toddlers, born punks believe falling down is how you get where you're going ("We Got the Days," "99 Degrees").
great tunes, corny songs ("Without a Trace," "Somebody To Shove")
Rappers so intelligent they only do an album when Prince Paul gives them some beats ("Dead Man Walking," "Fourmation," "Mr. Freeman Skit").
brutal depression simplified ("Ty Cobb," "Applebite")
Stooges for airports ("Big City")
there are smarter rednecks ("Ugly," "Bubba Talk")
recyclable Michael Franti--he's black, he's grooveful, he's Gil Scott-Heron ("Crime To Be Broke in America," "People in the Middle")
"Why you wanna be a nigga?/You was God before" ("Black Love?" "Find Ya Bes'").
Madonna next door (". . . Baby One More Time," "Soda Pop").
Pop queen or punk symbol, she comes direct from the land of dreams ("You Can't Put Your Arms Around a Memory," "She Talks to Rainbows").
Plowing past the fun, but never quite plowing it under ("Fun," "Plough")
"hippies," as in "En Why doing for funk syncopation what San Fran did for blues shuffle" ("Hungry Hamed's," "Cleopatra's Cat")
what's not to like? ("Hungry Hamed's," "Cleopatra's Cat")

album: Ladies and Gentlemen We Are Floating in Space
comment: even druggies deserve a fair hearing ("All of My Thoughts," "Cop Shoot Cop")

album: T.S. Eliot Reads The Waste Land and The Hollow Men
comment: what it says--loathes better than Uncle Bill, recites better than Dr. Dre, ace beat tracks, five bucks
"And you're wrong if you think/I am unhappy/Just because I wanna stay/Alone in my house/And sing my Swiss tunes/In a doleful English monotone" ("Youth," "Chasing Bugs")
windbag in love ("Cross My Heart," "The Long Goodbye")
his gift for social realist literature exceeds his gift for political music ("The Ghost of Tom Joad," "Across the Border")
Overstatement is his weakness, and Tom Morello definitely doesn't rein in him, but only cynics resist his skill set ("Harry's Place," "Dream Baby Dream")
It is my sad duty to report that he's a lot better at tragedy than comedy ("Feels Like Summer," "Fun!")
more confident and relaxed in their Sgt. Pepper retro, which naturally loosens its grip ("Goldstar," "San Diego")

artist: Tammy Faye Starlite and the Angels of Mercy
comment: dotty comedy, country parody, blasphemous obscenity, running incest joke ("God Has Lodged a Tenant in My Uterus," "DidI Shave . . . ")
Horrorshow abuse in living stereo--they mean it, man ("I'm With Stupid," "Wisconsin Death Trip").
dying in stereo, nothing left to say ("Slang of Angels," "Things I Miss the Most")

album: This Is It and I Am It and You Are It and So Is That and He Is It and She Is It and It Is It and That Is That
comment: The more concrete she gets, the less math can help her ("Roads? Where We're Going We Don't Need Roads," "The Package Is Wrapped").

How best expiate a conflicted grief--sardonic musing? Depressive rage? Ironic japes? Cautionary tales? Misery so brutal you burrow through to the other side? Surely something with more tensile strength than musical flower arrangements, doncha think? ("Death With Dignity," "Carrie and Lowell")
precious pop polymath as sardonic solo seer ("Re-Hab," "C'mon Everybody")
Bowie lives! ("Heart of Stone," "Oh No, Not You Again")
longer on groove than song, longer on song than the brothas ("Brotha," "Bottles and Cans")
Electronics more human than sopranos! ("Sleepless," "Luxury Problems")
Garage punk contracts Dylan virus, which makes his sore throat even scratchier ("Be Brave," "Laugh at Sex, Not Her").
sing-alongs for the international brotherhood of disenfranchised world-music punks ("Gamma Ray," "Bhindi Bagee")
teenpunk alienation at its most normal, with Satan impinging from the wings ("Heart Attack," "Motivation")
If Yo La weren't so darn pop ("Asphalt Road," "Fussy Fuss").
Sweet sad gal and dreamy nerdy guy let their tuneful murk do the talking--well, drawling ("Dust in the Gold Sack," "Watered Down")
Earl's return of the depressed is so much more soulful than Tyler's revenge of the nerds ("Sunday," "Sasquatch")
Bad old girl makes good ("Amy," "Drink Myself Single")
DJ nightmare for the war on terror ("Vietnam?" "Dream").
From the budding alt-rock Athens of Cincinnati, Ohio, three hairy thrash-pop guys help one bebanged post-riot grrrl work out her frustrations ("I'm Fine," "Reanimator")
They want more life, as should we all ("Ammunition," "Gone").
overarrangements no prob for we who avoid art-rock like the plague this means to cure ("Prison Song," "Bounce")
Firm in their convictions and (relatively) simple in their art rock ("B.Y.O.B.," "Radio/Video").
Bordello's bassist beckons ancestral Abysinnian atmospheres ("The Response," "Beyond Fasiladas").

album: Pulling Out Just Enough to Win
comment: Aerosmith: The New Generation ("Secretary's Day," "CYT").
When James Y. Jones took up West Side blues, the commercially fading Wolf himself was 20 years younger than Jones is now ("My Head Is Bald," "Tend to Your Business").

album: Woody Guthrie and Songs of My Oklahoma Home
comment: 20 Woody songs done calmly and faithfully, as a spiritual resource ("Belle Starr," "Talkin' Dust Bowl Blues")
A holding action like most Record Store Day vinyl, and not better because it's live-er no matter what Afrofolkies want to believe ("Tisnant an Chatma," "Outamachek")
Nice guy hip-hop from the community of the well-meaning mind, its soul in its skits and its smarts in its beats ("Just Not True," "Hardcore Gentlemen").
Thirteen-eighths of Bartï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½k--Gypsies kiss the rings of their high-class fri"De Cind Ma Aflat Multimea," "Romanian Folk Dances").

artist: Skatemaster Tate and the Concrete Crew
comment: rap so swinging it takes its bass upright ("Irv's," "Hey Wooley")
Stuck in L.A. with a raggedy band, Jody's prophet still makes infidelity signify ("Jody's Got Your Girl and Gone," "Little Bluebird").
The kind of blues where spiritual intensity vanquishes cultural pain ("Past Times," "Walk on Water")
Conscious-blues hoedown featuring Alvin Youngblood Hart, Guy Davis, and a tol'able Keb' Mo'--everybody but Corey Harris and his MacArthur ("Ran So Hard the Sun Went Down," "The Way It Goes").
Such as getting mauled by bears, getting overwhelmed by Paris, and foreseeing the end of grrrlpop civilization as they know it ("Huffy Walrus," "Paris Syndrome").
Imagine a shallower, less soulful, altogether French-er Art Brut, two years ago when they were fresh ("Homecoming," "Sunset Beach").
Believe your old dad--"What I figured out was I needed more time to figure you out" ain't gonna work ("Take Me Anywhere," "You Wouldn't Like Me").
Not exactly the first pop stars to be better at sex than love ("Closer," "Drove Me Wild")

album: Yes Darling, But Is It Art? (Early Singles and Rarities)
comment: part time punks and how ("Part Time Punks," "Arthur the Gardener")
Finally grime-ragga-whatevs produces one of the mildly likable commercial rappers we thought we had such a monopoly on ("Till I'm Gone," "Simply Unstoppable")

artist: Thao With the Get Down Stay Down
comment: Cheerfully braving love's unpleasant surprises with a lot of help from her friends ("When We Swam," "The Give").
Let's hear it for rock bands that speak kindly of social workers ("About to Break," "One in Ten").
You can hear him coming out of his funk better if you let the words come to you rather than hanging on every one ("Bed Bugs," "Every Song Sung to a Dog")
I thought she loved me but she didn't--why does this keep happening? ("Shane and Dixie," "For the Sake of Mary")
and he writes better songs than Clapton too ("Outside of the Inside," "Happy Days and Auld Lang Syne")
Finally, it says here, an acoustic record--which he leads with some rock and roll ("Miss Patsy," "My Soul My Soul").
A considerable guitarist whose voice fuses two gene pools deflects his songwriting problem with country covers ("Change of Heart," "Walking the Floor Over You").
Pretty loose for hardcore, pretty loose for militant too ("No Prevail," "Go Where the Kids Go").
down dirges and squeaky-fast dissonance for the insatiable pomo tunehound ("Helzapoppin," "Outer Space")

artist: Throw That Beat in the Garbagecan!
comment: the EP, not The Cool Album, which ain't ("Cool," "Little Red Go-Cart")
despite nondescript backup and much solo acoustic, his best crappy live tape yet ("Blame It on Mom," "Too Much Junkie Business")
Docked a notch for disrespecting pubic hair ("No Mediocre," "New National Anthem," "About the Money")
Riot gurl ("Heavy Mood," "Defenders")
He's as cute as you want him to be, and he really lasts a long time ("Let the Groove Get In," "Pusher Love Girl")
Moderately smart lo-fi punk lyrics await your magnifying glass, moderately cute lo-fi punk tunes await your shovel ("Faces on Fire," "[My Head]").
Fun enough example of arty equaling shallow and maybe vice versa ("Guggenheim," "Day to Day")
Lost postpunk album, more pop and less art than anyone knew at the time ("Seeing," "Cheap Machines").
as prole as Music Row gets ("Ain't Nothing Wrong With the Radio," "Cold Gray Kentucky Morning")

First he's a tradition-conscious trucker preserving the global warming equivalent of the railroad song, then he springs "Drill Here, Drill Now" on us ("The Ballad of Danger Dave and Double Trouble," "Chicken Truck").
Adolescent angst never gets old ("Arms Against Atrophy," "Titus Andronicus").

album: Le Red soul Program (10 Points Program)
comment: Only in a city as white as Barcelona could a John Sinclair tribute band sound so garage ("Capitalism Plus Dope Equals Genocide," "You Gotta Do It")
She's from Sierra Leone, she's trilingual, and it sounds more like her career than her life to me ("Blamah Blamah," "Ayiboh")
Funk-gospel pro juices self-help you can believe in with all-purpose dance-piration ("Bring It," "Blend").
sexy liars of the year ("If I Had No Loot," "Anniversary")
music for a postmodern sex ritual ("The Psychic," "The Darkened Room")
"improvisation" goes trad ambient--usually with a pulse, which usually makes all the difference ("Mixed Blood," "Slow Loris Versus Poison Snail")

album: The Queen Is in the House
comment: house as in disco, house as in a home ("Loca," "Payback Is a Bitch [What Goes Around Comes Around]")

album: Live at the One Love Peace Concert
comment: More politics than Bob or Bunny, and here's where they got him beaten within an inch of his life ("Speech," "Legalize It/Get Up, Stand Up").
bad girls ("Do Something," "There Will Be No #!*@ Tonight")
Grave to the grave ("Yer Bounda Fara," "Ledi Coumbe").
Pretty much what the title would lead you to figure, which is far from everything you'd hope ("Haallah," "Waya zarrabo 'Women Madness'")
Firmly avuncular old Malian dance-novelty star turned folkie--lessons in Bambara, love songs in French, time all wrong for blues ("Duna Ma Yelema," "Serrer la Main").

This indefatigable old-timer always has a gimmick, which high-generic world music can always use--here actual American bluespeople to shore up his Malian-blues cred, most noticeably on harmonica and most fruitfully on violin ("Je Chanterai Pour Toi," "Dounia Tabolo")
Mali's eternal round, described with the help of French blues harmonica ("Sogow," "Wolodennu," "Lala").

Watch out, lady--even sung more lissomely if not cannily than a well-respected Billie Holiday, humanitarian homilies requiring lyric-booklet translation will eventually put your respectful cadre to sleep. ("Nï¿½ï¿½" "Sï¿½ï¿½")

As impersonated by Fred Boak, "Cape Cod's Singing Valet," Travis is best on the smart women, attainable or not, male old-timers so often learn to appreciate too late ("Settle for Less," "All the Little Things")
give him decent material and let the poor guy be ("Small Y'All," "Gonna Walk That Line")
Decency is its own reward ("My Daddy Never Was," "That Was Us").
lay back and trust the band, gal--also your own lyrics ("Freedom," "Barnyard Poontang")
Obscure Italian chanteuse finds producer of dreams ("Moody," "Search and Destroy").

album: A Travis Tritt Christmas: Loving Time of the Year
comment: "`Free Bird'!" ("Silver Bells")
saying less with more ("I Wanna," "Crackin Up")
For once the campfire punkrocker nails the Billy Bragg album his excitable fans always said he had in him ("Glory Hallelujah," "I Am Disappeared")
songcraft as end-in-itself for as long as this contract shall remain in effect ("Not My Johnny," "Queen for a Day")
New Nashville's sexually liberated woman--proud, hot, and, especially, male-identified ("[If You're Not in It for Love] I'm Outta Here!" "Home Ain't Where His Heart Is [Anymore]")
I'll take the "green" mixes, and fuck you for asking ("I'm Gonna Getcha Good!," "Ka-Ching!")
they have garages in Finland--speak English sometimes too ("Don't Play Cello")
old-school beats, Egyptian mythology, looney tunes ("Daffy Wuz a Black Man")
Lovelorn rapper promises her everything and ack-acks her with hopes for humanity and shreds of common sense ("Unfashionable," "Lospital")
or anyway, greatest myths ("God Bless the Dead," "Keep ya Head Up")

artist: Shye Ben Tzur, Jonny Greenwood, and the Rajasthan Express
comment: Billing be damned, it's not Israeli composer Tzur or Radiohead busybody Greenwood whose horns, percussion, and vocals are the making of this double-CD--it's the 19 Indian musicians finally named on the back of the 32-page booklet ("Chala Vahi Des," "Modeh")
Nashvillians with a track record rarely lack for songs, but note that she wrote several of the liveliest ones herself ("The More Boys I Meet," "Last Name").
Not beautiful (or weird) enough for its own beats ("Celestial Annihilation," "Guns Blazing [Drums of Death Part 1]").
Rapper dresses Unabomber, name-checks Che ("Brooklyn," "Rome Too Burned").

If she's so smart, why isn't there one about Trump the racist dickwad to balance off the one about Obama the warmongering "coward"? (working theory: because that would be corny) ("Rage of Plastics," "Pearly Gates")
the sweetest nonvirgin a mama could ask ("Just Like Me," "You Make Me Wanna . . . ")
they got the beats ("Come On Everybody [Get Down]," "Sheep")
hit hooks that live off the guitarist's mysterioso lyricism, B sides that fall back on the singer's humanist egotism ("I Will Follow," "Pride [In the Name of Love]")
Why no-fail hookcraft is ideal for triangulating the not-enough--and also why it's not enough ("No Hope," "Change of Heart Pt. 2")
Demographically enticing indie-rocker emotes credible strum'n'drum but should fool around more with the electronics thing ("Mal ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï" "Minneapolis")
Madagascar supersession with Hanitra co-chairing--long on process, interactions their own reward ("Era," "Manigne").
As constructed if fetching an authentic Southern gal as ever you'll hear fills out her identity quest with pretty much the same love problems as everyone else's ("Love You Once Made," "Got Soul")

album: The Best of Van Halen, Vol. 1
comment: preening for the spotlight, they can be funny and spectacular--until Sammy Hagar horns in ("Jump," "Runnin' With the Devil")
the most steadfast of the folkies--and the funniest ("Another Time and Place," "Garden State Stomp")
He knows the tradition & also the difference between a traditionalist and a remaker ("The Pleasure's All Mine," "Wheel of Fortune")

album: The Real Deal: Greatest Hits, Vol. 2
artist: Stevie Ray Vaughan and Double Trouble
comment: shameless reshuffle though it is, it maintains a caught-in-the-act feel for a good hour ("Love Struck Baby," "Leave My Girl Alone [Live]")
Drum-driven guaracha created a sensation in early-'60s Colombia, signifies as minor accordion variant today ("Carruseles," "Mambo Loco")
PSA: booklet notwithstanding, deprogram 4-6 to avoid John Cale singing "All Tomorrow's Parties" and "The Gift" ("Some Kinda Love")
striving toward bar band to be born ("Straight," "Benjamin")

album: Esau Mwamawaya and Radioclit Are the Very Best
comment: Samples you love and others you don't know validated by a friendly African voice you don't understand ("Kamphopo," "Boyz").
They'd be better off not being Bloc Party if they didn't wish they were ("Rumbae," "We OK")
Lounge techno meets steel guitar, also bluegrass ("Swing Lite," "Hipalong Hop").

album: The Good, the Bad, the Ugly
comment: punk lifer's ordinary songs juiced by punk lifers' extraordinary guitars ("Busted," "Flower")
cynical, sex-seeking (alt) rockers who aren't getting laid enough ("The Richer My Dad Gets," "1/2 Hard")
"Stupid fucking job," the lyric goes ("SFJ," "Black Babies")
Noize-toon energy fights lo-fi breakdown to a draw ("Can't Get Over You," "I Have No Fun").
neotraditionalism across the pop guitar-band spectrum ("Two Seconds," "Don't I Wish")
Ever collegial and craving new blood, Jon L. and the gang take in a fortysomething alt-Nashville lifer ("Great Chicago Fire," "Someone That You Know")
at its best, why he needs the men's movement; at its worst, why you don't ("Talking New Bob Dylan," "Hitting You")
commentary not protest, and usually worse for it ("Tonya's Twirls," "Pretty Good Day")
62-year-old applies a lifetime of singing lessons and emotional travail to the coruscations of his youth ("Muse Blues," "Old Friend").
Repays hard listening at modest interest ("Oh What a World," "Natasha")
See: Effective but Defective.

The monologue disc needs track divisions and the songs aren't improved by his bellow-and-groan, but in concert Waits generates a groove even with his son manning the kit ("Get Behind the Mule," "Goin' Out West").
Loud is over if you want it ("Magic Trick," "Rollercoaster").
Black Flag goes electrofunk ("Right To Life")

album: My Favorite Time of the Year
comment: If new Christmas product you must have, these oldies definitely outshine newies from Darlene Love (eh) and Taylor Swift (ugh) ("Have Yourself a Merry Little Christmas," "Joy to the World").

Like Ben Folds--although he's punker than Ben Folds (as is Max Martin)--Nathan Williams proves that a talent for tunes does nothing for one's annoying personality ("Demon to Lean On," "Afraid of Heights")
Hold on to your feelings, but put down that thesaurus until you've got a firmer grip ("Breathless," "Summer of Love")

album: Trance Percussion Masters of South Sudan
comment: Drums beating high and fast, women singing high and fast--not "hypnotic," more like scintillating ("Woe Woe Wee Odo Gbere Ni Fanini [The Beautiful Girls Are Wonderful]," "Wa Ma Bire Re Kuragi Amsmar Ni Wiri Paranga Re [When You Next See Me, I Will Have Graduated]")
sounds from the dark side ("Diablos," "Gaya's Kids")
forget Elvis--the Steve Miller mention is the real giveaway, and breath of fresh air ("My First Lover," "Ruination Day Part 2");

The assiest moment in his half-assed attempt to make asshattery germane again is when he claims #MeToo for his foggy fat self, and if it's also the catchiest, fuck you if you can't take a joke--her too ("All Mine," "Yikes")
What gives this fool the right to ruminate all over your earhole is his trick cocktail piano ("Whatever Makes You Happy," "Final Hurrah").
So scabrous and sardonic it's cleansing ("Pimp the System," "Get Ignit")
Wiseass fratbags-too smart for college, too stoopid for their own good ("Wannabe Gangster," "Teenage Dirtbag").
wallowing in nostalgia as only a 25-year-old can--a 25-year-old with a voice sweeter than his soul and tunes coming out of his ass ("My Hometown," "Jacksonville Skyline," "Paper Moon");

"You know time has played a very important role in our relationship/It was time that first brought us together and/It's time that we separate and leave each other" ("Practice What You Preach," "Whatever We Had, We Had")

album: New Year's at the Village Vanguard
comment: if not Dixieland without corn, then Dixieland with spirit, smarts, chops, and a sense of the present ("Lord, Lord, Lord")
The present-day guitar god refuses to die ("Icky Thump," "Seven Nation Army").
Self-aware for white-rap fatalists, plus they play their own instruments ("Good Friday," "These Few Presidents").
purty music, but I yawn like a lawn when I hear him recite ("Jesus, Etc.," "I Am the Man Who Loves You")
The New Orleans Funk Repertory Orchestra ("Pocket Change," "Pock-a-Nae").

album: I'm Sorry, I Can't Rock You All Night Long
comment: scattered classics like the title tune, outtakes worth hearing ("I Wanna Watch You Age," "I'm Gonna Get Drunk With a Good Friend of Mine")
"Kid Rock don't come from where I come from"--and, oh yeah, "if you thought so goddamn you're fucking dumb" ("Pills I Took," "Thrown Out of the Bar").
Fine but increasingly long-winded bandleader splits the difference between po'-faced and lugubrious by mourning her father and salvaging a few outtakes. ("If My Love Could Kill," "Doors of Heaven")

album: The Inevitable Rise and Liberation of Niggy Tardust
comment: Slam poet Saul marches into battle with damned beatmaster Trent ("Tr(n)igger," "Convict Colony").
Born-again optimist's L.A. even has Mexicans in it ("Southern California," "Morning Beat").
respects her texts at long last ("Come On in My Kitchen," "Sankoma")
Catchy enough for the job, too perky for the lifestyle ("You Don't Have to Go Home," "If You Want a Mother").
Klezmer clarinet master salutes Russian-Romanian region far from Arabia ("Freylekh for Gwen Stefani," "Patriot Bulgars").

album: The Best of the Wipers and Greg Sage
comment: Gun Club Meets Suicide--Guitars Win ("Romeo," "Nothing Left To Lose")
It's only rock 'n' roll and they execute it ("I Should Not Have to Ask," "Panic Attack").
"I'm much too young to look this old" and other agonies ("All Dads Alike," "Brickface").
Reclaiming female feistiness, which is as close as Nashville gets to feminism ("I'll Think of a Reason Later," "The Man Who Made My Mama Cry").

album: Song Review: A Greatest Hits Collection
comment: if comp you must, Original Musiquarium is on CD, and the good rarities here you can somehow do without ("Hold On to Your Dream," "Redemption Song")
Has good enough values as long as he doesn't apply them too far from home ("I Love Her, She Hates Me," "Work and Worry").
Recorded at their home studio in the south of France, just like Exile on Main Street, only without a drummer, a producer, or an engineer ("Please Be Nice to Her," "Men in Sandals").
miscellaneous battle cries and war stories ("Never Again," "Cobra Clutch").
The live album Billy Zoom and their songbook have long deserved ("Johny Hit and Run Paulene," "Beyond & Back").
Dirty Texas rappers meet Eurodance beatmaker for mutual self-improvement ("Damaged Goods," "Dirty South").
Work up their share of Whitmanesque reach without sussing that yowling ain't yawping ("Doing It Right," "American Man")
precisely as good as her material, which gets stuffier all the time ("Walkaway Joe," "She's in Love With the Boy")
They try, and I'm rooting for them, but the real pan-Latino Black Eyed Peas would have more hooks ("Bilingual Girl," "Bla Bla Bla").
Not only does he no longer just [insert verb here] the pussy all the time--unlike DT, he knows when he's being recorded about it ("Fuck DT," "Blacks & Browns")

album: Merry Christmas From Yo La Tengo
comment: Three Xmas songs you don't know is miracle enow ("Santa Claus Goes Modern," "Rock N Roll Santa").
Remix, cover, instrumental, great Summer Sun reject, ordinary Summer Sun reject, judicious Summer Sun reject ("Styles of the Times," "Needle of Death").
Lovestyles of the rich-not-wealthy ("Debt," "Blueberry Breath").
baby he was born to lumber--and Pearl Jam wasn't ("Downtown")
His last song collection this dubious was, of all things, This Note's for You, which is where this one's chief selling point was long ago slated to appear ("Ordinary People," "The Way").
Four all-too-well-remembered classics, two collectibles, bonanza guitar ("Come on Baby Let's Go Downtown," "Cowgirl in the Sand").
Youngblood makes so many funny noises he can't convince me he's a "Neiman Marcus shopper"--which is a good thing ("#Twitter Song," "I Know")
Singsong porn from a purple people eater who's seldom as funny as he used to be and sometimes funnier than he wants to be ("Family Don't Matter," "Take Care")

album: Birdman Presents Rich Gang: The Tour
artist: Young Thug, Birdman, Rich Homie Quan
comment: New-gen big-tymers pledge thug love as they target that golden terlet in the charts ("730," "Milk Marie")
splitting the difference between sound effects and multilingualism ("De la Vie ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿" "Mr. Brown")
I've always wondered--does he put a vocoder on his bass too? ("More Bounce to the Ounce," "Midnight Hour--Live '93 (Remix)")
Middle East meets Far East for trance sans dance ("Hool Ki Seva," "Twice as Good as We Are").
title of the year ("Concrete and Steel," "Decision or Collision")

album: American Hardcore: The History of American Punk Rock 1980-1986
Austin Powers -- The Spy Who Shagged Me
Badenya: Manden Jaliya in New York City

Too young for '60s nostalgia, so old nobody can tell ("In the Dream Life U Need a Rubber Soul," "Factory Man").
Deadpan country-folk, nasty when you turn your back ("Nick Drake Tape," "Chinese Baby").
Impressionistic doomsongs that grow in beauty, as if to prove doom has an afterlife ("Pray," "With All My Heart").
The kind of record that makes you wonder whether he's feeling sad about selected American lives, or really just his own ("Walmart Parking Lot," "Denver").

The reason they're so mad is they just want to have fun ("Nestle in My Boobies," "Parking Lot").
The meat remains, the sauce does not ("Go Away," "Jaybird")

honking jump blues on the big-band side ("Cobb's Idea," "Big League Blues")

Go-Go's with heft by Norwegian gals in matching outfits ("Oh Boy," "Out of My Head").
He's so talented you can hear how much he wants it, so talented you wince every time he shoots himself in the foot, e.g. "Put some chains on my niggaz like I own slaves" ("World Is Empty," "Get By")

not the ideal place to get to know him ("Macho Woman," "City Living")
nor to continue your acquaintance--or is it the other way around? ("City Living," "Macho Woman")

Conscious rappers have afterparties too ("Gladiator," "Universal Mind Control [UMC]").
Gone back to Chitown, he "could give a fuck if it's real or a weave" ("Hustle Harder," "Nobody's Smiling")
Wish so much this all-star showcase was much more than a lecture--so much ("The Day Women Took Over," "Letter to the Free," "Pyramids")
hip hop of the everyday--a rare yet too ordinary thing ("I Used to Love H.E.R.," "Pop's Rap," "Resurrection")

album: Objects in Mirror Are Closer Than They Appear
comment: Detroit brings the noise, Chuck D- and John Sinclair-style ("U R Us," "Brake the Law").

Voice of reason ("C U When U Get There," "Homeboy").
"I haven't finished this song yet / Will you help me fix it?" ("Sappho," "Sinister")

collegiate revolutionary cliche equals gangsta revolutionary revelation ("Dig It!," "I Know You")

comment: The view from the desert as the sun sets on the American empire ("Yalla Yalla [Let's Go]," "Turn On, Tune In, Drop Out With Me").
soulful things to say, tuneful ways to say them, way too long getting there ("Ode to My Family," "Zombie")
lucky for her music she's been unlucky in love ("You and Me," "Loud and Clear")
eerie, stately, cosmic, minor, cute, beautiful, full of shit ("Everywhere," "Clear")
few if any soul men play better, not many write better, plenty arrange better, almost all sing better--a formula for the blues ("These Things," "My Problem")
Jolly garage punks prove how heedless they are by adding xylophone ("Saturday Night Live," "Beach Bug")
Worked-over meditations on the persistence of romance ("Will We Ever?," "Where Homes Used to Be").
"punk" "supergroup"--Jon Spencer Blues Explosion, Babes in Toyland, Babe's hubby's band--exposes its funk-metal soft spot ("Swine," "Punishment")
Indie-rock notes from a sweet, intense, failed romance, or maybe a few of them--not her last, anyway, and just maybe these songs will help her achieve that consummation ("Dean's Room," "Expatriate")
Impertinent electro-squelchers prove crystal castles are forever like sand castles are for never and byte castles are in between ("Crimewave [Crystal Castles vs. Health]," "Alice Practice").
Guitar rageboy marries too young, gets concept album out of it ("The Game of Who Needs Who the Worst," "The Night I Lost the Will to Fight").
Woo-ooh I love you ("Out There on the Ice," "Hearts on Fire").
One step up the evolutionary ladder from indie-rock eats itself--you can hear it sprouting tunes, grooves, feelings ("Living North," ".ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½").
Sound kind of Giant Sand, think more Hold Steady ("Hey Moe--You Kicked Ass," "Apt. K").
Just how did it happen, do you think, that the inventors of rap-rock got lost in the shuffle? ("[Rock] Superstar," "We Live This S***").
Teen overkill by a teen with the get-up-and-go to survive it--and get off a few shots back ("7 Things," "Breakout").
1971--the juju patriarch still undefined ("Okin Omo Ni," "Labondo")
they don't like what they see and they know how to sound that way ("Teenage Loser Anthem," "Drive-By Kiss")
Dandies have feelings too--no, strike that, tunes too ("Shakin'," Godless").
Groove-launching space oddity light years from home ("Welcome to the Third World," "Mission Control").
From a band so immersed in the immersive, Tennesse Ernie Ford and offers to rest your head qualify as welcome moments of clarity ("Slide," "Alternative Power to the People")
It's tricky to rock a rhyme, to rock a rhyme that's right on time--it's tricky, tricky, tricky, tricky ("99 Problems," "Change Clothes").

album: Wanna Buy a Monkey?: A Mixtape Session
comment: best of Lovage, best of Bobby Digital (Lovage, "Stroker Ace"; Bobby Digital, "The Rhumba")

blues his heritage, his politics, his craft ("Best I Can," "If You Love Somebody")

can the flute and add track listings ("Zimbabwe")

Inclusive music trumps militant ideology ("Last Days Reloaded," "Window to My Soul")

How much you need the latest Jack White move depends on how much you've been missing Queens of the Stone Age, which for me was more than I'd thought but, get real, not much. ("Open Up," "Three Dollar Hat")

Enough to make me wonder whether hip-hop's rawest sonic warriors are getting more death metal, but not enough to a-b the albums and find out ("Giving Bad People Good Ideas," "Eh")
Marvin Gaye gets out of jail ("Love Still Good," "Love Jones")

Won't upset your stomach as it heals your soul ("Nar-1 Ask," "Guilname").
Searching for truth among the believers ("These Old Shoes," "Not So Dense").

sharp narrative eye, cocky nerd attitude, too smart for folk and his own good ("Coldwater Park," "Sexy/Scary")

Continues to project a hedonistic lassitude and desperate edge you wish you could warn your buddy off ("American," "Body Electric")
three women clashing and meshing, meshing and clashing ("Punkrock-icity," "Love Song")
Her heart cherishes Jesus' memory, but her mind, voice, and soul remain her own ("He Reached Down," "I've Got That Old Time Religion in My Heart").
Less Cambodian and more indie rock, a good thing for everybody concerned except Asian pop fanciers ("Sober Driver," "Mr. Orange").

smiling bravely through their tribulations ("Independent Women Part I," "Happy Face")
rule marginalia ("Be Stiff," "[I Can't Get No] Satisfaction," "Mongoloid," "Penetrationin the Centrefold")

the kind of genre move you miss when the well runs dry ("Radi," "Reconnaissance")
all your Afropop faves, with extra added attractions ("Soul Makossa," "Diarabi")

comment: Three years before he'd die at 67 in 2009, the Memphis producer-paterfamilias has lost his voice, as the 1983 coda proves, while retaining the entirety of his brain, spirit, and attitude ("Redneck, Blue Collar," "Lazarus")
Small voice, loud drummer, big dream: "I want to be the best one at this/But I don't want to get out of bed" ("Maid of the Mist," "Blob Zombie")

They've reformed for a three-decades-late tour I hope I catch, but there were better mbalax bands and this is volume two for a reason ("Am Sa Waye," "Nianky")
cherry-picking the skillfully turned-out nakedness of (her first) two self-released tapes/CDs ("Lost Woman Song," "Both Hands," "Anticipate")
or is that puddle diva? ("Names and Dates and Times," "Pick Yer Nose")
Two well-armed To the Teeth remixes, two (out of three) well-designed covers ("Hurricane," "Do Re Mi").
Learned a skill while doing 28 goddamn years for a murder he didn't commit ("Black Robes and Lawyers," "Chasing a Dream")
somehow his axe and his voice sing the same tune, momentarily transmuting his self-pity into simple sadness ("Out There," "Start Choppin")
Greatest practitioners on record of America's premier you-had-to-be-there music ("Dirty Old Man," "We Gon' Roll)
pinched punk for girls ("Girls Can Play," "Fishnet")
desperately seeking Hitsville ("Hey Little Boy," "Don't You Go Walking")

he was DB before we knew drum 'n' bass's name, and he still believes in, try to remember, "audio and sensory awakening" (Hatiras, "Spaced Invader--High Contrast Remix--J Malik Remix--Optical Remix"; Nasty Habits, "Shadow Boxing [Remix]")
Club carnaval of the mind ("De Dar Dï¿½" "Azougue").
Songs not mixes based on beats not tunes (except for the best 1) ("Proletariado," "The Mind Inspector").

artist: DJ Jazzy Jeff and the Fresh Prince
comment: The antigangsta, as only a master of light comedy could render him ("Summertime," "Lovely Daze").

comment: RZA-inspired beats, CSI-inspired rhymes ("Destruction of a Guard," "Exploitation of Mistakes").

Global-warming riddimscape inna praise-Jah style (DJ /Rupture & Matt Shadetek, "Underwater High Rise"; DJ /Rupture & Matt Shadetek, "4th Story Waterline").
basslines with a sense of humor ("Your Revolution," "Viagra")
the international brotherhood of groovus interruptus (TTC, "L'art d'Ecouter"; Slug, "Edie Brikell")

Old soul tragically widowed, triumphantly remarried, and madder than ever ("In Time of War Who Wins," "They Crowned an Idiot King").

The curse of Tanya Morgan--great real-love concept and skits surrounding songs you feel no physical compulsion to hear again ("Girl, Girl," "I See You").
Scoff all you like at the very notion of a live rap album, but just remember--no skits ("Name Dropping," "I Hear Voices").

More believable when he's dark and textural, more likable when he's soft and melodic ("Cha Cha," "$")

Notes for a musical about a doubly theatrical drama queen--an arty show with laughs and heart ("Night Reconnaissance," "Dear Jenny").

"Ain't no party like an art rap party 'cause an art rap party's so smart" ("Helicopter," "Mole in Your Ministry," "WTF Is Art Rap?")
Beatwise enough to prop up his unpretentious absurdity-trumps-sarcasm, but not to put it across ("Informations," "Dark Comedy Morning Show")

Boss of the Blues, a/k/a Single Again ("Baby's Just as Mean as Me," "Ain't Nobody's Daddy Now")

Road songs for insomniacs just driving around ("Down 42nd Street to the Light," "Cybercar").

not country, not rock and roll--rock ("Me and Billy the Kid")

the queen of morna, which is like fado only--no thanks to the Portugese, I'm sure--more African ("Flor na Paul," "Tudo dia de dia")

album: The Very Best of Cesaria Evora
comment: if it was, no one would know, but juicier than average ("Sodade [Remix]," "Sangue de Berona")

bang bang bang ("Going Out of My Head," "Santa Cruz")

notes on the abiding pleasures and disappointments of small-town life ("Promise of a Kiss," "No Vacancy")
your typical leftist country dub ("She Moved Away," "Mary, Her Husband, and Tommy Too")
at 76, finally an official pro, with Jim Keltner the proof ("Boquiï¿½ï¿½ï" "Buenos Hermanos")

album: Buena Vista Social Club Presents Ibrahim Ferrer
comment: At 72, he has the right to take it easy--and luckily, also the ability ("Marieta," "Bruta Maniguï¿½ï").

album: Food and Liquor II: The Great American Rap Album Pt. 1
comment: Veteran wannabe avers amid thousands of words that if he were a Buddhist he'd be reborn as himself ("Bitch Bad," "Hood Now [Outro]")

Light it is, miscellaneous too, but only dumbbells make light of his skills, and few rappers you think you like more have managed anything as tragic or comic, respectively, as its two undeniables ("NGL," "Jump")
Most Intriguing Use of Roots Riffs in an Eclectic Context Nobody Comprehends (Including Them) ("Worry Worry," "Up in the North")

the great black pop of middle-class dreams ("Cottage for Sale," "Let's Stay Together")
living in the moment gets old ("Going Away," "Now It's Now Again")

album: Throw Down Your Heart: Unreleased Tracks: Africa Sessions Part 2
comment: Outtakes worth preserving, but the great lost keepers do dry up as the banjo takes over ("Chant," "Spirit Song").
That double-edged Kiwi wit--bad things are funnier at a distance, but then again, bad jokes are lamer at a distance ("Foux du Fafa," "Business Time").

dirty old rock and roll gal ("Where the Action Is," "Stupid Girl")

"We used to wanna sing like Joan Baez/Jesus, what were we smoking?" ("Russian Limbaugh," "Peace Is Out")
country-rock was never this gangly--singer-songwriter either ("The Circle," "Drop")
songs too good for the help, subcontracted to none other than Edwyn Collins ("Cryin' Love," "I Can Do")
around the way preppie ("Poly Sci," "All You Gotta Do")

The rare undie-rapper who's learned from his opportunities ("Underground for Dummies," "Got Up This Morning").

Nicely unexistential murder ballads, including several garden-horror lynchings, a Reconstruction MD mob-killed for healing all races, and righteous Mexican revenge ("Jesse Washington, 1916," "Joaquin Murietta, 1853").
neodisco whose smartest message, as usual with this guy, is its music ("Rock the Nation," "Thank You")
"From Mexico to China/All I want is vagina" ("Not Tonight," "We Fresh").

The truth is, his Auto-Tuned flow has more future in it than his intermittently interplanetary rhymes ("Turn on the Light," "Permanent Scar")
