Better half of a pretty decent album, in order of appearance: "My Collection," "Coming Out Strong," "Testify," "Fresh Air," "Neva Missa Lost," "Turn on Me," "Sorry" ("Turn on Me," "Coming Out Strong")
The grown-up, brainy tomboy of country's least sexist dreams ("L Is 4 L-O-S-E-R," "Braggart").

album: Never Slow Down, Never Grow Old
comment: Right, the Boston sportswriter, who enlists Theo Epstein on a Clash cover and seven actual Red Sox on "Wake Me, Shake Me" ("NyQuil Blues," "Model Citizen").
Soundscape dance-rock more artful than arty ("Vacuum," "First Communion").
Inspirational Verse: "What you think about screwin'? It don't have to last very long" ("The Thought of You," "She Never Liked Elvis")

"alternate Detroit mix" useless, concert version hornier and less strung up ("Head Title," "Sixties Medley: That's the Way Love Is/You/I Heard It Through the Grapevine/Little Darling [I Need You]/You're All I Need to Get By/Ain't Nothing Like the Real Thing/Your Precious Love/Pride and Joy/Stubborn Kind of Fellow")
gangsta as mystery, religious and literary ("Shadowboxin'," "Killah Hills 10304")
sonics lean, drama thin ("My Secret Reason," "Cancer of Everything," "Stars")
With nothing much at stake but the shape of his life, Howe Gelb keeps his slow hand in ("Fields of Green," "Better Man Than Me")
Not the standards album he has in him ("Mack the Knife," "Ripple").
Thump, bump, hump ("Final Warning," "No. 1 Fan").
The loneliness of the dirty-minded teengirl ("Blah Blah Blah," "Slutmouth")
Picking their way through a world that ain't all that big no matter how scary ("Before the World Was Big," "Ideal World")
Phil Spector overstated his feelings too, and look where it got him ("Honey Bunny," "Magic")

album: You Can't Fight What You Can't See
comment: psyche-pathic brrrs, by which I mean still cold bastards ("Basstation," "Let It Breathe")
Living-room alt-country blues from Brooklyn, I guess--with Dixieland horn section? ("Cheap Two-Faced Star," "Family Tree").
U.K. hip-hop beatmaster constructs oft engaging sonic collage in which beats oft shatter flow ("Docbond," "Raindrips")
a goof not a concept, except insofar as they deny there's a difference ("Re-Hash," "Clint Eastwood")
"Honey ain't no woman like a Southern girl," declares Arkansan female now residing in Northwest bohemia ("Swing Low," "Southern Comfort")
Astor Piazzolla goes ambient ethnotechno inna musette style ("Queremos Paz," "Triptico")
The Indianapolis version of Barcelona's El Guincho is longer on madness and shorter on joy--must be the water ("Let's Go Mad Together," "You Will Love My Boom").
Accomplished sound with not much new to say meets 12 minutes to say it in ("MGM Grand," "Hand Crank Transmitter").
turning the nightmare up a notch to find out whether the world has gone completely bonkers ("Graveyard Chamber," "6 Feet Deep")
their horror movie turned real-life doomshow, and when they hit a vein they sound it ("False Things Must Perish," "Burn Baby Burn")
If only Esther Phillips had written her own songs, she would have sung worse ones ("I've Committed Murder," "Caligula").
Not great--OK ("I Can Make Music," "I Wanna Hold You").
beats masturbating ("One for the Razorbacks," "2000 Light Years Away")
punks can age gracefully, but for whiners it's hard ("The Grouch," "Walking Alone")
Southern-fried hipsters uproot some pavement ("Parting Shot," "Boho/Alt")
Two bluegrass masters tend their roots in Hasidic melodies old and new, sprightly and melancholy, devout and not so ("Anim Zemiros," "New Shabbos Waltz").
Two startlingly chaotic burners, two declarations of noisy spiritual devotion, and 20 minutes of sun-dazed head music wavering woozily over the bright desert sand ("Beatte Harab," "Ragsa Jaguar").

album: Muleskinner Blues: The Asch Recordings Vol. 2
comment: Knew a good tune when he stole it, no great shakes at singing them ("Muleskinner Blues," "Rubber Dolly").

At 79, last Chicago blues master standing nabs cameos, nails songs by his Berklee-trained drummer, survives the Muscle Shoals Horns, and claims his birthright yet again ("Come Back Muddy," "Kiss Me Quick")
"Record execs wanna push the album way back?/And hold back my advance? They didn't pay that" ("Rough Cut," "Knock, Knock")
who wrote his country soul was Lefty, not Hank--as if we didn't know ("Always Late [With Your Kisses]," "If You've Got the Money [I've Got the Time]")
Rebel, patriot, musician, legend, populist, sentimentalist, small businessman ("That's the News," "Lonesome Day").
Three sisters unite to negotiate reassuringly generic man trouble--even the madrigal hooks have a suprapersonal anonymity to them ("The Wire," "Falling")
a folk-rock tour de force that goes "Life is all right for the time being/Life is all right for the time being"--for 38 minutes
Fun mbira-guitar history lesson, with Thomas Mapfumo only a bit player ("Mudzimu Ndiringe," "Tamba Zimba Navashe").
Say this for near-death experiences--they tune up the sensitivities ("Don't Kill," "Downs").

Follow up with either no singers at all and more Wayne Shorter (plus Roy Hargrove maybe?), or all Joni all the time doing as many early classics as will bear the harmonic burden ("Tea Leaf Prophecy," "River").
Low lonesome honky-tonker uses the term "work of art" in two straight songs and declares undying love for his parakeet ("Don't Want Me Too," "The Parakeet").
Not that Brett doesn't adore Rennie as they honor 20 years of marriage, just that he has trouble telling the world about it ("Wild Wood," "Darling, My Darling").
innocent, sure--also as layered as a $100 haircut and as mannered as a Stanislavski class ("Weird," "Man From Milwaukee")
their Voidoids is hotter than their "dance music" ("Grandbag's Funeral," "Kinky Afro")

Seven protest songs from their studio album take on heft and emotional focus as boogieing Allmans-style jams that also stretch them too far past the limitations of all involved ("Blackland Farmer," "I Don't Have a Gun")
Hard-headed songs about hard work are hard to find ("Stomp and Holler," "Blackland Farmer")
the best thing he can do for his roots is grow new songs from them ("Honeysuckle," "Basehead," "Teabag Blues")
Has more blues in him than Ali Farka Toure and Sylford Walker combined ("The Bush Is Burning," "Mama Wata").
grand old newfangled one-woman hootenanny ("Hard Times," "Guitar Town")
First acoustic bluesman to cover the Cornelius Brothers and Black Oak Arkansas, but probably not the first garage rocker ("Fightin' Hard," "Manos Arriba").
A genius's depressions can be as dull as anybody else's, especially if she thinks passion precludes laughs ("It's You," "The Pocket Knife")
Senegalese drummers add jam and Muhammad to klezmer jazz ("Waaw Waaw," "Yemin Heshim")

album: Last Night the Moon Came Dropping Its Clothes in the Street
comment: Being the moon and only wearing a few veils anyway, it did this very, very quietly ("Abu Gil," "Courtrais").
at least as smart as an old-time riot grrrl, at least as rocking as an old-time Blake Baby ("Houseboy," "Let's Get Married")
Musically clean-cut Phoenix "punkgrass" fixtures lay out the jolly economics of private prisons and swear their favorite cocktail is the Molotov ("High Demand," "Let's Start a Riot")
Miles in the sky of drum'n'bass ("Telluride," "Tristan in the Sky").
shambolic sweethearts ("C Is the Heavenly Option," "Tool")

album: The Decline and Fall of Heavenly
comment: nice quiet girl asserts herself--quietly, but you can hear her talking ("Me and My Madness," "Three Star Compartment")
They wanted that grungy punk finish, because that's who they are, but they didn't want to sound like kids, because that's what they aren't ("On the Breaks," "Revolution").
With New York drummer Reid in the driver's seat, "folktronica" turns frantic, dark, urban ("Lyman Place," "1st & 1st").
Really Sahara funk, inauthentic as hell yet true to its school ("When the Sun Breaks Through," "Sahara Swing").
Creaky old coot gets him a band, rendering new old favorites funkier than a preacher's skivvies ("Tennessee Jed," "Kingfish").
speeding, crunching, giving as bad as they get ("Unsung," "Give It")
A superior barrel scrape, with Hendrix's comping behind Lonnie Youngblood worthy of the permanent collection ("Let Me Move You," "Somewhere")
"characters who sing like William Burroughs while thinking they sound like Bobby Womack (is there anything sadder?)" ("Want Too Much," "Great Lake")
Beatier than Culture Club, but less winning, the usual price of transforming pop into art ("Raise Me Up," "Blind").
Pop boys are always facing manhood, but that doesn't always spruce up their songs ("Your Son Is Not a Soldier," "Fuck This Year")
Decades past his last outright keeper and 60 this year, he continues to roll out listenable collections like he'll never stop ("Don't Wanna Leave You Now," "Damn This Town," "Detroit Town")

Encroaching decrepitude suits him so well vocally that he eggs one of the funniest songs ever written about old age into taking the piss out of a gaggle of musicians who can't grow up ("Old People," "Terms of My Surrender")
Lapsed Cracker after "before the great decline" ("Friends," "Beauregarde's Retreat").
the old old-timey shtick sits better on an actual old-timer ("Up! Up! Up!" "Who Are You?")
East Bay Afrocentricity, hold the pikls ("At the Helm," "All Things")
Real-life fictions from a rapper with screenwriter dreams ("Patty Farmington," "Small Victories").

Vancouver melodist quotes Rilke, references Isherwood, reprises Gilbert & Sullivan, covers Bowie, covers Eno, insists M.F. stands for megafauna, and steals her best lines from her young son ("Burst," "Lover/Hater")
A great-grandmother's blues, uncannily John Hurt in the picking and domesticity ("Snap Your Fingers," "Whatcha Gonna Do When Your Good Girl Turns You Down?").

"Don't want your stars n bars and your blood on my damn hands / I'm lookin' away now Dixie cause I've seen all I can stand / But I'm still a Southern man" ("Nikki's a Republican Now," "Thoughts and Prayers")
New Yorker poetry, downhome quaver, uptown chords ("Hand Me Down All Stories," "Deliver Me," "The American Rhine")
Living off the low life too long ("Wait a While," "Almost Everything")
Better punk than actress, better actress than popster ("Celebrity Skin," "Awful").
Sketches and disses living-room style, with a sweet kissoff for Chan Marshall ("Uncle Disney," "Old Timers Disease")
Five years later, the same techno and classical strategies and sonorities less cunningly, therapeutically, and for that matter singularly deployed ("Emerald Rush," "Everything Connected")
Electrobeats smarter, love songs not ("Bendable Posable," "Don't Dance").
Possibly the world's most thoughtful and loving dance band--virtues that, tragically as usual, often aren't as exciting as one might hope ("How Do You Do," "Don't Deny Your Heart")

album: Every 1's a Winner: The Very Best of Hot Chocolate
comment: high-schlock hyperaestheticism, low-concept programming ("You Sexy Thing," "Brother Louie")
The Gypsy spirit recollected coolly and modestly, with photos of 120 wooded road scenes for Nordic spice ("My Heart Belongs to Daddy," "Karius & Baktus").
Pop satire, its targets obvious but left wriggling in a discomfort they deserve ("Jingle Jangle," "Soldier in a Box").
the rationalizations of a million pretentious losers--not including you or me, of course ("I Am Afraid," "You're Too Young")

album: All Songs Written by: Human Television
comment: Part of the discipline for tune adepts is to let the tunes carry meaning themselves, which is rarely how it worked with the bands they love ("Saw You Walking By," "Yeah Right").
Londoner juices African rhythms with electro arrangements while dissing Boko Haram in her Nigerian-born parents' native Ibibio ("Give Me a Reason," "The Pot Is on Fire")
remixed two-song Predator best-of plus nigga-devil-bitch plaint ("It Was a Good Day," "Check Yo Self")

His first album worth noticing in longer than one need determine proves that even facing death with his best buds he'll rely on the shtick that has served him so profitably for so long ("Job," "Dirty Deal")
slightly sparer, slightly rougher fan/band faves ("The Beginning," "You're One")
"Too many songs we sang are left unsung"--that about sums it up ("Last to Know," "Out From Inside")
rap-rock rides dancehall bass, further befuddling sludgehead market ("Death Threat," "Revolution")
Foot soldiers' tales ("Movas & Shakers," "Elevation").
This guy's got talent--some band with their shit together should show him the ropes ("Codeine," "Stopping By")
Cowpunk meets cyberpunk in Americana's dark past and damaged future ("Ever Since the Grid Went Down," "Carbon Dated Love").
"If I suck your dick it'll come fast/'Cause I'ma stick my thumb in your ass" ("The Watcher Remix," "Nookie Remix").

album: HIStory: Past, Present and Future Book 1
comment: if stardom is your only subject, you might as well take it to the limit ("Smile," "Tabloid Junkie")
metalhead solo room, metalhead showoff space ("Gate to Heaven," "What's Not Said")
Jack White hits the geriatric Christian hottie with songs and horns that remind us what a weirdo she must be ("Thunder on the Mountain," "Shakin' All Over")
Seattle beatmaker respects backpackers and gatpackers at the same time (Blueprint, "Scared"; Freeway & Brother Ali, "The Truth").
Sudanese child soldier turned Christian rapper meets Sudanese Muslim elder for great story and above-par music ("Alwa," "Gua").
Torching cocktail cool ("My Old Flame," "I Only Have Eyes for You").

Before capping his exploits with the best hookup song ever written, Missouri pro claims farmer, redneck, dad, and bartender as he reaches out to the entire country-radio demographic ("Drunk Girl," "I'm Your Farmer")

album: Salegy! Hot Dance Music from Madagascar
comment: 6/8 dance beats from Madagascar, by guys with their own drum set ("Samy Mandeha Samy Mitady," "Mampanino Anao")
Getting their shtick together on three EPs, 2006-2008 ("To Hell With Good Intentions," "Darkness on the Edge of Gastown")
arrogant yet diffident, ruthless yet cute--a scary original ("[Always Be My] Sunshine," "Real Niggaz")

artist: The Jazz Passengers Featuring Deborah Harry
comment: Who says a rock chick can't sing jazz music? ("Fathouse," "Dog in Sand").
Frankie Valli versus thugs, Tom Jones versus deadbeat dads, Bob Dylan versus war--somehow I don't think it'll work ("Masquerade," "PJ's")

album: From the Hut, to the Projects to the Mansion
comment: As ex-stars' moralizing post/anti-gangsta rhymes go, medium hard and sufficiently scientific ("Slumdog Millionaire," "Walk Away").
A racially complex life recalled by someone who's extracted multivalent music from that life for well past four decades ("14 Steps to Harlem," "Colored Boy Said")
The juice and talent to make their retro happen without the brains or vision to run with it ("Rollover D.J.," "Look What You've Done").
hasn't lost a step, hasn't gained one either ("Spinster," "You Got a Problem")
roll over Ogden Nash and tell Jimmy Castor the news ("Rapper Rapper," "Minute Man Man")
Frantic even when conciliatory, sweet-voiced young things half-articulate their fury by recognizing no boundary between punk and twee ("I Don't Want to Relax," "Separate Bedrooms")
new producer, so it can't be good outtakes from a great album--can it? ("For a Lost Key")
Too obvious too often ("Wild Irish Rose," "Golden Ring").
The Possum, Billy Sherrill, and a great American songbook plus ringers ("The Old Rugged Cross," "In the Garden")

artist: Janis Joplin with Big Brother and the Holding Company
comment: the history enjoyable, the jams educational, and listen for this Inspirational Interjection: "When I say no that's exactly what I mean" ("Easy Rider," "Down on Me")
credit to her family, credit to her sex ("Girls With Guitars," "Tell Me Why")
As dance music, not my idea of a good time, but as electronic pop, so much trickier, sillier and more kinetic than Kraftwerk ("Newjack," "D.A.N.C.E").
46-year-old NYC firefighter--a "job," not a "calling," he stresses--crystallizes Brownsville gangsta knowledge into finely worked rhymes gruffly and grittily served ("Finer Things/Tamahagee," "Just")

belated one-shot occasions belated mid-'80s comp as belated minor Sly & Robbie album ("Here Comes the Hotstepper," "Rough")
Montreuil HI-NRG to the mellow--generically, but he invented the genre
She'kspere's sista ("Hey Kandi," "What I'm Gon' Do to You").
Dakar-born neotraditionalist links to Morocco for the discriminating world muso ("Talibe," "Niane").
Praising iPods and decrying consumerism, 2010 effort demonstrates why grime has always deserved more respect from American hip-hop fans and why it never quite sparks their interest ("MAAD," "Slaves")

Congo legends lend status to white remixers, who never wreck the Africans' cultural identity and even texture it sometimes (Deerhoof vs Kasai Allstars, "Travel Broadens the Mind"; Mark Ernestus vs Konono No 1, "Masikulu Dub"; Eye vs Konono No 1, "Konono Wa Wa Wa"; Skeletons vs Sobanza Mimanisa, "Kiwembo/Unstuck")
Inconveniently, it's true--12 songs over 102 minutes do get samey ("Beware the Fetish," "The Chief's Enthronement/Oyaya")
Malian world-beat with a pan-Afropop flavor-not-flava ("Africa," "Dakan-Fe")
Megaskills for megasale ("Half on a Baby," "Did You Ever Think").
Jay all unrepentant swagger, R. his wheedling yes-man ("The Best of Both Worlds," "P***y")
Heartfelt, lively, and sweet--as r&b maturity statements go ("Girl on Fire," "One Thing")
panpop move ("Lillah," "Detni Essekra")
these daftly annotated old odds and sods could so easily be Les Meilleurs, and ain't ("Ya El Mima," "Ana Bia Taxi")
Meaning Jam & Lewis this, a decent interval after London Symphony Orchestra this and Prince this ("Disrespectful," "Foolish Fool").
Long-grinding Seattle MC thinks hip-hop is just beginning and has the grand beats and cheap nachos to prove it ("Pony Boy," "Blaq Han Solo").

Sometimes this Thai electric lute ensemble leads parades, other times it provides atmosphere, a mode favored on this follow-up, and while I'm complaining let me ask why it skips their Cranberries cover ("Thang Yai Thang Yao," "Phom Rak Mueang Thai")

album: Man on the Moon: The End of the Day
comment: Less fraught than most tunefully sensitive types, which a residue of hip-hop can do for you ("Day N Nite," "Soundtrack of My Life").
Ice-T as low rider ("These Stories Have To Be Told," "I Got Pulled Over")
Conscious-going-on-political gangsta's laments and celebrations are more tough-minded than his threats, boasts, and analyses ("Willie Burke Sherwood," "Anywhere but Here," "R.A.P. Music")
blue talk and bluer sounds for the young at heart ("Black Rooster [Fuck and Fight]," "Cat Claw")
Rolling out licks, turns of phrase, satire, and persuasion, country cat tries to create a country he can be proud of ("I Lie," "Act Like Nothing's Wrong").
Catchier riffage than last time, and that's all they'll ever write ("Closer," "Be Somebody").
Philosophical-psychological explorations in her own soft, crystal-clear, personal synth-pop lingo. ("Hello, Lakisha," "Obsessing," "Existential Crisis Hour!")
Raincoats' drummer's kids form purist rockabilly-etc. trio, get solid gone ("Going Up the Country," "Polly Put the Kettle On").
Only a band this seminal and lovable could support such a musically redundant live retrospective, although the six-song DVD is fun ("Lust," "Geierwally").
Like the Lord God Jahweh, gospel-klezmer collaboration can be awesome or awful ("Elijah Rock," "Didn't It Rain").
not fascist, just German--and also, not fascist, just industrial ("A Drug Against War," "More and Faster")

Too much to prove, and neither Nelly Furtado nor Nas can help ("Nothing to Lose," "Coming to America")
It's a lot easier to write the wild side than to live it, but not a lot smarter ("The Jealous Kind," "Carla Came Home").
A much tastier Michael McDonald than Duncan Sheik (or Michael McDonald) ("Give It to You," "A Different Party," "I Could Never Take the Place of Your Man").
Pan-West Indian Toronto calypsonian thinks always, reproves often, wines never ("Kaiso Newscast," "Joe the Paranoiac")
Your chance to eavesdrop on a genuine African ritual! ("Lufuala Ndonga," "Mama Liza").
Stoned afternoon in a Berlin hotel room hooked on the samples "Dayum, son, where'd you find this?" and "Maybach music" ("C.R.E.A.M.," "Uoeno")
hard again ("Streets of New York," "Erase Racism")
You know, space--where he rules the world ("Fine Girls," "Intro").
"Tell your a&r and his wife to get out of my fucking life" ("I Don't Believe You," "Extravagant Traveler").
Youssou N'Dour's xalam/ngoni man expresses himself, with the blues nod catchy but hardly the biggest prize ("Andra's Song," "Bassekou").
At ease with himself and in synch with his people ("Jamana Be Diya," "Falani")
Female pride, Malian and Islamic style ("Doninkï¿½" "Douwawou").
Projecting quite a lot of voix and not all that much rï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½volution, Guinean paladin"Fouba," "Namatimbaye")
Klezmer clarinetist gets all jazzy over kosher hip-hop beats (and a couple of raps) ("Bubbemeises," "Moskovitz and Loops of It").
visionary guitar, '60s-style, plus low-life lyrics by Mick Farren, who should know ("Dangerous Madness," "A Dead Man's Vest")
so it's never too late for an MC5 tribute ("Future/Now")
don't think Hendrix-Beatles, think Prince-George Michael ("Fields of Joy," "Stand by My Woman," "Stop Draggin' Around")
Netwise trope-tweaking at its best worst ("Blas? Blas?," "Go Hard [La.La.La]")
producer's pawns, voices changing, they hang in there ("Da Bomb," "Alright")
ragged and unbowed

album: A Long Way to the Beginning
comment: The old grooves are still good grooves, and if only the old imprecations were out-of-date ("IMF," "Kalikuta Boy")
Heir apparent with less to prove and nothing new to prove it with--except, uh-oh, new musicians ("African Soldier," "Mr. Big Thief")

More woke than you, more skilled than you, and doing OK in the paper department too, he proves all these things yet again without getting his music around the crisis he knows his people and his country face ("She's My Hero," "Knockturnal")
"Anybody can tell you how it is/What we puttin' down right here, this is how it is, and how it could be" ("Eternalists," "For Women").
are made of (Euro) disco (as if there's another kind anymore) ("Be My Lover," "Le Click: Tonight Is the Night," "Sweet Dreams")

London-based Moroccan's main ax is the three-stringed gimbri of Jajouka fame, but it's the percussion he overdubs that will move you and the occasional extra voice that will come in handy ("Solami," "Dounia")
Greenville, South Carolina, rebel learns what she means by country music in LA, NYC, and at long last Nashville ("Walk of Shame," "Gone, Gone, Gone")
Loves sex and is joined at the hip to her man, which unfortunately for her aren't the same thing ("Right Time," "Man Up")
By my count, seven varieties of musical "authenticity" in 11 cover takeovers ("Together Again," "I'll Take Care of You").

artist: Jonboy Langford and the Pine Valley Cosmonauts
comment: "explore the dark and lonely world of Johnny Cash" with more cojones than Rick Rubin ("Cocaine Blues," "What Is Truth?")
knows where to start when the beats commence ("Born to Ball," "The Man")

Free jazz made up on the spot, and although their guitarist died in 1994 and their drummer in 2013, I bet they have more brutalist live stuff in the can ("So Small, So Weak, This Bloody Sweat of Loving," "No One Knows Anything")
corny-fresh conga-funk like they still mean it ("Reasoning," "See")
endorsing Alice Walker and Ray-O-Vacs ("Lady Don't Tek No," "The Bumpin Contraption [The Recalibration]")

And I thought recording with the Drive-By Truckers meant Patterson Hood would write her some songs--and rein her in a little, maybe ("I Still Want to Be Your Baby [Take Me Like I Am]," "The Last Time").
I never cared whether she was really a punk (as if)--I just wished she'd act like one ("The Best Damn Thing," "Everything Back but You").
meaningful when funny, wry when serious, lugubrious when artistic ("Blind Dating Fun," "Until Now")

album: I Was in Love With a Difficult Man
comment: confessions of a marginal literary professional ("Trade Up," "Sunday Breakfast With Christine [and Ervin]," "Making Friends With My Gray Hair")

album: Sometimes Mother Really Does Know Best
comment: Half funny folksongs, half the standup beast itself ("Planet X," "The Legal Ramifications of a Crackerjack Vendor Who Works in Yankee Stadium")
One song so irresistible it makes you think the other tracks are songs too, which sometimes they are ("North American Scum," "Time to Get Away").
Still an expert architect of musical spectacles, but . . . does anybody actually like the guy? ("Tonite," "Oh Baby")

"My history has brought me to this place/This power and the color of my face"--not an easy brag to bring off modestly, and the more I listen the more I appreciate the trick ("I Know Better," "Darkness and Light," "Marching Into the Dark")
Mad Red Bulgarian Wannabes of the Appalachians ("Somethin' in the Water," "No Such Thing").
forget Lou Ann and think Janis cum Bonnie--a voice to make Austin's dreams come true ("Locomotive Blues," "Wild Women Don't Get the Blues")
Not Lou meets Leonard, children, Eef meets Jonathan, and just as dark and droll ("Giving Up Redheads," "Apparition")
Diasporan pansalsa, the next level-meaning ready for the cruise ships and good clean fun ("Boom Boom Tararï¿½" "Ave Maria [Por Dios]").
Birdlike 17-year-old romantic proves how precocious she is with jazzy keyb chords I hope she outgrows and tricky beats that mark a way forward ("Moon Shoes," "Free Room")
in-joke after glorious rock-bohemia in-joke ("Mekons Come to Town," "Jean-Michel")
Early on, Dundalk raver fuses "raw"--nay, "cotton field"--songs with standup bits ("So Frightened," "Brothers Gonna Work It Out," "Heavy Music for the Hard Working Man")
From Kansas City, Kan. (it makes a difference), a white rapper-by-default whose sarcastic rhymes hook sharper than his hooky beats ("Lithium Lips," "Jihad!").
Taking leftism pop--that one's tough to pull off ("Viz," "I'm So Excited").

album: It's the Ones Who've Cracked That the Light Shines Through
comment: Doubles as a cartoonist, where it's harder to cram so many words in ("Don't Let the Record Company Take You Out to Lunch," "You Don't Have to Be a Scientist to Do Experiments on Your Own Heart").

album: The Jerry Lee Lewis Anthology: All Killer No Filler!
comment: not the post-Sun comp he has in him--and the compiled-to-death Sun tracks are only half the problem ("Money (That's What I Want)," "Drinking Wine Spo-Dee O'Dee")
just normal stars like Jackie, Diane, and the Great Houdini ("28 Days," "6 Minutes")

album: They Threw Us All in a Trench and Stuck a Monument on Top
comment: not a bad trick--tension-and-release that never lets go ("Grown Men Don't Fall in the River, Just Like That," "The Garden Was Crowded and Outside")
"Original soundtrack" to a theoretical blaxploitation movie, and less beaty for its pains ("Night Out," "Double Up").
Glasgow art girl ends punk fling in Sydney, five years ago now ("The Leanover," "New Town").
Postpunk E Street for fuckups clocking e-dollars ("Touch My Stuff," "Lie Down on Landsdowne").
avant German trap drummer and eager Ivoirians with something to teach Mick Fleetwood, Byrne & Eno, and all too many patronizing jazzmen("Renï¿½" "African Loops")
What they were put on earth for--loud guitar and very little else, which happens to include a pastoral interlude ("Sound Guardians," "Rain on Lake I'm Swimming In").

artist: Lil Jon & the East Side Boyz
comment: 'Hood shit slammin', 'ho shit damnin' ("Get Low Remix," "Get Low Merengue Mix").
Throws her voice around more and her pussy down hardly at all ("Spell Check," "Lighters Up").
gangsta pop at its funniest, sickest, and safest ("My Baby," "Where They At")
tough-guyisms so steeped in convention they disappear into the bounce ("Drop It Like It's Hot," "Tha Block Is Hot," "F*** Tha World")
So smart and scary about death as the flip side of ecstasy, so unperceptive and embarrassing about emo ("Drop the World," "American Star").
the men don't know what the angry boys understand ("Points of Authority," "Papercut")
Darn-not 69, 50, or even 48, only 15, none of them up for legislative ratification ("The Songs of the 50 States," "New Hampshire").
Great players and unusually reliable thinkers, they still have something to prove and more to teach, especially to the hard-rock faithful ("Asshole," "Burned Bridges").
Cooler as Captain Lifer than Mr. Goodbar, but surprisingly likable either way ("Bath Salt," "We Came to Party")
Just too nice a guy to make his pan-Africanism panoramic ("Jamm," "Dieuf Dieuf")

Jack Douglas replaces Roy Thomas Baker at the helm, and if you know the difference it sounds that way ("Rock & Roll Professionals," "Keep Your Girlfriend");
Twenty-seven years old and already an older woman--how wearisome ("Once and Never Again," "Heaven Help the New Girl").
Civilized sex--the dark side ("Guilt," "I'm Going to Hell").
Billie Holiday tribute mixtape-qua-rip, no more and definitely no less ("Lost Souls," "The Night")

"My lyrics seem to amaze us--all five of us," cracks the crackpot, who at least cans the porn in this multi-collab whose producer is solely responsible for the instrumental intro it never tops ("Time? Astonishing!" "Dr. Bipolar," "Upwards. To Space!")
Atmospheric North Carolina beatmaster embellishes sincere Topeka rapper, Firesign Theater chips in ("Before Midnight," "Dopamine")

sounds great, but still--one song about angels, one about rain, one about a dream, one about a train ("Kiko and the Lavender Moon," "Saint Behind the Glass")
From Chicano r&b to Chicano bricolage and most of the way back, with famous friends pointing the way ("Kitate," "Hurry Tomorrow")

Just what their retro-nuevo surf instrumentals needed--singers (translating '60s hits into Spanish? One of them an Anglo anyway?) ("Hey Lupe [Hang on Sloopy]"; "De Dia y de Noche [All Day and All of the Night]").
Her daddy was a DJ and she makes the most of it ("No V.I.P.," "Daddy Was a DJ")
Poison-hearted one track and into you for life the next, Anglo-Zambian Dane claims rapper as opposed to pop star but may not really know ("Poison," "Thunder")
Entertaining to the converted ("Here I Am," "I've Been to Memphis").
Note with relief that he's papering over his spiritual limitations with covers and cowrites ("Pantry," "Loretta").
Song band turns groove band, not necessarily on purpose ("Danny's Outta Money," "Little Queen of New Orleans")

"Place my bet on my rockin' machine" ("Livin' Large," "Crackpot Baby").
manly, masculine, male--they cover the bases ("Door #1," "My Side of the Bed")
"mid-century Chinese pop" that sounds like John Fahey--when nobody's singing ("Please Allow Me to Look at You Again" [track 2], "Please Allow Me to Look at You Again" [track 13])
Rap porn clown as rap businessman, a richer choice thematically than rap entertainment mogul or rap crime boss ("Tell It Like It Is," "Mouths to Feed," "Slap").
Pale Blue Eyes play ambient alternative ("Friendly Advice," "Going Home")
downsized no, privatized yes ("Sweet Child o' Mine," "U.S. Out of My Pants!").
Alt-country lifer as murderer, Iraq vet, rancher, and fucker up of the love of his life ("Sadr City," "S Lazy H")

album: Ballads, Banjo Tunes, and Sacred Songs of Western North Carolina
comment: As imperious as Odetta, and he's got a right ("On a Bright and Summer's Morning," "Old Mountain Dew").

"Hella" good rapper swears that this album he'll break out, and then, unfortunately, writes album about it ("Whispers," "Do You Buy It").
so intensely beautiful you can hear through the instruments from the right angle ("Sama Duniya," "Swing Yela")
Afrocentric mixmaster's multiculture speaks only da English--but in a beatful way (Outlaw Blues Band, "Deep Guilty"; Steve Grossman, "Inmate Man").
seductive self-regard over the best tracks fame can buy ("Don't Stop")
learning and adjusting like always, and no, stupid, not hypocritically--although maybe inattentively ("Mother and Father," "Nothing Fails")
OK, a middle-aged fitness nut can sing pop ditties just like middle-aged lushes could once sing pop standards, with this requirement--a little help from Timbo and Kanye ("4 Minutes," "Beat Goes On").

album: The Hidden Treasures of Taj Mahal 1969-1973
comment: A dozen previously unearthed semiprecious stones plus ramshackle concert ("Sweet Mama Janisse," "I Pity the Poor Immigrant")

for his supper ("Masole A Banana," "Amaqhawe Omgqashiyo")
after 30 years, not everything (or everywho) they used to be ("Ilamba Lidlile," "Umgqashiyo")

album: Power to the People: Nigerian Reggae
comment: militant roots and sufferation, Afrobeat-style ("Coat of Many Colors," "Injustice," "Bubbler")
obliging ethnic Angolan adds Lusophone accordion to Zaire-rooted pan-Afro-Latinism ("Galo Negro," "Maloba")
old rumba master's new songs, meaning neoclassicism that misses on one cylinder ("Escrobondo," "Ibrahim")
punk propaganda poppified, which generates an illusion of context ("Ocean Spray," "Let Robeson Sing")
"Go back to the cave, go back to the .ï¿½ï¿½" ("Engwish Bwudd," "Tunneling Through the Guy").
an original even on her endless ballads, conflating florid and soulful without ever sounding like the wannabe she is ("Ooo La La La," "Lovergirl")

album: It Won't Be Soon Before Long
comment: Learning what Prince has always known--that kindnesses render a falsetto manly and kiss-offs don't ("Nothing Lasts Forever," "Won't Go Home Without You").
"You wanna hear me sing straight, buy an ablium" ("Drink to Me Only With Thine Eyes/Pennies From Heaven [Bourbon]/Hello, Dolly [Vegas]," "Monologue").
Homemade-sounding ditties about what sounds like middle-class family life ("Family Tree," "Marco Polo")
The brawnier-voiced Musclehead On Parade makes a metal record ("Stand Up," "Ground Zero").
Sounds like a nice chick, but her Arabic leaves too much to the imagination ("Yemma [Mummy, I Lie to You]," "Ya Kelbi [Oh! My Heart]").
Saudade Algerian-exile style--and yes, the translations help ("Inspiration [Ilham]," "Tell Me Why").
Pre-millennium unction ("Risingson," "Man Next Door").
Four different ways of revisiting a trip-hop ("Bulletproof Love [Van Rivers and the Subliminal Kid Remix]," "Psyche [Flash Treatment]").
Old-schooler as working stiff--craftsmanlike rhymer and plotter, much heart ("Da Grind," "Bklyn Masala")
Kills Ghostface because RZA still rules ("Old Man," "No Said Date").
The Mars Volta on pinkeye, Vashti Bunyan on pink elephants, and Fleetwood Mac on second-hand news are all froth to them ("Long Way Home," "Laura").
As much tributes as covers, "township tech" remakes of 40 years of South African hits ("Jacknife," "Melodi")
Living songs about the power of blackness and the illusory allure of green ("The L&N Don't Stop Here Anymore," "You'll Never Leave Harlan Alive").

he can't outbeat D'Angelo, so he works on outsinging and outsonging him ("Temporary Night," "This Woman's Work," "Lifetime")

hippie imitation of the year, sad division ("I'm Sailin," "Holah")
a marriage manual like only Nashville can make them ("Crying on the Shoulder of the Road," "All the Things We've Never Done")

album: Things We Said Today: The Best of Mary McCaslin
comment: progressive schoolmarm as spirit of the West ("The Bramble and the Rose," "Last Cannonball")

knows what she knows ("When in Love," "All That")
as sane as Chuck D, plus she likes to have her toes sucked ("TRG [The Rap Game]," "Everyday")

the country songbook can't convey their desperation and rage, high mountain "Burnin' Love" notwithsstanding ("Dempsey Nash," "Go Out Smokin'")
The dark side of bluegrass revivalism ("TMP Smackdown," "How Can I Be So Thirsty Today?").
singing the blooze like Wilko Johnson or Roger Chapman--and he isn't even British! ("Witch on Fire," "War All the Time");
High anxiety in the fine old strained, dissonant, guitar-slashing manner ("Death on Display," "Paint You").

ragamuffin world-pop, Anglophone Ethiopian-Swedish division--light as a feather, sank like a stone ("Ragga Steady," "Poppadink Tribe")

Mantras-meditations-celebrations-boasts ("Speak to the Wild," "Tape")
Tectonically propulsive riffing signifying besotted erotic enchantment ("Exalted," "Smoke of Dreams")

"The Beauty of the Days Gone By" ("Georgia on My Mind," "Man Has to Struggle")

album: . . . It's Too Late to Stop Now . . . Volumes II, III, IV & DVD
comment: Three concerts within just two months of 1973, 45 songs total, only seven repeated, none thrice--nifty package, considering ("Since I Fell for You [IV]," "Come Running," "I Paid the Price")

comment: Trad like it useta be ("Lost John," "Don't You Rock Me Daddio").

Pretty consolations for a broken-up man ("Woke Up New," "Half Dead").

comment: Ayatollahs or no ayatollahs, she will too sing these devotional love songs ("Beloved," "The Desire of Union")

folk songs for an age of electronic media and confusion-is-sex ("Harvey Fierstein," "The Cosby Show," "Richard's Brown Baby Boy")
Embarrassing truths beneath America's mild surface ("Terrorist Song," "European Vacation").

comment: Finally, repertoire worthy of his voice/shtick ("Rainy Night in Georgia," "Respect Yourself").

musically, Hieronymus Bosch as postindustrial atheist; lyrically, Transformers as kiddie porn ("Heresy," "Reptile")

as in condoms--also kidded ("Just the Flu," "Where's My Slice?")

artist: Conor Oberst and the Mystic Valley Band
comment: At last less depressed by his fame, still too impressed by his gift of gab ("Slowly [Oh So Slowly]," "Roosevelt Room").
Uncommonly uncompromising garage barrage, its admonitory peak an obscure modern soul song ("Call the Police," "Fire Detector")
The--all right, an--erotic truth for an epoch of signal-impaired courtship and the phone pulsing every time you get a new sext ("Grip," "Veritas")

Fleshing out the biggest drawback of the bi life, which is that love is complicated enough when there's only one sex to choose from ("Gallery Piece," "Women's Studies Victims").
Crude but ultimately likable singer, willing band, decent melodist, better writer than the Decemberists' Colin Meloy ("For Real," "In a Radio Song").
The most affecting song is the least literary--and yet without storytelling the music would be styleless arrangements gathered around the intermittent tune ("Savannah Smiles," "Unless It's Kicks").
Any friend of Jeb Loy Nichols is a friend of country music--especially Ricky Barnes ("Big Mistake," "Shade Tree Fix-It Man").
That n***a'z really crazy--which doesn't make him Richard Pryor ("I Can't Wait," "Recognize").
Their rough and rowdy ways--two CDs worth ("Time Bomb," "Barrier Reef").
Stretches Rhett Miller's skill set most impressively when he takes the name of the Lord in vain ("Good With God," "Jesus Loves You")
he's got skillz, connectionz, a wicked laugh--and he can rhyme some ("Biological Didn't Bother," "No Hook")

these days, rap-salsa . . . gumbo, gusado, couscous, whatever, doesn't just feel like chaos--it also feels like life ("Pa Lante," "1234")
Timbaland sets him off, the 919 keeps him going ("Raise Up," "Petey Pablo," "I")

so much command of Nashville conventions he'd fool with them as soon as feel with them ("Little Moments," "Famous People")

In the grand solo-artist manner, better when she explains her dark-side vision than when she explores it ("Runs in the Family," "Ampersand").

Impure pop from faux-punk people ("Hard Times," "Caught in the Middle)
he tries hard, but he could use a producer ("Bush Killa," "Make Way for a Panther")

artist: John Parish and Polly Jean Harvey
comment: art project, theatre tryout, like that--striking proof that her words mesh best with her music ("Dance Hall at Louse Point," "Taut")

buzzsaw industrial ("Fork Lift")

beats the part-time variety in life, but not necessarily in art ("Bouncin' Back," "Fear No Evil," "Miss You")

"Garbage burning in the yard, a rebel flag waves/Car on blocks, a pit bull chained/All the sheriff's deputies know his name" ("Real Country," "Jesus Was a Revolutionary").

comment: Sub rosa reports from the Travis County Liberated Zone ("It's Too Late to Live in Austin," "The New American Dream," "Aunt Lou")

unperfected ("The Crack Up," "In Conference Again")

crazy like a glue ("10 Commandments," "Mr. Dino Koosh Rock")
see the movie ("Being Boring," "October Symphony")
two discs of marginalia proving what?--that Very could have been more amazing yet? ("What Keeps Mankind Alive?" "Shameless," "Too Many People")

First three new songs on the bonus disc gave me hope for the next four, which, well, you know (and there are also some pretty decent remixes/remakes!) ("Be Still My Heart," "A Tattered Line of String")
Clean-cut Canadienne tops shows of intelligence with novelty cover ("I'm Too Sexy," "Barricades")
Exes all, ex-Pogue Cait O'Riordan and ex-Hothouse Flowers Fiachna O'Braonain and Dave Clarke kiss off their departed spouses, Rolling Stones-style ("Suckerpunched," "Firefighter").
style over substance ("Night in My Veins," "I'm a Mother")
For some people, love never gets easier ("Boots of Chinese Plastic," "You Didn't Have To").
four early songs twixt thrash and Sleater-Kinney ("Liquid Courage," "Modern Day Emma Goldman")
Halfway to what every diva has to learn-pipes are not enough ("At Least [The Little Things]," "Married Man").
Austin interpreter triangulated by Memphis, Nashville, and El Lay ("Bluebird," "Too Much Coffee")
Musicianly postgraduate postpunk steals one of its few credible melodies from X-Ray Spex and proves hookiest when ranting ("No Big Bang," "Suck")
To hell in a cybercar ("Kill All Hippies," "MBV Arkestra [If They Move Kill 'Em]").
With roots going all the way back, genealogically, to the Salem witch trials, banjo-accordion-sousaphone-drums steamfunkers got a right to sing the bemused ("Astronauts," "Little Arrow")
quite possibly the strangest top-10 band ever, and good for them ("Bob," "DMV")
modern teen horrors simplified--and funkified ("Wynonna's Big Brown Beaver," "On the Tweek Again")

artist: Prince and the New Power Generation
comment: doesn't know his own new power ("Willing and Able," "Jughead," "Cream")
Put it this way--two decades after "What'd I Say," Ray Charles's shtick was a lot tireder ("Hot Wit U," "Undisputed").
four previously unreleaseds, three previously rereleaseds, who cares--he's got a million of 'em ("Lake Marie," "Stick a Needle in Your Eye")
14 divorce duets plus one excellent Hank Williams ringer, none written by Prine, whose wife Fiona joins in on "My Happiness" lest you worry ("Mental Cruelty," "Just Waitin'")
assaults get irritating sometimes, sense of humor or no sense of humor ("Jericho")
Weird thing--at the proper historical distance, good rave and good punk provide the same cheap thrill ("Thunder," "Invaders Must Die").

album: Bobby Fuller Died for Your Sins
comment: Protest songs that leave you more pissed than you were before and half-told tales that leave you curiouser and curiouser ("Alex Nieto," "Jesus Was a Social Drinker")
"Preachin' to the Quiet," as in, "How you gonna say no to drugs if you don't say no to thugs?" ("MKLVFKWR," "New Whirl Odor").

album: Nothing Is Quick in the Desert
comment: Giving it away isn't phoning it in, but I wish their sharpest line had a song attached and find that Ice-T's scornful 16 cuts deeper than all of Chuck's gruff outrage ("If You Can't Join Em Beat Em," "SPEak!")
death--the greatest hook of all ("What You Gonna Do?," "I'll Be Missing You")
record collectors and their robot trying very hard to feel ("Silicon Teens," "Tunnel Song")
if someone were to call Sam Coomes an archetypal indie whiner, how would you respond? what about if I did? ("A Fable With No Moral," "Empty Words")
either too dubwise or not dubwise enough ("Sunday Shining," "It's Great When We're Together")

would rawk more unremittingly on one's stereo without the transmission interruptions claiming rawk's banned from one's radio ("You Think I Ain't Worth a Dollar, but I Feel Like a Millionaire," "Hangin' Tree")

paring down from "I Hate Your Fucking Guts," "I Just Called to Say Fuck You," "Journey to the Center of Your Empty Fucking Skull," "Stupid Fucking Vegan," "My Cunt's a Cunt," and "Just Say Cunt" to "See You Later Fuckface" in just two years! ("I Never Got the Girl," "Homo")
Jack helps Brendan with his problems, remains stuck on his own ("Steady as She Goes," "Intimate Secretary").
Developed in concert, hence more jammy, less songy and less Yorkey, which is good ("Jigsaw Falling Into Place," "Bodysnatchers").
So much more fun than Eno these days ("Little by Little," "Bloom")
multi-user shared hallucinations of an alt-rap record geek ("Pyramidi," "Clam Chowder Day")
"Thinking in a way that is interesting to me," alt-rapper explores Fairlight, drinks Haterade, lives "day-to-day" ("Sometimes," "Personality Theft").
Egyptian-American rapper remembers where he came from but has too evolved a sense of humor to just stick it in your face ("Gypsy Shoe," "Antibiotics")
the right music at the wrong time ("Failing and Leaving," "Sugar Free")
Mancunian groovemasters sneak Brit hip hop into Yank underground flow (Swollen Members, "S & M on the Rocks"; Mr. Scruff, "Get a Move On")
The root source of Salif Keita, Mory Kante and Djelimady Tounkara put to a completist test few bands still working stuff out can ace ("Armee Malienne," "Fankante Dankele").
Bartholin's glands don't fail me now ("Used to Rule the World," "Million Miles")

album: The 18th Letter: The Book of Life
comment: his canon has a clarity his comeback can't match ("When I'm Flowin'," "It's Been a Long Time")
punk rant at its streetest ("Rejected," "Adina")
Solidarity forever ("East Bay Night," "Civilian Ways").
it's all about the beats ("Mr. Loverman," "Ting-a-Ling")
Underground rap manifesto as genuinely worthwhile endeavor ("Hard to Choose," "The Man")
Brave, openhearted Trap City irregular has a message for Myron Ebell, a name you'd best get to know: "Lord save our burning planet!" ("Friends," "Revolution")
In control of (their romance with) the out of control ("Boys Who Rape [Should All Be Destroyed]," "Bang!").
rueful moans in the quiet night ("Uncertain Blues," "HIV Blues")
Paroled Death Row intimate pours some gravel on poor righteous teaching ("Stop That," "Echoes of My Mind").
Several of the best songs here aren't even the best songs on "Blood Visions," and then there's the momentum thing ("Let It All Go," "Hammer I Miss You").
the varied punk noisefests I credit to their learning curve, the screechy punk vocals I blame on their voices ("Alright!" "Wrecked")
Chicano, Native American, conscious, Christian ex-gangbanger from the Beach Boys' hometown inspires curseless Kurupt cameo--wow! ("405," "Death of a Salesman").
Hot mix of two concerts that duplicate the one memorialized as Live in Europe way back in 1967 ("Try a Little Tenderness," "Respect").
they've grown up, they've learned to write, they've got a right to be sex mystiks ("Give It Away," "Breakin' the Girl")
Aptest alt-country band name yet devised ("Nixon Stamp," "After the Revolution").
honoring his own history with Dylanesque craft and disregard, only you can understand every word ("The Kids," "New Sensations")
Brainiac monkeys sit at keyboards, write cross between "Jabberwocky," "Millie Pulled a Pistol on Santa," and Marx's "Eighteenth Brumaire" ("Everybody Come On," "Active Galactic Nuclei").
that old-time riddim meets dem newfangled beats ("World Gone Reggae," "Not a One Man Thing")
profuse guitar, 'nuff rap ("CP Time," "What's My Name")
On Steve Vai's label, only would you believe funkier? ("Known Unknown," "Brilliant Corners").
Jack White's garage-blues feel without its poetry ("Time Bomb High School," "Stormy Weather")
Never-say-die hipster rails at the powers that be--wins one occasionally, too ("Boltcutter Blues," "Clean Blood Blues")
Gospel-funk journeyman Gean West rises from his deathbed to put his God's stamp on this mortal coil ("Rational Culture/Testimony," "Can't Feel Nothin'")
At last the pop album nostalgics are always bitching about, and it's an improvement ("Around the Sun," "Leaving New York").

album: Don't Sell or Buy, It's Crap
comment: loud sloppy rools ("Satellite")
slow thoughtful rools ("Sadly Beautiful," "The Last")
sexist subtext (or text), no redeeming antisocial value, rock like a funk-damaged Ministry nonetheless ("Stainless Steel Providers," "Beers, Steers and Queers")
Sometimes the threat of jail time can clear a man's head ("Arab Money," "I'm a Go and Get My . . .").

album: We Used to Think the Freeway Sounded Like a River
comment: More three-dimensional in his novels, Willy Vlautin's not-yet-down-and-outers are uncommonly humane in his murmured songs ("The Boyfriends," "A Letter to the Patron Saint of Nurses").
Concocting a persona of interest out of one dynamite musical trick and a bad patch I wouldn't wish on Lindsay Lohan ("Hard," "Rude Boy").

album: Duke Robillard and His Dames of Rhythm
comment: Skilled blues-rock guitarist expands into pop-swing-etc. keepers he hands off to women who can sing him under the bandstand--none deeper, natch, than Maria Muldaur ("Was That the Human Thing to Do," "Easy Living")
domestic nonviolence, subtly sublimated for your tranquil contemplation ("My Winter Coat," "I'm Someone Who Loves You")
Too much timba, not enough that other part ("El Sabor Del Shabat," "Oran Oran [Homage to Maurice 'Papi' El Medioni]").
world's greatest roots-rock band ("Brand New Car," "New Faces")

The rare arena-rock recording that does justice to the subgenre's power dwarfs their 1971 Marquee Club vault-pull while making a case for the excision of "Midnight Rambler" and "Brown Sugar" from their A list ("Happy," "Starfucker")
Gen X Comedy Hour X 2 ("Strength--Pt. 2," "Airplanes")

album: If I've Only One Time Askin'
comment: A normalization move even if the title song romances a prostitute, and I miss the oddball ("Learning to Do Without Me," "Two Word Joe")

album: The Roots Come Alive: Open Access
comment: World-class DJ and beatbox, excellent drummer and bassist, pretty darn good rapper(s), bourgie jazzmatazz ("Proceed," "Love of My Life").

album: The Roots All Stars: Gathering of the Spirits
comment: Mutabaruka, Sly, Robbie, and friends meet the predancehall elite (Culture, "Blackman King"; the Mighty Diamonds, "Blackman Pride").
after seven long years of Mitchell Froom, Los Lobos's rocker has it his way ("You've Got To Lose," "Better Way")
Likes women, loves his parents, abuses Miller Lite, raps with an easy flow, cultivates a sense of humor ("Lark on My Go-Kart," "His Dream").
Beat-seeking classical violinist connects more deeply with Philip Glass than with DJ Spooky, mostly just because Glass is deeper himself ("Metamorphosis," "The La La Song").

Though they finally own the trick of tune, the Norwegian electropoppers still rent out the gift of voice, with not Robyn or Lykke Li but Karin Dreijer Andersson again giving them the most for their Euro ("This Must Be It," "Tricky, Tricky").

album: Roswell Rudd's Malicool With Toumani Diabate
artist: Roswell Rudd's Malicool With Toumani Diabate
comment: Trombone learns Sahel ("Bamako," "Johanna")
Not "Latin jazz," Latin plus jazz, with which guys this friendly equals fun ("Pouchie & the Bird," "Mayor G").
as hi-NRG as any Zaire-Berkeley connection will likely get ("Santa Bella," "Fire-Fire")
Peace to Killer Mike, Bing his Ferguson speech please, but I've been around too long to let a corticosteroid abuser like El-P get in my face about right and wrong ("Early," "Angel Duster")
A mixtape that does its honest best to focus his subset's goals in a world way more mixed up than the mixtape is ("World in My Hands," "Most")
talking dirty and saying something ("Two in the Bush Is Better Than One in the Hand," "(Mr. Insurance Man) Take Out That Thing for Me")
alright alright keep up the speed girls ("Alright Alright [Here's My Fist Where's the Fight?]," "Keep Up the Speed")
Egyptian-American from Tennessee kicks off her Americana EP with a Huey Smith figure and makes you wonder whether her melodic shading is cultural or individual. ("Been Around," "One Too Many")

album: Belly of the Beast: The Scram Jones Files
comment: Gangsta realist's mixtape ain't his urban-legend debut, but it's tough, it's smart and it jams ("New York Streets," "Nobody Cares").
Modern love for the postmodern English--sad, kind, contained ("Mr Donut," "Been So Long").
"I've been searching for/All the people/I used to turn to/All the people/Who knew the answer/Let's get the feeling again" ("Soft Like Me," "Rock Palast")
Classy lady reveals not only that she's feral but that she takes out the garbage ("Prince Johnny," "Psychopath")

Beyoncï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ and Drake's go-to angel finds time for his own piano-rooted reflections, which between his unforced falsetto and his electronic atmospherics prove so intim"Plastic 100ï¿½ï" "Kora Sings")
Deep in neither beats nor conceits ("Disparate Youth," "Go!")
twisted tuneful love songs for fruity electronic baritone and jaded late-teen females ("I Want You," "Truly Madly Deeply")
Hot Chip he's not, though from what I hear he's hiring ("Wildfire," "Something Goes Right")
the Allmans had join the White Panthers ("88," "Marijuana Wine")

Gay street-hustler-once-removed rough-rides the rock canon and tells drug stories that'll make you chortle as your hair stands on end ("I'm Waiting for the Man/Walk on the Wild Side/You Can't Always Get What You Want," "Scream Along With Billy Theme").

"He said you gotta have a reason for a revolution/She said if you don't have the wherewithal you don't need the why," and like so many ex-Marxists, Green Gartside loves women in theory ("The Boom Boom Bap," "Road to No Regret").
authentic Senegalese mbalax, high-powered but resistant to export ("Allo Petit," "Abibatou")
Rolling Mandinka beats from agricultural and above all non-Wolof Senegal ("Nyancho," "Dimbaayaa").
18 salty tunes, 11 acoustic instruments, no overdubs ("Ground Hog," "Tennessee Dog")
old-timey all-stars ("Shaking Off the Acorns," "Brown's Ferry Blues")
Recorded well before Buena Vista, when he was a mere septugenarian, and the extra synovial fluid helps the son flow ("Chan Chan," "Me Diras Que Sabroso").
Singsong raps or vice versa on brand new marginal themes over basswise chamber-pop beats ("Accommodating," "Karate")
A little night music about too many day jobs ("They Fired Me," "Have to Go to Work").
live boot (Burton Upon Trent, 9/24/76) as budget-priced history--crude, kinda slow, a few rare titles, four demos added ("Substitute," "No Fun")
Conscious hip-hop Rwanda-Ontario style, comedy included ("The Old Prince Still Lives at Home," "I Don't Like To").

album: Mr. Lover Lover (The Best of Shaggy . . . Part 1)
comment: so r&b that for incomprehensibilty's sake he outsources some patois ("Boombastic [Sting Remix]," "In the Summertime")
Reborn Berlin techno drone litens up his ancestors' horny dance music without cheapening its charm--more than is appropriate, anyway ("Sota," "Disko Partizani").
Attn. Gary Clark Jr.--21st-century blues eclecticism done right, although admittedly an arena-rock anthem would be a nice addition ("Banking Blues," "Endless Path," "Down on the Block")
Another Christian truth-sayer heard from ("Live Forever," "Slim Chance and the Can't Hardly Playboys").
Enjoy today's best-researched protest songs while they're still funny ("The Head of Alberto Gonzalez," "Stuff Happens").

Philly quartet with shrieky woman on top do indeed convert Skynyrd's "Gimme Two Steps" into their own "Fan the Flames," but I say they're headed for a Real Album and predict the remake will rock ("Fan the Flames," "Button Up")
Humanist country, Bobby Braddock-style ("Cotton Pickin' Time," "The Bartender").
Although his big voice bogs down making his songwriters' big emotions sound deep, their jokes he's got the attitude for ("Hey," "Get Some")
Three women in wigs shout their shouts and tell their weird, unassuming tales ("Teacher," "Prozac").
She'd be fixing to backslide all the way down if there wasn't a title song making her bow her head to you-know-who ("Look It Up," "Tryin' to Go to Church")
mates ambient and beatwise so deep down they almost procreate ("No Dog Jazz," "Boogaloo")
striver's rap, JA-U.S. style ("Cigarette Breath")
Problem's less the precious lyrics he attaches to his premium melodies than the increasingly precious way he sings them ("Simple Song," "September")
Unsurprisingly given her ax, go-to alt-country violinist sounds more herself on the twisty, evocative melodies than the direct, declarative rockers ("Harmless," "The Way It Dimmed," "Pale Fire")

If only she could light up the melancholy of "Good as Gold" with the dawning consciousness of "What It Takes," she might be able to figure out how to duck men's meanness without drinking herself into the ditch ("Parting Words," "Lesson")
Much more fun mixing down Afrostyles than claiming roots reggae roots--also more meaningful ("Tamagbondorsu [The Rich Mock the Poor]," "Mhloma [Let Us Be United]").
His beats are as tough as his rap, and damned if I know whether that's good or bad ("What Your Life Like," "Ride 4 My").
Not to be essentialist or anything, but this Kenyan-American-led Bay Area Afrobeat unit generates uncommon funk--and appears to comprise black musicians exclusively ("Shelter," "Chrome").
One meta-masterpiece, six pieces of lovingly belabored art-grunge ("Don't Look Back," "The Operative/His Mark Replies").
Old perfessor's enjoyable survey course in his own legacy, only he should never let the world forget "Peace Like a River" ("The Boy in the Bubble," "That Was Your Mother")
The real Avril Lavigne ("Autobiography," "Lala").
Hard to believe the big bad label guy told him to write about outlaws when he loved his daddy so much ("Life Ain't Fair and the World Is Mean," "King Coal")
hippiedom as folklore ("She Would if She Could, She Can't So She Won't," "Romance Is All Screwed Up")

If only glam had actually liked girls--if only the Runaways had written better songs--if only all-covers CDs didn't fall a little flat--if only revivalists didn't overrate Girlschool ("High School," "Tumble With Me").
From Portugal, why not, Afrotechno 15 or 20 years behind schedule ("Sound of Kuduro," "Aqui Para Vocï¿½").
gentle generic Zimpop, masterful mbira guitar ("Chakafukidza Dzimba," "Vakomano Vehondo")
cavalcade of drips ("San Diego Zoo," "Pillow Fight," "Heaven in a Black Leather Jacket")
in the mildly overrated tradition of Massive Attack and Soul II Soul ("Digital," "Electricks")
steam-driven dissonance down a blooze-based groove ("Nod Off," "The World's Most Famous Undertaker")
No longer going for the jugular, he risks missing pencilnecks like yours truly altogether ("Try It Out [Neon Mix]," "Stranger")

album: Skrillex and Diplo Present Jack ï¿
comment: Powerhouses sucker-punch hardest with help from 2 Chainz and Kiesza--not, hilarious idea and predictable profit-taker though it is, Justin Bieber ("Febreze," "Take ï¿½ï¿½ï¿")
out of left field ("You Got Away With Love, "Why Did You Stop")
"You know I've made a lot of albums/Trying to get national attention/But what it seem like now I'm gonna be a old man/Living off a pension" ("I'm Tired Now," "Widow Woman")

album: That'll Get It (Even More of the Best)
comment: Smith-penned/produced oddments that include one Huey-plus-Clowns essential, eight previously unreleaseds, and much amiable joking around (Bobby Marchan and the Clowns, "Would You Believe It [I Have a Cold]"; Danny White, "Educated Fool"; the Clowns, "Barbara"; Jesse Thomas, "Baby Won't You Turn Me On")
always took herself too seriously, still touched with the divine ("Persuasion," "Gone Pie")

album: The Thrill of It All (Deluxe Edition)
comment: Where on his debut bonus cuts diluted an intense album, on his star turn they salvage a laxer one ("Scars," "HIM")
Raps better than Rodney Dangerfield (even when he was alive), and funnier to boot ("If You Can't Dance [Slide]," "Ms. Holy Roller").

album: Stride Piano Duets: Live in Toronto, 1966
comment: The master, pushing 70, and the acolyte, just 50, push each other forward and around ("Sweet Georgia Brown," "Charleston").
expansive new songs, congenial new band, and the stompingest foot this side of John Lee Hooker ("Happier Blue," "Honeysuckle Bone")
Getting squishy on the emotional, spiky on the economic ("Diplomacy," "Origin of Species").
His dad died, the economy crashed, and his easy groove feels more amenable very year ("Surprise, Surprise," "Old Man Down").
The country-rock highlights will sound brighter live and acoustic, but other moments shine loud enough ("Late Last Night," "Margaritaville").
Musings of a slacker who knows too well why he chose that path ("Mission Accomplished [Because You Gotta Have Faith]," "Is This Thing On?").

album: Time as We Know It: The Songs of Jerry Jeff Walker
comment: The Godfather's material sounds loopier every time I play this thing--that is, more like the son's, which is a credit to them both ("Continuing Saga of the Classic Bummer or Is This My One Way Bus Ticket to Cleveland," "Pissin' in the Wind")
One-hit lipstick lesbian looks back at her life and/or career, swears she's got nothing to prove, and proves it ("Wendell Lee," "Nothing to Prove").
Out on their own, g-g-b-d survey the song-friendly precincts of the big wide indie-rock world and try a little of this and a little of that ("Saratoga," "Bound to Fall")

album: Sol-Angel and the Hadley St. Dreams
comment: Frothily, defiantly, privilege's child runs through her options ("Would've Been the One," "I Decided, Pt. 1").
Postmodern preblues ("Good Cheap Transportation," "Cold Wet Steel").

album: A Buena Vista: Barrio de la Habana
comment: more effervescent than your average Buena Vista spinoff, which it isn't, or exploitation, no comment ("Bilongo," "A Buena Vista," "La mï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½")

"Voter" skanks, then "Bamako" funks, then Iggy fronts "Sahara," and without ever quite nailing the Malian-American fusion Garba Toure's guitar just knows is there, they get closer and closer ("Dabari," "Bamako")
Mexico City youths adapt Peruvian cumbia to a mystical vision that has more Martin Denny in it than they know ("El Ventarron," "La Patrona")

Palenques are where Colombian escaped slaves reclaimed their lives with, among other things, call-and-response rhythm chants that sound great at first but do get repetitive ("Cumbia Africana," "Unye Unye")
A debut that flaunts their sound, suggests their parameters, and establishes their bona fides ("The Godfather," "Rivers of Babylon")
Roots revival fully worthy of the concept's primitivist conceit--Lesotho shepherds piece together their own guitars, fiddles, and drums ("Ha Kele Monateng," "Jerusalem")
old pros in control ("Abantu")
Arguably his most intense record, yet also arguably his most wearying and even sometimes dullest--the death-metal effect ("La Sidounak Sayyada," "Lansab Sherek")
Stoopid, but far from dumb--especially compared to the dogboys who froth at the mouth about him ("Bird Walk," "Eazy," "Soulja Boy Tellem").
Italian girlpunk with two boys, mucho irony, and a drum machine ("Magilla Godzilla," "Cadillac and Dinosaurs")
trumpet-tuba-guitar-(drums) improvise ballet score and other variations on "My Bonnie" ("Movement 3: Sisters," "Movement 5: End of the Night")
hardly the first not-terribly-bright teenager to approach self-knowledge via the words of others ("Overprotected," "Cinderella")
Her heart, her soul, her aesthetic maturation ("Oops . . . I Did It Again," " . . . Baby One More Time").
As in "media circus," but still fun more often than not, which is more than she could manage from on top of the world ("Womanizer," "Blur").
Lauryn wannabe unearths apposite folk-rock tunelets ("Slave to It All," "The Hey Song")
Once again, wise-ass New York art-pop (cf. Apple, McKay) outslugs subtle Toronto art-pop (e.g., Stars, Feist) ("Your Honor," "Ode to Divorce").
Permanent floating Chapel Hill garage trio promise they'll always always be honest with you--and mean it ("Summer of '79," "Back With You Again in the World")
Trying their hand at lounge jazz, chamber oboe, soundtrack bombast, any sound that'll stick ("Trouble and Luck," "I Undid Myself").
Always emotional, sometimes mawkish, he lives with war as he tries to forget it ("Last to Die," "Livin' in the Future").

album: Bruce Springsteen and the Session Band Live in Dublin
comment: As loose and unforced as he ever gets on record ("Open All Night," "Old Dan Tucker").
With Yo La Tengo and wide-ranging covers, and loosened by both inputs ("Venus," "Compared to What").

artist: Peter Stampfel & the Ether Frolic Mob
comment: Old coots sit around their virtual porches reinventing the hootenanny, young folks step up ("Shake It Break It," "Deep in the Heart of Texas")
Tweedy-Staples Secular Gospel Revival Finalists: George Clinton and . . . the Staple Singers ("Can You Get to That," "I Like the Things About Me")

album: If All I Was Was Black
comment: Flummoxed by the exacting distinction between catchy and memorable, she does her gospel-pop best with 10 Jeff Tweedy protest songs so subtly crafted they barely leave a mark ("Who Told You That," "If All I Was Was Black," "Try Harder")

Recorded a decade before he died in 2000 and now shored up with modest bass and drums by Jeff Tweedy and his boy, the patriarch's vocals and guitar recall very late John Hurt ("Somebody Was Watching," "Gotta Serve Somebody")
dance hits that got lost between soul and disco ("Victim," "Honest I Do Love You," "Young Hearts Run Free")
a piece of Mr. Fagen's band ("Bodhisattva," "Peg")
not quite hooky enough to reconcile me to a world that needs Marxist background music ("Wow and Flutter," "Fiery Yellow")

album: In Advance of the Broken Arm
comment: Guitar-shredding prog that makes its point in half its 45 minutes--except insofar as the point is aggravation ("Grapefruit," "Every Single Line Means Something").
Pretty battles evil in the service of kind ("The Dress Looks Nice on You," "In the Devil's Territory").

Outtake songs that fail to top the alternate versions of "Chicago" subsumed by outtake art-rock Glass-style, which beats Moussorgsky-style, Copland-style, Messiaen-style ("Dear Mr. Supercomputer," "Adlai Stevenson").
very large professor as rake-about-town ("The Naked Dutch Painter," "Giselle")
Selling metaphor to Volkswagens galore ("Kingdom of Drink," "Mind the Noose and Fare Thee Well").
Back to writing show-tunes-sans-show--rock and roll show tunes, sometimes, but always set pieces ("Black Men Ski," "Speed")
Starts off young and cocky, ends up sad and drunk ("I See the Want To in Your Eyes," "Drinkin' Thing")

album: As Time Goes By . . . The Great American Songbook Volume II
comment: No Sinatra, but also no Ronstadt, plus he knows the difference between Nelson Riddle and Gordon Jenkins ("Until the Real Thing Comes Along," "As Time Goes By").

As if by magic, at a farmer's market in Eugene in 1985, Pittsburgh-spawned "cult collective" have a fine old time marshalling their horny punk polyrhythms and brave female singer in support of Leonard Peltier and an autonomous Central America ("Products Throughout the Store," "Leonard")

"I'm nothing like 'Pac, I'm probably more like Posdnuos"--true that, but the prosey, not very Posdnuos "probably" suggests why Stik's Midwestern rhymes are better served by these commonsensical beats than by L'Orange's eloquent attentions ("James Lemonade," "Down Payment");
The sound of a bloke thinking big thoughts, which are less impressive than the bloke ("Everything Is Borrowed," "On the Edge of a Cliff").

artist: Street Sweeper Social Club (Tom Morello/Boots Riley)
comment: Rap's smartest revolutionary has lost some of his zest for life because a) Tom Morello knows only rage, b) collapse is just around the corner or c) there's a black president ("Clap for the Killers," "The Oath").

album: One Way Rocket Ride to Kicksville
comment: good old same-old excellent, drinking and girl problems high generic ("Proverbial Straw," "Drunk Idea")
immanence not transcendence, sonics not songs ("Tilted," "JC Auto")
a striking voice does not a pop band make--a striking band, maybe ("Birthday," "Vitamin")
more proof than we needed that she actually recorded "Don't Cry for Me Argentina" ("Love to Love You Baby," "Bad Girls")
New Zealand electronicat and Mexican guitarist dub it up with a glitchy thickness in boogie-down Melbourne ("Kow Chow," "Rokkit Snot")
For six songs, DC trio reiterate the garage-protopunk verities anew ("Push It," "Angel Eyes")
Fred Schneider and friends wish you an ebulliently ironic 25th ("Fruitcake," "Jingle Those Bells")
Chicago duo claim house, hip-hop, and avant influences for their ambient, which is indeed less austere than ambient ordinaire ("Belly," "Val Venus")
EP embraces a maturity they define in part as saving your winners for Warners ("Drinking Problem," "I'm Not Ready")
From Louisville, Ky., and why not, the articulated inarticulate rage crypto-fascism deserves ("Patriot Act," "F--- Your Stupid Civilization").

As her sister Katie toegazes with her Waxahatchie side project/one-off, Allison Crutchfield dons the grrrl-punk mantle with less musical, verbal, and vocal distinctness ("Movie Star," "Hundreds and Thousands")
for about 10 songs, the great glam-rock hit machine ("The Ballroom Blitz," "Fox on the Run")

hip hop interlopers from Vancouver with more technique than content, which falls back on that old reliable, horror comics ("Front Street," "Horrified Nights")
London logorrheic milks the romance of punk for hooks and pathos ("368," "Castro Dies").
In a noisy way ("Mystero," "The Golden Age").
North African Parisians get rowdy, live ("Comme d'Habitude," "Eray");
Imagine Kim Gordon and Gina Birch marking out turf between DNA and Swans ("Boldface," "Uniforms").

You have to respect a nuevo-psychedelic sage whose message to the world is "Nothing ever changes/No matter how long you do your hair/It looks the same to everyone else"--well, at least I do ("Apocalypse Dreams," "Feels Like We Only Go Backwards")

Swathed in electronics and simulated tenor, possibly the most soothing "alt-rock" record ever--so soothing one can barely feel the heartbreak 'tis said to expiate ("New Person, Same Old Mistakes," "Yes I'm Changing")
Their groove has evolved into a given, which does happen in Azawad ("Wainan Adobat," "Ehad Wad Nadorhan")
Brooklyn-born sideman, philosophy prof, and alte kaker waxes tender and unperturbed on the wings of gospel music and his Canadian citizenship ("Farther Along," "Brooklyn 1955")
contains six versions of their two girl-love hits, including a video ("Not Gonna Get Us," "All the Things She Said")
country blues from the other end of the Underground Railroad ("Ten Million Slaves," "Just Live Your Life")
Conscious bluesman's dolor is always earned, but that doesn't guarantee that it's always compelling, and sometimes it's enough already ("Blue Rain in Africa," "Jae Jae Waltz")
the everything-clashing model of passionate cooperation ("Uncle Phranc," "Don't Try Suicide")
Negotiating different power relations than heterosexual women, they have trouble getting out of themselves ("Back in Your Head," "Hop a Plane").

There are just seven insomniacs awake at 4:18 AM on one South London block, so Tempest rhymes their suffering over music that backs more than it powers, leaving us free to wonder--how are the sleepers doing, anyway? ("We Die," "Breaks")
Spitting image Shawn Sahm and raised-from-the-vault Freddy Fender resurrect lost supergroup's good humor and Tex-Mex pride ("Chicano," "Esta Bueno").

artist: Thao & the Get Down Stay Down
comment: As she must know already, improving your rhythmic interactivity seldom enhances your romantic connectivity--they're just different realms ("We Don't Call," "The Feeling Kind")

We know this trickster is "the last romantic" because, in the very same song, he tells his babydoll to present "panties to the side" ("Florida University," "Sex Intelligent")
Hither-and-yon mixtape featuring a number of indie-rappers doper than Doseone ("Keys to Ignition," "The Medicine").

Anticonspirator Jel's oldschool-schooled percussion figures and scattershot virtual orchestrations impart apparent coherence to Anticonspirator Doseone's verbalized personality disorders and scaredycore image-slinging ("BackIIburn," "Roman Is As Roman Does").
"History will show our progress is slow," so they make sure their music isn't ("A Stare Like Yours," "Remember Today")
tunes, aarghh, tunes--please not more tunes ("Dead," "Your Racist Friend")
but that doesn't mean they hate short people ("Older," "Wicked Little Critta")
something German plus something Jewish equals borscht-belt gestalt ("Santa's Beard," "Feast of Lights")
Kiddie songs becoming a habit, clever fellows service the grownup market ("When Will You Die," "2082")

album: Album Raises New and Troubling Questions
comment: A "rarities compilation" needn't maintain a surge, but it should peak more than this one does ("Authenticity Trip," "Marty Beller Mask," "Tubthumping")
He's got the falsetto thing down and the beat thing down, so if Weezy thinks he's Justin Timberlake, why not you? ("Hard on My Love," "Magic").
An amusing fellow getting her into bed, kind of a bore when he's done, and what else is new? ("Mrs. Sexy," "Sex Therapy").
Processed chï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½"Indra," "Treasures").

album: Bob Dinners and Larry Noodles Present Tubby Turdner's Celebrity Avalanche
comment: not that the words mean anything, but they create the illusion that the ricocheting guitars do ("Another Clip," "El Cerrito")
Belgian music for a European block party celebrating world migration ("Antwaarpse Shaabi," "Oppressor").

album: It Takes a Nation of Assholes
comment: Frantic fury ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½"Garbage In/Garbage Out," "Nailed to the Cross").
Keeping the dream alive--Minor Threat's, not MLK's ("About Last Night," "Makes My Teeth White," "My Notes").
Gogol Bordello as novelty act, albeit novelty act about our approaching doom ("Earworm," "Lucy")

IDM, midlife midtempo edition ("Singles Bar," "Hormones")

not enough concept/too much band ("Skillet," "Chocolate," "Pandemonium")

comment: Alt-country songbook ("Cry Cry Cry," "Rock Me to Sleep").

comment: she doesn't sing so great either, but she's better than he is, and his writing deserves it ("Unionbusting," "Let's Stay In")
Buppie sex Brit-boho style ("Anything," "Too Tough to Die").
"Our lives are ahead of us," so let's keep driving and hope the roses are still coming and going when we get there ("Heydays," "Circling")

in a ruminative mood, with a band cogitating in ("Goye Kur," "Dofana")

gangsta without apologies as entertainment without apologies ("Can't F**k With the South," "Take It to Da House")

grands beats, les gars, et je parie que j'aimerais les paroles aussi ("Les Pauvres Riches," "Pollutions")

Big enough to command great songs, even to put her hand to a feminist few, but not big enough to trust her indoor voice ("Mama's Song," "Two Black Cadillacs," "Remind Me")

album: How to Dismantle an Atomic Bomb
comment: Pop music as spiritual balm--there are worse ideas ("Miracle Drug," "Vertigo").

Adoring Bikini Kill adoring the Go-Go's adoring the Ramones adoring Phil Spector ("Tell the World," "Never See Me Again").

comment: Includes Fats Domino cover, a good look for any neogarage hopeful ("I Do!" "Georgy Boy").

ace arranger in thrall to fourflushing singer-songwriter ("Goin' Out West," "All Stripped Down," "I Don't Wanna Grow Up")

in love with her own voice, which deserves it, and him for listening, which is a mistake ("My Heart's in Trouble Tonight," "River of Love")

the five per cent nation of Oscar aspirations ("The M.G.M.," "For Heavens Sake")

more song, less band--also more feeling, less story ("Nothing Starts Today," "Baby in a Jar")

The finest Afro-European rhythmic structures Mali can provide ("Diama Don," "Dya").
word-mad proof that real has a softness and tough can flow ("UKNOWHOWWEDU," "Spontaneity")
The missing link between Bing and Billie--only subtler, meaning less substantial, than either ("Shoutin' in That Amen Corner," "The Weekend of a Private Secretary").

album: Love Songs for the Hearing Impaired
comment: macho token of the year ("I Love You Period," "Dixie Beauxderant")
Edinburgh weed drones and strums his snotty, whimsical, gender-conflicted plaints ("Sex Is Boring," "Donald in the Bushes With a Bag of Glue")
Their name was always the cheapest thing about them, and finally they write the respectable songs to prove it ("Single by Choice," "Song for a Good Son").
Europeanized Islamo-Yoruba Afrobeat strives to please ("Fuji Satisfaction," "Oya").
Mixtape musings of hip-hop hierophant start effulgent, lose current ("Word Vs. Meaning," "RZAView," "Make No Mistake").
Banjo-toting songman chronicles the homely-to-criminal travails of the downwardly mobile majority ("TSA," "Broken Clock").
laid-back Howard minimalists outart and outjosh the Native Tongues ("Not Over You," "Ode to My Favorite Beer")
Is that blood the big-time vocalists smear on the tracks, or ichor? ("Lucky Star," "Cish Cash," "Right Here's the Spot")
crystalline vision of pan-African bliss ("Morro do Kussava," "Kuribï¿½ï")

Summing up their entire career until Wild Honey, this is busted to noncom in honor of Endless Summer, only 13 of whose 20 tracks survive--"Wendy," "Catch a Wave," we salute you ("Fun, Fun, Fun," "Surfer Girl").

after the hype has cleared, this--their inalienable right to juvenilia, historical context, and live ones where you can hear the words ("Money [That's What I Want]," "Can't Buy Me Love," "Shout," "Moonlight Bay")
One alleged Bay Area belly dancer plus two Bay Area lower-case gypsies dub up Middle Eastern beats--and tunes--they play themselves ("Beauty Beats," "Roustabouts [Bassnectar Remix]").
cute but deadly, pop but not, fussy but that can change ("I've Come for My Award," "I Think the Answer's Yes")
too pissed for their own good ("Prettiest Eyes," "Mini-Correct")
Is that the world ending in his rearview mirror, or just his career? ("Rental Car," "Earthquake Weather," "Quï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿").
rich junkie's gimlet-voiced lament ("Junkie Girl," "Down in the Bottom")
"African gospel" indigenous-charismatic style, which sounds nothing like Western hymnody and everything like Nigeria ("Iba Re Eledumare," "Jesus, I Love You")
Hip-hop plus salsa plus r&b plus more r&b equals pure reggae crossover ("Analyze This," "Girls Dem Sugar").

album: Bel Canto: The Best of the Genidia Years
comment: 1982-'87 versions of Rochereau's Afrisa International accommodate his wife's sweet, small soprano ("Nazali Mwasi," "Contre Ma Volonte").
Slightly sketchy ZZ Top fan unlooses her folkie chains ("Outside the Bars," "The Texas Aggies Win Again").

Vocally, "Born Under a Bad Sign"'s cowriter is barely diminished as he pushes 80, and with help from John Leventhal his new songs are solid, but he was never a star because that voice was never a show stopper, which may explain its longevity ("More Rooms," "People Want to Go Home")
busy busy busy ("Bentley's Gonna Sort You Out!" "Whoosh")
Still lost in sound, but oriented enough here to make tunes out of it ("The Hard One," "Round the Bend").

No matter how hooky your g-g-b-d pop, no matter how unchauvinistic your female-with-male-support setup, it gives the wrong impression to call your best song "You Wouldn't Like Me" ("You Wouldn't Like Me," "Happy Unhappy")
The more she wonders how to voice her confusion, the louder the band fills the vacuum ("Mossie ['Previously Unreleased' by Moss]," "Souls Travel").
