One of our finer big-guitar bands--and without a hint of macho, including the "ironic" kind in which cred-hungry young horndogs camouflage their ignorance of history ("Mayhem," "D.I.Y.")
Billy Eckstine masterminds an all-star combo and nobody shows off, especially Billy ("Speak Low," "Satin Doll")
One keeper satire, one displaced outburst and one minor threat, all declared too violent for full-length by bad ex-teens' megacorp ("Becky").

album: You Come and Go Like a Pop Song
comment: Thelonious Monster's feckless leader explains what happened to his teeth ("Cereal Song," "Boy at a Bus Stop").
More funny than smart, meaning too cornball to truly kick Montgomery Gentry's ass ("Rolling [The Ballad of Big & Rich]," "Kick My Ass")
Endless pride, solid beats, a key credo, and a few hooks ("Gumpshun," "They Got Us," "Children of the World")

His generic superstar dreams as over as his Def Jam deal, he's free to make the most of the friendly drawl, good heart, and garden-variety ambition we went for to begin with ("Bury Me in Gold," "Big Bank")
Henry Mancini as guitar-bass-drums, which undercuts the showbiz and programmatic in his noir ("Just Plain Scared," "Crooked")
Now guitarist Steve Ulrich's band solely, with Tamir Muskat's drums missed, so it's to the leader's credit that he's kept the atmospherics spooky and compelling ("Unswerving," "Human Sacrifice")
fastest mouth in the East ("Still Not a Player," "Beware," "Super Lyrical" )
Radio City, loose and in person ("O My Soul")
At 75, reformed National Merit Scholar and University of Chicago physics major keeps on rolling like it ain't no thing ("Keep On Rollin'," "100 Years of Blues," "That's What I'm Talkin' About")
Everyrapper as Everynerd--his manageable tribulations, his modest progress, his magniloquent doody jokes ("T.S.R. [Toilet Stool Rap]," "Busy Doin' Nothing")
Divinely chosen leader of an all-girl horn orchestra ("Declare Independence," "Earth Intruders").

Available in five distinct physical configurations (collect them all!), the review version being CD 1/DVD 1, which showcase her electro-march mode emphasizing its most recent manifestation and indicate without conveying the ritual reach of her 2007 tour, respectively ("Army of Me," "Pluto").
makes writing short catchy postpunk songs seem so easy--maybe too easy, considering how hard the longer ones come ("Velvety," "Whiskey in Your Shoes")
Words of Wisdom from Gift of Gab ("Sky Is Falling," "Release")
The cleansing power of a big fat gloomy wartime drone ("The First Vietnamese War," "Manipulation").
What all pop might be--so much brighter and kinder than it is ("Pump It," "Don't Phunk With My Heart").
not Jimi yet, but fast approaching Stevie Ray ("She Said, She Said," "I'll Be Your Man")
Smart, loud, vocally nondescript pop savant patches together a song cycle wiser about ordinary relationships than you'd figure ("Don't Take the Money," "Let's Get Married")
an around-the-way girl's recipe for happiness ("Mary Jane," "I'm Goin' Down")
Plainspoken, low-drama, midtempo love vows, with attempted glamour relegated to the cover shoot ("Tonight," "I Am").
Mature enough to understand how vulnerable youth is, but not how grueling maturity is ("Feeling This," "Go").

Bullied ambisexual child weaves adult aural tapestry about black depression that's more pleasing in its overall affect than its lyrical-to-meandering musical specifics ("Nappy Wonder," "Charcoal Baby")
Halfway there, it sits down in the middle of the road and won't budge ("Tender," "B.L.U.R.E.M.I.").
insufficiently scientific ("Love's Gonna Getcha [Material Love]," "100 Guns")
live fantasias and self-indulgences ("Medley: Slow Down/Bony Maronie/Knock on Wood/I Heard It Through the Grapevine/Classified," "Medley: Tico Tico/Papa Was a Rascal")
Ambient musique concrï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½te out of acoustic instru"Tokyo," "The Future, Wouldn't That Be Nice?")
roadies' band, blunter, rockinger, and more realistic than their bosses in Uncle Tupelo would stoop to ("Kerosene," "Got What I Wanted")

honky-tonk romance, laborious dirge, and caffeinated double-time the quality outtakes you'd expect, dining-car praise song and Chattanooga chantey the lost oddities you'd hope ("Dinner Train to Dutchtown," "Coffee Monkey")
Bitchin rock move, but any band that boasts about not using a calculator cares less about history than it believes ("Gotta Get Up," "Headed for the Ditch").
"The long way isn't the wrong way," insists a driving record that includes one about taking the bus ("Kid Next Door," "Nothin' But a Driver").
Splitting the difference between jazz-rock and rock-jazz ("Electric Ladyland," "Who Knows/ Talkin' Bout My Baby").

album: The Best of the Box Tops: Soul Deep
comment: Alex Chilton's first vehicle went deeper than "The Letter" and "Cry Like a Baby," but I won't fib about how deep until "You Keep Me Hangin' On" makes CD ("I Met Her in Church," "Choo Choo Train").
watch out America--polite four-part harmonizers are coming to fuck your daughters ("U Know," "I'll Make Love to You")
Funk lite to improve the race ("Probable Cause," "Let's Dance").
adolescent petulance, tingling clits, no bass player ("Throway," "No You Don't")
McEnroe All-Stars trade EP cameos ("Breakfast All Day," "No Other MC").
Indie-rock as borderless utopian collective, kind of like Yo La Tengo with no heads instead of two-plus-one ("Swimmers," "Fire Eye'd Boy").

artist: Broken Social Scene Presents Kevin Drew
comment: Human Being Collective instructs Yanks in alt-rock soundscaping, knowwhutI'mehing? ("F----- Up Kid," "Backed Out on the . . .").
Four songs about sampling and not all that much food ("Mr. Songwriter," "Amuse Bouche")
Rocking the self-conscious party ("Lookin' at Me Sideways," "Uncle Sam Goddamn").
The cadences and dope tales too pat, the joys of fressing generics and jacking sunglasses far from it ("Thank God," "Cartier," "Guitar Solo")
"No apologies/For the misogyny," although students of the class system and serious cunnilingus fans might forgive him anyway ("Scrap or Die," "I Will")
If bomb-ass pussy could talk ("Hot Spot," "My Life").
all the jams you need and more ("Ain't It Funky Now, Pts. 1 & 2," "Come On in the House")
tempos up a notch, vocal pitch down a notch, he puts out like he has something to prove ("It's a Man's World," "Make It Funky")
r&b plays house, playa-style ("Fingerpointing," "Blackout")
U.K. soul retro without angst, substance abuse, melanin envy or even much romanticism--her songs are too peppy, and too poppy, as may well be her life ("Quick Fix," "Shark in the Water").
That's New Zealander Jonathan Bree, not Jonathan Richman, and his sweetie pie Heather-not-Katherine Mansfield ("Mars Love Venus," "Beautiful Militant").
Canadian trumpeter meets Cuban pianist for decent enough jazz and musical tales of Marranos, Roma and Sephardim ("Freylekhs Tumbao," "Lailadance").
The yoked disconnect of the rapper's hyperarticulate monotone and his female helpmeets' sweet hooks mirror the broken marriage he obsesses on ("Super Pretty Naughty," "Je T'Aime Mon Amour")
Like Uncle Neil says, "It's all one song--except for that flamenco thing" ("Conventional Wisdom," "Mess With Time").

album: That Depends on What You Know: The Sirens Return: Keep It Real 'Til It Flatlines
comment: atmosphere gathers fitfully into song (and rap), then disperses beautifully ("[Bas] Kiss," "Two Bass Blipsch")

album: All You Zombies Dig the Luminosity
comment: Greg Tate's permanent floating black-bohemian-nationalist big band speaks its truths to power and its beauties to the grays ("The Charmer," "Yung Black & Vague," "Black Fros Black Gold")

album: Black Sex Yall Liberation & Bloody Random Violets
comment: wish Tate edited his music like he edits his copy (which doesn't mean perfectly, believe me) ("Funky Rich Medina," "No Direction Home I").

artist: Charlie Burton and the Texas Twelve Steppers
comment: "She's the sugar in my gastank" and other funny lines ("Baby Let's Play God," "Livin' on Borrowed Time [Livin' on Borrowed Money]")
"The musings of a winded fact-checker"--attempting, with some success, to escape the prison house of self ("Less Yes's, More No's," "Casting Agents and Cowgirls").
sometimes I wish their lyrics crunched and played like their guitars, and sometimes I wish their guitars crunched and played ("For Kay," "Huh Huh Hear")
They love pussy and all it implies ("Send Me You," "Make Yr Life")
love life much smoother, music summat ("Totally From the Heart," "Point of No Return")
Looking for the same new love with the same new tunes ("Thunder of Hearts," "Why Compromise?").

Busy beaver Zach Hill and a guitarist 10 times as obscure make some, what else, noise, only this time--what? can't hear ya--it congeals even as it flies apart ("Cold Reading," "Click on That [Smash the Plastic Death]".
raw, sweet, and gawky--too bad Neil himself didn't play guitar ("Did You Hear What She Said?" "Many Splintered Thing")
MTV cheerleaders make art-punk as angular as they look and angry as they feel ("Bum Leg," "Suck")
Brave indie-pop girl lilts at windbags ("Suspended From Class," "Knee Deep at the NPL")

album: Let's Get Out of This Country
comment: Forever indie, and here's how you can tell--too often they think nudge when they need a knockout ("Lloyd, I'm Ready to Be Heartbroken," "Let's Get Out of This Country").
shameless ripoffs to be proud of ("Things That Make You Go Hmmmm . . . ," "Here We Go, Let's Rock & Roll")
He talks too much about how good he is only because nobody else will--and he is, damn it, he is ("Pine Comb Poem," "Golden Terra of Rap")
love that medicine-show rag, appreciate the rest ("Going to Germany," "Madison Street Rag," "Bring It With You When You Come")
One samba record with the warm soul, melodic grace and atmospheric intelligence claimed for all of them ("The Bridge," "Pena de Mim").
at Def Jam, where he strove to combine hard, conscious, and profitable ("Raggy Road," "Wings of the Morning")
he wants God in your life--or does he really mean Gods? ("Love Is the Message," "Super Model")
Serious by Carney's standards, which means teaching '40s honker Big Jay McNeely "Futuristic Rhythm," a Fields-McHugh song written in 1929 ("Backtrackin'," "Blow Big Ralph [aka Blow Big Jay]").

Three actual "Negroes" reconstitute "genuine" African-American fiddle band--sprightly and lyrical and a trifle polite, as perforce such bands must be ("Your Baby Ain't Sweet Like Mine," "Trouble in Your Mind").
One difference from Gram & Emmylou is they both write the songs ("Two Different Things," "Please Break My Heart").
Country music as saying what you mean--or trying to, which is just as good, right? ("Thrice All American," "South Tacoma Way").
glad she took Manhattan, wish her songwriting had stood in Nashville ("September When It Comes," "I'll Change for You")
Serengeti and Beatmaster Open Mike Eagle rap in character from a cross-class scenario so detailed you don't always know who's rapping as who--which is interesting ("Lemons," "Typecast")

album: Cee-Lo Green and the Perfect Imperfections
comment: not only does he sing, he transcends good-versus-evil! ("Live [Right Now]," "Southern Love")

Disruptive, radical, all that good stuff, Marc Ribot-Shahzad Ismaily-Ches Smith jams are nonethless strongest at their most ideological ("Fuck La Migra," "Pennsylvania 6 6666," "Muslim Jewish Resistance")
In New South Wales as in Nashville, heart tuggers are hard to get right ("Pony," "Guilty as Sin").
Digable Planet as a nicer Basehead, with a healthy injection of Gary Numan ("What Im Talking," "A Street Gospel")

album: The Best of Chic: Dance, Dance, Dance
comment: too much disco, not enough discord ("My Feet Keep Dancing")
Cheerful Afropop absolutely, Zimbabwean-Congolese get it, pan-Zambian if you say so, rebel lyricist over my head ("Jombo," "Mailesi")
Bedroom soul, as in where this homespun illbient funk is made--the lov's made in the mind of the funkateer ("Give Me," "Owl")
recorded performance art--rock hipster misprises classic pop as acoustic folk ("My Baby Just Cares for Me," "Time After Time")
healing don't make humming, especially on a thumb piano ("Huya Uzoona," "Mudzimu Dzoka").
a national treasure--in a nation ransacked? ("Ndabaiwa," "Uchiseka")
Great move to bring Solange in midway through, only she immediately steps to the front of the personality parade ("When the Night Falls," "Night by Night")
Tub as platform, tub as cornucopia, tub as slop bucket ("Tubthumping," "Amnesia").
Master craftsman of high good-old-boy convention ("Before She Does," "What I Almost Was").
He should never try to belt a lyric out of the park again ("Kill a Word," "Mr. Misunderstood")
Too atmospheric? naturalistic? programmatic? somewhere in there ("Gorilla," "Waterfalls")
"I'd like to hear 'Wooly Bully,' by Sam the Sham and the Pharoahs--yes, not Sham 69, but Sam the Sham" ("Capital Radio," "Know Your Rights").
Arena-rock focused them punker than hit-making did ("Rock the Casbah," "Clampdown").
Began crude and ended tired like most mortals, but for two-thirds of these two CDs, they were dronin'! ("Beatnik," "Two Fat Sisters (Live)").
hard to maintain that rock and roll edge when you've fallen in love with a baby ("All Green," "Action")
fun with indie-rock, good--only their idea of fun is so inarticulate ("T.K.," "C.Q.")
Beats come easier than songs, which suits Tjinder Singh's work ethic fine ("People Power in the Disco Hour," "G.T. Road").

artist: George Clinton & the P-Funk All Stars
comment: authenticated gangsta grooves for the sample factory ("If Anybody Gets Funked Up [It's Gonna Be You]," "Funky Kind [Gonna Knock It Down]")

artist: George Clinton & the P-Funk All Stars
comment: more funky than fresh, their best live one withal ("Flashlight," "Cosmic Slop")
When they say, "Like the new Death Row," I think, "Just what we needed" (even though I know they're lying) ("Hate It or Love It," "Play Your Part").
Further adventures in the aesthetic of the tantrum ("I'm Not Part of Me," "Now Hear In")
The good tracks keep on coming, but the irresistible ones total, well, one ("Blow Up," "Farewell")

album: Tha Funk Capital of the World
comment: Five historic P-Funk tracks fronted by Cornel West, Samuel L. Jackson, Jimi Hendrix, Al Sharpton, and a panoply of old A-game rappers followed by 11 well-meaning Bootsy tracks distinguished by cameos from Buckethead and, wouldn't you know it, George Clinton ("After These Messages," "Hip Hop @ Funk U")
Chasing drugs under the stars, staring at the ground through the hole in his shoe ("Tonight on the WB," "Invisible Drugs").
Few of the best moments belong to the main attraction, who's not as wise as they tell him he is ("It's Your World [Part 1 & 2]," "The Food [Live]").
Still on a major label, he's damn well gonna act it ("Raw [How You Like It]," "The Believer")
Lee Perry's falsetto-and-tenor duo revived for our dubwise era ("Row Fisherman," "Children Crying")
The return of polycultural prophet Kip Hanrahan, starring Ishmael Reed and some funky jazzmen ("In War Such Things Happen," "Bad Mouth").
The musical tail of a cat whose best friend is a leftist mouse--OK, I'll bite ("Red Cat Till I Die," "Cat and Mouse").

Soundtrack to the nifty book of linked short stories this version includes, which is more entertaining than the songs because the characters aren't all musicians ("Pink-O Boogie," "Ridin' With the Blues").
Accounting B.A. accounted a Loretta Lynn for our time by no less an assessor than Nanci Griffith and not without reason! ("Sunday Morning," "Sometimes It Takes Balls to Be a Woman").
the confessions of everygangsta swallow the boasts ("County Line," "Mama I'm in Love With a Gangsta," "In Da Closet")
a much safer, rather shallower, somewhat catchier hook collection than Gangsta's Paradise ("County Line," "Aw Here It Goes [Theme From Kenan & Kel]")
The title refers to her age, which she's come of ("Can't Let Go," "Somebody Else's Jesus")
Think Macy Gray with less voice and no corny side, which she needs more than the voice now that she has some songs ("Woke Up White," "30th Birthday").
Filthy and whimsical, a strange combo anywhere, is even stranger in a Brooklyn weirdo who pretends to sing country music--and does, pretty much ("Life of a Bear," "Shaved [Like a Razor]")
The Impostors sound even more pissed off than Elvis, who seems less embittered as a result ("Button My Lip," "There's a Story in Your Voice").
sings Burt's chewy music lots better than Burt, not to mention Hal, who proves a healthy influence on his poesy ("Such Unlikely Lovers," "The Long Division")
Costello sings better than Toussaint, Toussaint exposes Steve Nieve as a klutz ("On Your Way Down," "International Echo").
Rocking on the edge of everything for 30 years, and how many margin mavens know his name? ("I'm Wild," "More Than Enough").
pushing 50, on the road, and "afraid to let this one go" ("No One Special," "Baby's Arms")
"Real" bluesman or not, he writes subtler songs than blues boosters can hear ("Up in the Sky," "Survivor").
"I wanna see you burn all the way down/I wanna see your ashes all over the ground" ("My Last Regret," "Twenty").
picking 'em better than he writes 'em ("Twenty-Five Forty-One," "The `In' Crowd," "Theme From `Flaregun'")
From that spiritual place where you conclude that since life doesn't resolve neatly, neither should songs ("Passing Through," "Right on Time").
A punky little Brit-pop album with its advertised hooks in place for once, leaving us free to ponder how much its romantic self-examinations are worth ("I'm a Realist," "Major's Titling Victory").
Commercial instincts undimmed, he does Americana AC confessionally, thinking hard all the while ("Earthbound," "Preachin' to the Choir").
One more pissed-off patriot heard from ("The Obscenity Prayer [Give It to Me]," "Don't Get Me Started").
67-year-old proves he's still growing in wisdom, especially when he trots out the biographical fallacy ("Nashville 1972," "It Ain't Over Yet")
Real Brazilian girls admire B-52's (hmm) and Chicks on Speed (uh-oh) ("Patins," "Music Is My Hot, Hot Sex").
almost a great pop marriage--ardent, troubled, in love with itself ("Make You Mine," "That Is That," "I Wish I Was")

Inciting to riot up front, awestruck by lust at closing time, they're most convincing mourning their people's losses and nailing a 16 for Muddy Waters ("Gone," "Any Way the Wind Blows," "Mr. Morganfield and Ms. Waters")
Shows impressive expertise in both sex and the city but devises better hooks for the one that's more fun ("Garfield," "A.U.T.I.S.M.")
Veteran L.A. DJ keys two 20-minute soul mixes to Ethiopian beats, which soon prove the main attraction ("East Side")
MF Doom adds not quite decisive comedy/insanity/gravitas to Deck/7L/Esoteric's not quite supergroup ("Badness of Madness," "MF Czar," "Captain Brunch")
Driving, melodic, engaged, humane, disillusioned v-k-g-b-d-trumpet from El Paso, which emerges as one of the cities David Byrne ended up living in ("We Hungry," "Orange & Black")
sound punk, structures art-rock, violin bi ("Copsucker," "Idaho")

88-year-old auteur of the 1973 LP I Hate the Capitalist System sings dirty blues by L. Cohen and M. Minnie, enlists M. Allison in her battle with neuron loss, and sneaks in a 52-year-old anti-nuclear power song ("I'm Sellin' My Porkchops," "Slow," "My Brain")
it's the rhythm not the song, but the singer helps ("Rewind," "Booty Man")
Three high school seniors from Mississippi show a bossa-tinged mastery of the three-minute pop song that has Zach Condon counting his gray hairs ("Friend Request," "50's Film").
"Ain't no bluesman, I'm the bluesman's son/But I'll sing this song until my daddy comes" ("Ain't No Bluesman," "Let Me Stay Awhile").
country blues in the spirit of friendship, like John Hurt did it ("Good Liquor," "I Don't Know")
in the predawn of Bitches Brew, Wayne Shorter plays jazz, Chick Corea plays fusion, and Miles Davis plays trumpet ("Miles Runs the Voodoo Down," "It's About That Time/The Theme")
Four uncommonly brief double-funked remixes add up to collector's curio ("Freedom Jazz Dance [Evolution of the Groove]," "It's About That Time").

album: Live in Europe 1969: The Bootleg Series Vol. 2
comment: There are probably 30-40 Miles albums I'd rather play, but not with Shorter blatting quite so much, or Corea providing a tolerable dose of the fusion I'll come to hate ("Bitches Brew," "Directions" [7.25/69])
Sun Ra guitarist organizes free-improv pan-Afrobeat ("I'm Not Scared," "Send-Return").
Crime pays--better than capitalism, anyway ("Hell Yeah [Pimp the System] [Remix Featuring Jay-Z]," "Fucked Up")
signs of postundergraduate life ("Steadier Footing," "Coney Island")
Death-metal hip-hop for El-P fans who secretly wish the Insane Clown Posse wasn't so dumb ("Blood Creepin," "Klink")
Atmospheric rapper conveys advanced thought and warm feelings with pliant voice, enveloping beats, and lyrics that have their sharper moments ("Studio Backpack Rap," "Collapse," "Shawshank")
The conceptual growing pains of a good idea for a band, English lyrics included ("Habesha," "Ambessel")
New Age disco in the musical biosphere of Bootsy, Bernie, Catfish, and the Horny Horns ("Rubber Lover," "Electric Shock")
Brooklyn's own Asylum Modal Beat Farmers, countrier than I See Hawks in L.A. and Spike Jones put together ("Get What's Coming to You," "Thin Air").
if the Femmes had never gotten famous . . . ("Bend Down Low," "So Happy Together")
studio obscurantism as street credibility ("Millie Pulled a Pistol on Santa," "Fanatic of the B Word," "Keepin' the Faith")

Always aiming sweet and never straying saccharine, natural-born Willy Vlautin heroine Amy Boone sings her continuing pain and occasional solace ("Calling In," "Colfax Avenue," "Wichita Ain't So Far Away")
Self-made sad girl celebrates self-caricaturing sex appeal of self-fulfilling bad love. ("Cruel World," "Ultraviolence")
Languid self-expressions of considerable theoretical interest, just like the Lana Del Rey character's sexual proclivities used to be ("When the World Was at War We Kept Dancing," "13 Beaches")
Sounded hot, acted cold, ran out of riffs (or was it interest?) ("Mind Your Own Business," "Now That You've Gone").

album: I Wish My Brother George Was Here
comment: funkentelechy vs. hoodz and Hammer ("The Wacky World of Rapid Transit," "Mistadobalina")

For three highly listenable CDs--incorporating the previously download-only Automatik Statik and Funk Man--impeccable rapper's electro beats don't stop and only occasionally rise above ("Calculate," "Dzl Funk," "Fit Like a Glove")
Definitely not as dumb as he pretends to think he is ("Breathing," "It Girl")
protesting too much, with a gusto that won't be denied ("Man and Wife, the Latter [Damaged Goods]," "Hole in One")
Languid Houston rapper makes love and jokes out of how hard meaning no harm can be ("Briarpatch," "What?").
Underrecorded Malian guitarist's final album goes long on balafon and doesn't corral the singers he deserves ("Soubagaya," "Moussolankolo")
Hews so close to girl-of-Wassoulou verities she's lucky her musicians don't ("Na," "Aye Yafama").

Whose songs do you think stick out when the Deer Tick guy convenes yet another roots-rock supergroup with the Black Lips guy and the Dead Confederate guy? ("Christmas in a Chinese Restaurant," "Gimme a Beer")
Hyperactive selection from mbalax thirtysomething's Senegal-only cassettes, which apparently peaked songwise in 1996 ("Koleurï¿½ï¿½ï¿½" "Biri Biri," "Withiaxou").
distracted by piano, accordion, even horns from her lithe sound, self-starting folk-punk remains a tough broad who aims to figure it all out ("The Diner," "Letter to a John," "Face Up and Sing")
you can wear out the hard and the brother-brother-brother, but you can't wear out the cosmic slop ("The Dflo Shuffle," "Kiss You Back")
imparts new flavor, if not flava, to the word "lubricious" ("Who Got the Gravy?" "Wind Me Up," "The Odd Couple")
More about moments than flow, which is strange when you think about it ("Workinonit," "Lightworks").
difficult love, endless sufferation, sweet-souled music ("On the Road Again," "One Step Forward," "Feed the Fire").
best-of EP masquerading as singles comp, complete with fucked-up Frampton cover ("Just Like Heaven," "Little Fury Things")
Carving out a punk alternative after the collapse of Albion's dream ("The Gentry Cove," "If You Love a Woman").

Melodies you want to hear again for their shapes and harmonies alone, lyrics of discernible emotional import that include the cheerful verbal preset "that doesn't make any sense what you just said" ("Maybe That Was It," "Dance for You")
giving their displacements a flow ("Come Home," "Ellen & Ben")
Blood lust meets death wish where punk meets metal ("The Gallow Is God," "Hall of Mirrors").
Unlike three virgins ("Goodbye Earl," "Sin Wagon," "Ready To Run").
Fick and foughtful, finally ("Sirens," "Hard Back [Industry]").

Hardly unprecedented I carp, just Woodentops with bottom say I, only then I discover that I no longer have my Woodentops albums, and wonder whether anybody else does either, and what that means for these much-bruited newcomers ("Default," "Love's Dart")
"mangue electronica" from Recife, so retro-nuevo his (yes, his) band (yes, band) includes ska trombone and a 400-year-old Lusofiddle ("A Danï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿" "Adorela")
He loves the studio, which earns it, and his young-money peeps, who don't ("Still Rise," "Magic").

album: The Champions: The North Meets the South
comment: Classic mixtape slams so hard even Fat Joe rides like a playa (Remy Ma & Razah, "One and Only [My Boo]"; Papoose, Remy Ma & Hell Rell, "The Hardest Out").
just keeps on go going ("Let Me Clear My Throat," "Let Me Clear My Throat [Old School Reunion Remix '96]")
German collagist claims Sgt. Pepper, provides magical mystery tour ("Marilyn Whirlwind," "Homesick")
G-funk, hold the G-i.e., "Things I used to do/I don't do no more" ("Do Whutcha Want," "Pitch In Ona Party").
Either the sonic testament of the master of the Chicago dance movement called footwork or a surprisingly fun set of thick 808 beats with vocal accoutrements ("Feelin," "Only One")

Variety-wise, the new and-it-don't-stop is more house than hip-hop--the beats do repeat (DJ Rekha and Sunil Sehgal featuring Bikram Singh and Wyclef Jean, "Basement Bangra Anthem"; Tigerstyle featuring Amar Arshi, "Aaja Nachiye Boliyan Paiye").
His best since The Private Press is a sound effects record by comparison, heavy on first-rate texture, rumble, and of course beats ("Nobody Speak," "The Mountain Will Fall," "Mambo")

album: The Amazing Adventures of DJ Yoda
comment: It's harder when you have to create the songs yourself, but Biz Markie and Tiny Tim help, as do the laugh lines ("Breakfast Cereal," "Tip-Toe").
Subtler, which for those of us who seek cheap thrills from our let's-call-it-techno seldom means better ("Magenta," "Snap, Crackle & Pop")

album: The Dr. John Anthology: Mos' Scocious
comment: takes his respectable period seriously ("Morgus the Magnificent," "Wash, Mama, Wash")
Afrocentricity with a middle-aged spread ("I've Never Been to Africa [And It's Your Fault]," "Appelle-Moi Noir")
Eat the theme up with your mouth Doom ("Hoecakes," "Kon Queso").

album: If You're Reading This It's Too Late
comment: So articulate, so intelligent, so (relatively) decent--so how come I perk up when Lil Wayne comes on with his pottymouth absurdities? ("Used To," "Legend")
West Indian daisy age from boogie-down Toronto ("Ludi," "My Definition of a Boombastic Jazz Style")

If this Chicago rapper-turning-singer was half as irresistible as I wish she was, there'd be more than one thing on her loosely plotted tale of trading Jamal in for Sean that's half as great as its great greatest hit ("Body," "Afford My Love")
Includes title song directed at a trust fund baby I personally am sorry they ever met ("A World of Hurt," "Goodbye").
Patterson Hood learns the hard way that great songs are never an inexhaustible resource ("Birthday Boy," "Eyes Like Glue").
the PBA meets the IRA and turns left--another punk precinct heard from ("Which Side Are You On?" "Caps and Bottles")
They'll never be the Pogues because they're not outright alcoholics, which bodes well for their class analysis ("Tomorrow's Industry," "Never Forget").
Ethiopian with dub flavor rather than vice versa, and believe it: Dubulah knows his enjira ("Azmari Dub," "Ambassel").
Pretty darn good Pretenders ("Wasted Away," "In My Head")
Mr. Smarty Pants mocks meritocracy and enjoys his body ("Jack Shit George," "Geraldine").
December 1990-bloody lively for an oldies reunion ("Billericay Dickie," "Blockheads").

album: Tell Tale Signs: Rare and Unreleased 1989-2006
comment: Out of 29 tracks, not counting the dozen in a deluxe edition that'll run you another hundred smackers, I count two or three stunners, eight or nine keepers, many outtakes, and a few live versions and movie songs ("High Water [For Charley Patton]," "Series of Dreams").
Dark secrets of the counterculture revealed--sexism! greed! hooks! ("San Berdoo Sunburn," "Kiss the Devil").
demands its own Grammy category: Best Use of Outlaw Pathology in a Roots-Rock Setting ("South Nashville Blues," "CCKMP," "More Than I Can Do")
Living-room loserdom at a very peak of depressive tunefulness ("Druglife," "What Does T.S. Eliot Know About You?").
Ethnotechno soundscape, sometimes a shade too comfortable or anonymous, sometimes just eerie enough ("In This Drum a Secret," "Bodhichitta Dub").

album: I Have Fun Everywhere I Go
artist: Mike Edison and the Rocket Train Delta Science Arkestra
comment: Ex-Screw and High Times editor bellows yock-strewn war stories over punk boogie ("Pornography, Part I," "Ozzy, High Times, and Me").

album: The Very Best of Eek-a-Mouse Vol. 2
comment: approximating the strangeness of the world with falsettos high and low, instrumental nonsense syllables, and always the same slow skank ("Border Patrol," "The Mouse and the Man")
Dope jokes offensive and funny, pimp jokes offensive and stupid (retain pejorative correct spelling please) ("Gouda," "Yay Area," "They Might Be Taping").
Dance-rock for an "evil generation"--their own, if you can believe them ("Rock and Roll Evacuation," "Jimmy Carter").
postpomo guitar heroes--not quite smart enough to be slow ("Makin' Like a Rug," "That's the Point")
Pitch-perfect, undiluted by irony, Welshmen re-create the folk-pop '60s, and if the Hollies sometimes made better albums, the Association never did ("Aren't You Grand," "Don't Worry Marie").
hardcore to the booty, slimfast to the brain ("Work It," "Bring the Pain")
No more Missy Nice Girl ("Busa Rhyme," "Smooth Chick").
a little too worried about her weight ("Lick Shots," "Get Ur Freak On")
Loathing this fearsome gets kitschy fast unless it cops to caricature or abjures surreal overstatment--which latter his least austere album does sometimes ("The Jig Is Up," "Drones Over Bklyn")
Live leavings of a helluva bar band ("Faith Healer," "Time Has Come Today").

album: The Drought Is Over Part Six
comment: Beats, rhymes and cameos classier than your average Wayne mixtape, drops ridiculous ("Best Thing Yet," "Put Me in the Game," "Shootout").
two discs of digitalizations to die for, one of songs on life support ("Seven Deadly Finns," "The Lion Sleeps Tonight (Wimoweh)")
three years after the audition, they still don't cohere enough to let the songs quit ("My Lovin' [You're Never Gonna Get It]," "Giving Him Something He Can Feel," "Free Your Mind")
She knows who her friends are, and they'll stay her friends even if she never overtakes Rihanna ("American Boy," "Wait a Minute [Just a Touch]").
meaning of title: public property ("Dounya," "Thiapathioly")
irony-pop gone garage-rock--hooky whether it steamrolls, trudges, or whines ("Breakfast," "Bed-In")
Kenyan-American quartet's inner jam band generates discernible jam ("Gimakiny Akia," "Piny Yore Yore").
Mozambican not South African--guitar lilt soukous or chimurenga or samba or Larry Carlton, soul Rio-urbane not Soweto-muscular ("Samukhela," "Oh Mama")
Violins loud like horns ("Bailando con Otro," "La Mano en el Arazï¿½").
virtuoso time warp--as gorgeous and shallow as Aja ("Teahouse on the Tracks," "Trans-Island Skyway")
a ravaged old hippie's bitterest laments ("Vagabond Ways," "Incarceration of a Flower Child")
Still plumbing love's impossibilities as death nears and the Nazis come nearer than that ("They Come at Night," "In My Own Particular Way")
but it's really great shit ("Land of Sunshine," "Midlife Crisis," "Midnight Cowboy")
the reassuringly literate clatter of avant-garde background rock--two hours of it ("No Bulbs," "Kurious Oranj [Live]")
great original sound, one hell of a cover band ("Lost in Music," "I'm Going to Spain")
Alt-rock won't die till they ban Pignose amps in Mark E.'s senior residence, but that doesn't mean he'll put this much into it ("F-'Oldin' Money," "Touch Sensitive").
"I hate the country sound so much/I hate the country folk so much" ("Boxoctosis," "Contraflow")
Expatriate Afrobeat meets devotional Gnawa in la belle France, climaxing with a concert-climaxing tour de force worthy of the Allman Brothers themselves ("Wouarri," "Kelen")

Unflinchingly specific and analytic protest blues-rock counts on musical torque it doesn't get from a soggy hummed groan that's half misprised field holler and half godless gospel rip ("Working Poor," "Rant Rushmore")

album: You've Come a Long Way, Baby
comment: proving what all pop pros know--that obvious is harder than subtle ("The Rockafeller Skank," "In Heaven")
The third disc will half convince you he didn't follow one decade of visionary shtick with two of waiting to meet Bill Murray ("Will You Love Me Tomorrow," "Kiss and Tell").
O.P.G.--Original Postpunk Glaswegians indulge unnatural sense of rhythm ("Meat Whiplash," "Discord").

Name's Ursula Knudson, "opera-trained," is in fact married, to a Gypsy-style violinist named Martinez, they make love and Roma music together, the latter with their friends Smolens and Stijepovic ("Woman in Sin," "Espagnolette").
the good-versus-evil of dreams ("Fight Test," "Do You Realize??")
Twentysomethings foresee, rue, and encapsulate in tightly wound pop-rock a constrained, moderately diverting life of futile, moderately comfortable survival ("Go," "XYZ")
Steady-state DJ undulates a world of sound in the world's direction ("Comet Course," "Golden Diva").

Dully danceable Britpoppers sound better cherry-picking other people's weirdness than showcasing their own competence (Condry Ziqubu, "Confusion [Ma Afrika]"; Marshall Jefferson Vs. Noosa Head, "Mushrooms [Justin Martin Remix]"; Tony Allen, "Kilode [Carl Craig Remix]")
"Ben Folds adds music and melody to Nick Hornby's words," which are so much better than Ben Folds's words, but tend cute and pat even so ("Levi Johnston's Blues," "Belinda")
the spirit is strong but the identity is weak ("This Is a Call," "Big Me")
singer-songwriter ("Baby Stones," "Is This What You Call Change")
Half live and half sampled, go go evolves, making everything funky ("The Spirit of '75," "Papa Was Stoned").
Young enough to only work when they need the money, a musical tradition worth fighting for ("Michael," "Jacqueline").
why George Shearing fans hated rock 'n' roll, and other '50s foibles ("The Great Pretender," "Sh-Boom," "Banana Boat [Day-O]," "I've Got You Under My Skin")
the simple punk songs I credit to Kim Gordon, the simplistic punk noisefests I blame on Julia Cafritz ("Top 40," "Teenie Weenie Boppie")

album: The Loneliest Man I Ever Met
comment: Sings as bad as ever on this covers album from nowhere, aging well anyway ("My Shit's Fucked Up," "A Nightingale Sang In Berkeley Square")
Earnest Glasgow brother band share their pain and add a song to the casual-sex canon ("Keep Yourself Warm," "My Backwards Walk").
Buenos Aires freakstylers claim cumbia and baile, retain temperate-zone electrocool ("Mueve La Cuchi," "Los Originarios")

Somebody marry this winsome sad sack, whose increasingly plausible rhymes now include open-ibuprofen, gauche-precocious-neurosis, salad on the tennis court-valid passport, speckled melanin-freckled up your skin, and the very sexy errands-gerunds ("Visit Me," "27 Dollars")
For synthy no-lyrics psych-dance, pretty rocky--pretty funny, too ("Surf Solar," "Rough Steez").

The acerbic Fulks tailors his material to the "sunny, high-humored attitude" of Jerry Lee's little sister, who was way more fun acerbic herself on 1991's alt-rock International Affair, not to mention 1969's consanguineous Together ("Round Too Long," "Till Death," "Memphis Never Falls From Style")
Anxious seeker hires horns to tickle his playful side, also his female side. ("Body Was Made," "Lousy Connection")
Complete with guitar band and harmonica, throwback chronicles teenage wasteland and America the not so beautiful ("I Killed Myself but I Didn't Die," "Teenage Wasteland")
if Whale is Tricky without a dark side, Garbage is Whale without Tricky and depressed about it ("Queer," "Supervixen")
She doesn't drink anymore, she sings--remembering all too well what alcoholism was like ("I Drink," "Mercy Now").
Finally the influence reverses, providing Uncle Neil the chorus idea for his own 2006 album, only this one's about love in the desert or something ("Get to Leave," "That's How Things Get Done").
With the sand running out on his atmospheric alt-country, he shifts to cocktail piano--effortlessly, or so he makes it seem ("Terribly So," "Relevant")

album: Songs in the Key of W
comment: He calls, they respond; he loses and we get to make Dubya jokes, we lose and he gets to make First Amendment jokes ("War in Iraq," "Peeance Freeance")
Nine dead women, a stillborn baby girl, a male suicide, and whatever got thrown off the Tallahatchee Bridge ("Knoxville Girl," "Little Sadie")
Living off his past, but it's quite a past and a damned decent living ("In the Park," "Purified Thoughts")
One of them newfangled song-cycle sounding sorta things ("[well] Dusted [for the millennium]," "Temptation of Egg").
Tripartite autobiography that turns Howe Gelb's natural sprawl into a concept replete with strange yet sensible songs ("Texting Feist," "Eye Opening," "Transponder")

Maybe the songs about slavery top the songs about love because it's harder to oversing a song about slavery, especially one as honed as these are ("Julie," "At the Purchaser's Option," "Come Lover Come")
Sonic Youth as Poison from a Portland married-couple-plus-dynamite-drummer who heard another album in those tricks ("Sinking Ship," "OK This Is the Pops")

Don't let the "again" suck you in--of course he's more fluid and sapient than the Soundcloud upstarts, but they have things to tell the world that he can't ("Gentrification Song," "Freedom Form Flowing")
looks Muslim, raised Christian, sings international--in Amharic, with an avant-jazz accent ("Bale Washintu," "Kahn")
I've tried to find translations, really I have ("Chuckberry Fields Forever," "Volk, Volkswagen Blues").
trying to prove he's not trad, which we knew already ("Black Snake Moan," "Borderland")
mack beats bumped and grounded ("Pony," "Holler")
Actually, I liked how weird he is better when he was producing himself ("Gone Daddy Gone," "Go-Go Gadget Gospel").
Lesser title tracks have anchored lesser EPs than this prematurely deleted outtakes wrap-up ("Stills," "Baby's Just Waiting").
Very live BBC session plus odds and sods plus DVD worth seeing for more than its very very live climax ("Troubled Friends," "Ultimate").
Hmm--the two catchiest new songs by the now Brazil-based Eugene Hutz are the two with Latin titles ("Companjera," "Uma Menina Uma Cigana").
Down-and-out from inside out, quasi-Appalachian style ("No Help Coming," "Lord Knows We're Drinking")
Really the roots-rock-they mean it, man ("Whipping Piccadilly," "Love Is Better Than a Warm Trombone").
honest pop band presents its songs punk, and that makes some people so mad ("The Story of My Old Man," "Riot Girl")

album: Live at the Earl of Old Town
comment: Found great songs, wrote good ones, loved a laugh ("I Gotta Hand It to You," "When the Cubs Go Marching In").
Pop trip-hop as alternative reality, from fantasyland to apocalypse ("All Alone," "Dare").
Exceeding their emotional reach, musical grasp, and conceptual limitations whether softer or more elaborate ("Apollo Throwdown," "Bust Out Brigade")
Skills trump indirection on one disc of outtakes and another of collabs ("Nah'mean Nah'm Sayin," "My Angel Is You," "Power, Money & Influence").

Honorable alt-rap vet extracts long-awaited album from alt's most musical rapper, which despite many fine moments isn't focused by its silly concept and ends up longer on his raps than hers ("Waiting for the Moon," "Gold Purple Orange")
the good old days, circa Keith Godchaux ("Jam," "Going Down the Road Feeling Bad")

Old and on their way, they jam in the Fourth on July 7, 1989, with a miraculously or pharmaceutically pepped-up Jerry launching a searing "Iko Iko"-"Little Red Rooster"-"Ramble On Rose"-"Memphis Blues Again" sequence before receding into grotty but engaged desuetude ("Iko Iko," "Knockin' On Heaven's Door")

album: Near the Edge of the Penny Jar Spill
comment: Best when he trusts his sources more and his pick-up musicians less, you think--until Paul Cebar constructs a threnody from the linguistic shards of late-stage Alzheimer's ("Used to Say," "Six Snakes," "How Records Are Made")
tenor sanity ("The Cat")

album: Guitar Music From the Western Sahara
comment: World-traveling Sahrawi Hendrix fan preserves his music on homemade cassettes a mite too crude for the international market ("Eid For Dakhla," "Cheyla Ya Haiuune").
A legendary band recorded live--and in Gambia as anywhere else, studio recording can beef up your vocals and frame the rhythm players who do sometimes elevate your songs ("Tara," "Sanehmentereng")
New Zevons for a pomo world ("Trial Separation Blues," "One by One")
past 60 and feeling it, he's relaxing more and feeling that too ("Midnight Train," "Did Somebody Make a Fool Out of You")
Blues subpatriarch claims soul as his dominion ("I Put a Spell on You," "Ninety Nine and One Half").

In a farewell so posthumous electric bassist Steve Swallow replaces him on the three Carla Bley-composed tracks, the great humanitarian tells the planet he loves it so ("Time/Life," "Song for the Whales")
Leave Iraq and stay with your love ("Where's All the Freedom," "It Always Will Be").
fast ones fast, slow ones heartbreaking ("This Could Be the Night," "Always," "Magic Kingdom," "Everyone Knows")
Exulting "As Good Can Be" over the chords of "I Wanna Be Your Dog," which given how loyally he follows his wife around may not be such a bad match ("In Its Pull," "Our Love")

album: The Song He Was Listening to When He Died
comment: Even for a journo-musician he's getting too old to know more about music than love, but he's never been a quick study ("America," "The Song He Was Listening to When He Died").

album: Abdel Hadi Halo & the El Gusto Orchestra of Algiers
artist: Abdel Hadi Halo & the El Gusto Orchestra of Algiers
comment: Six guttural excursions in chaabi, where the bendir and derbouka sound folkloric to you and the piano and banjo sound Western to them ("Win Saadi," "Lalla Fatima").
de facto best-of cum fine how-de-doo to you and several hordes of Ani DiFranco fans ("Sugarfree," "7 Seas")
digging for the great elusive motherlode of American tragic deadpan ("Weightless Again," "The Woman Downstairs," "Cathedrals")
Holding the mysteries of death in this old land to a (temporary) draw ("The Bottomless Hole," "Gail With the Golden Hair").

In this unpoetically dark time, only the social realism that has never been their style of pessimism seems to truly . . . can I say spark them? they're way too dour to enliven ("Back in My Day," "Gold")
Love life of an ex-Raincoat with bad habits and a new sampler ("Sorry," "We Had a Really Smashing Time").
He's dropped the Williams but kept the sincerity gene, which makes what a mean and miserable cuss he is more frightening and pitiable ("Candidate for Suicide," "3 Shades of Black").
Jazz and salsa guys "Walking Through Harlem," as Olu Dara puts it, by way of its musical history, with hop-hop slams and James Brown funk for a climax ("Lil' Bit," "Think").
ex-Coolie meets Wreckless Eric in totally improbable guitar-organ garage ("The Next Contestant," "Health Food and Homicide," "Airport Holiday Inn").
Name EDM producer nabs collabs with near-name pop-dance frontpeople--a great trick when it works ("Bounce," "I Need Your Love")
say this for death--it focuses the mind ("Any Road," "P2 Vatican Blues [Last Saturday Night]")
album-available single plus two utterly disparate signature B sides ("Wang Dang Doodle," "Daddy")
Eight efficient catalogue covers add a little flesh, four apt album-unavailables add a little catalogue ("Naked Cousin," "Sheela-Na-Gig").
Sahrawi powerhouse finds new Sahrawi guitarist and rides the haul music they share as hard as she can--for non-Sahrawis, maybe a little too hard ("Maatal-La," "Haiyu")
"Improved" world-ambient trumpet concerts that "migrate" layers between shows and even from older studio to newer live ("Darfari Bridge," "New Gods").

To my surprise--Heaton is a genius who's been warehousing songs for years, Abbott his tartest opposite number--something about the Beautiful South concept (moment?) (band?) upped his game and I wish they'd somehow stuck it out ("I Am Not a Muse," "When I Get Back to Blighty")
One track is the "b-side of 'Don't Curse,' " everything else the A side, and more seductive for it ("The Overweight Lover's in the House," "Black Coffee").
Introducing Sun Ra and Michael Henderson-era Miles to Henry Mancini and Maurice White ("Distant Star," "Joyride").
The Cox-Mitchell band at its most documentable ("Hey Baby [New Rising Sun]," "I Don't Live Today").

After a lifetime of well-regarded overstatement, her straight protest album embraces r&b subtleties no one who starts with "Strange Fruit" will believe are there ("When Love Goes to War," "Strange Fruit")
Chicago, street, basic, reporter, sounds older than he is ("Malcolm," "Red Snow")

Decorating friendly distorto guitar swells with sad angelic vocals, 21st-century supergroup (from Espers! Howlin Rain! Comets on Fire!) makes someting of the touching belief that "psychedelic" has a musical meaning ("Sudden Lament," "Rama")
What Joel Gibb wants isn't dirty sex; it's the transcendence its abandon affords, so the dirty sex faded away as the melodies grew ("Lollipop," "Awoo").
P.C. record of the year--songs soft, singing ordinary, rapping skilled, rhymes up and down, skits de trop, production subtle and terrific ("Lost Ones," "Superstar").
Don't care about "going down no in no history," thus wiser than those who think it matters that they won't (only they may) ("Walk Idiot Walk," "No Pun Intended").
Approach the debut's perfectly conveyed and controlled illusion of headlong desperation, then lose their cool ("You Got It All & . Wrong," "Well All Right!").
No, actually, their best songs weren't always about rock and roll ("We Can Get Together," "Rock Problems").
Nightmare on Gurl Street, or Beyond the Valley of the Sonic Youth ("Teenage Whore," "Clouds")
well before Live Through This, her outtakes have it going on ("Pale Blue Eyes," "Over the Edge")

76-year-old Birmingham/Atlanta environmental junk sculptor improvises tuneless songs about a pain-wracked cosmos you'll want to get to the bottom of ("Six Space Shuttles and 144,000 Elephants," "From the Other Side of the Pulpit")
Gospel-soaked revivalists stretch their net wide and land an uncommonly savory soul-blues album--a cancer survivor's soul-blues album, which makes a difference ("Edge of the Ledge," "Feed My Soul").
"How can a artist make too much art?" ("Runts," "Relapse")
Runs on half a dozen Columbia/Legacy classics, way long on covers, instrumentals, and wife jokes ("She Was a Washout in the Blackout," "Them Hill-Billies Is Sweet Williams Now").
Where the raspy, associative Frances Quinlan of Painted Shut crackled with limitless becoming, this clearer and more coherent one is hemmed in by all she's learned ("Look of Love," "Prior Things")
Voices so sweet and melodies so convincing they could make you think a banality was a serious truth--and sometimes you'd be right ("One Life Stand," "I Feel Better").
Shoebox of American folk music ("Nat'l Weed Growers Assoc.," "Your Old Gearbox").
Bronx Puerto Rican emigrates to New Orleans, where she crystallizes a rock group fit to declaim her story ("Living in the City," "Pa'lante," "Rican Beach")

album: Az Much Ass Az U Want
comment: this just in--rappers get head, respect you in morning ("Great Tazte--Lezz Fillaz," "All That (Just a Little Action")

Some of the smartest raps of his career--"Most rappers are parrots/They say what they told to say to get a neck full of carats"--and some of the easiest beats ("Hood Mentality," "Gangsta Rap Made Me Do It").
Not the first pop dolly with a thoughtful side who's deepest at her shallowest ("I Like You So Much Better When You're Naked," "Louie").
Anthems of the New Sincerity ("Roseability," "Those Wooden Ideas").

Saharan trance music as the contained dance music it was born to be, with citizens of the sand who make their musical rivals sound like tourist bands getting the party started with a track that could sell a whole album of the stuff ("Aï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿")
He's got rhymes, he's got flow, he's got beats, and he wants the world to know that 9/11 was an inside job ("Obnoxious," "Crossing the Boundary")
Pastoral escape put to the tasks of magic social realism and skanky beats ("Pagan Angel and a Borrowed Car," "Resurrection Fern").
The problem with sobriety records is that they're so damn sober ("Elephant," "Cover Me Up")

A more relaxed--too relaxed--Gram-era Flying Burrito Brothers with tales to tell when they're on it, which isn't as often as those tales make you hope ("Byrd From West Virginia," "Raised by Hippies").

Ronnie croons and cries the forebears' songbook while Carlos and Ernie soar-not-shred, and yes, consciousness is included ("Total Destruction to Your Mind," "God Bless the Child," "Mercy Mercy Me [The Ecology]"
Roma finger drum as musical Dardanelles ("Askin Sarabi," "Katar").
when did he become human? I missed it--and I heard his roots album many, many times ("Drive [For Daddy Gene]," "Where Were You [When the World Stopped Turning]")
singing the erotic obsession and existential futility of any spirit too long attached to the flesh, then trying for love too late ("Evening Gown," "Hang On to Me Tonight")
Wreaking havoc the piercing, rocking, 808-fueled, screaming-meemie way ("I Started a Fire," "Cherry Soda").

Classically trained Hindustani tabla player gathers wittingly unkempt and you bet hard-touring Gypsy brass brand from the fountainhead of the Gypsies--Mother India ("Piya Tu Ab To Aaja," "Sonia Dil Da Mamla")
Catch him before he turns into John Cougar Mellencamp--oops, too late ("In the City," "Down in the Tube Station at Midnight").
Soul revivalism done right (for once)--(mostly) well-chosen songs delivered with spunk and smarts ("Baby I'm Scared of You," "Simply Beautiful," "I'd Rather Be With You").
jug-band hokum for slide and tuba ("Ooze It to Me, Mama," "Downbound Train," "Viola Lee Blues," "Wet Laundry Blues")
His 2000 incarnation, gentler and more choral ("Somaiko Somainao," "Alima").
Loud guitar, loud drums, and two guys yelling, sometimes melodically ("The Boys Are Leaving Town," "Wet Hair")

album: Near to the Wild Heart of Life
comment: Five years after their road album, their next road album, so praise G-d they know more at the end of it than they do at the beginning ("No Known Drink or Drug," "In a Body Like a Grave")
meet Keybmaster Swizz Beats, the missing link between Charles Strouse and Too Short ("Hard Knock Life," "If I Should Die")
"Jay-Z's poetry reading"--pronounced "rea-in" not because it's more ghetto but because it's more childish ("Song Cry," "Izzo [H.O.V.A.]");
The pleasures of going legit ("Minority Report," "30 Something").
A trip when jazz heads interlock with rock hooks, workmanlike post-bop when they improvise, give the drummer some throughout ("Heavyfoot," "Clash-Up")
On crack, maybe--them, not Gandhi, who wasn't an "It's not guns that kill people, it's bullets that kill people" kind of guy ("A Storm of Swords," "The Wolf").
Just because she loves him for bringing out the folk-rock softie in her doesn't mean we have to ("Big Wave," "Just Like Zeus," "My Pet Snakes")
'twixt Courtney and Alanis on the noise and normality scales, only sexier ("Luv Song," "Highway 90")
30-year-old Canadian idol retrofits as sexy-bubbly teen in combination star bid, art project, and escape from reality. ("I Really Like You," "Gimmie Love")

Rhythm music as mind music rather than groove music as spirit music--the sound of hundreds of lively ideas lining up to grab your attention without once smoothing them down into a rhythmic or melodic through-line ("Kyanite," "1%")
folk-postpunk Donald Fagen ("Tucumcari," "No Violins")
trying to say what he can't sing, trying to drive with the green light on ("Bad Reputation," "Evie's Tears")

album: It Don't Get Any Better Than This
comment: old faithfuls ("Wild Irish Rose," "It Don't Get Any Better Than This")

Begins with two all-time keepers and a fine novelty, after which the songs need more than the scratch vocals he was stuck with after he ran into an abutment playing his stepdaughter the tape ("Choices," "Cold Hard Truth," "Sinners & Saints")

Listen to these 26 numbers not for their resonance or intensity, but for how expertly and dispassionately they're picked up, performed, and put back down ("I'm Ragged but I'm Right," "Who Shot Sam," "Intro: Hold It")

artist: Hank Jones Meets Cheick-Tidiane Seck and the Mandinkas
comment: Afro-jazz fusion with the emphasis on the Afro for once ("Touniya Kanibala," "Hadja Fadima")
Naptown indie-rapper runs Frankie Lymon and Jackson Pollock through his beat-pumped emotional wringer ("Option Control & the Spirit," "Needy")
Imagine the Ventures playing pan-cultural South American pop in the psychedelic '70s--only really poky, say ("Ya Se a Muerto Mi Abuelo," "El Hijo de la Runamula").

You'd never know there was only one African on this rocking piece of Sahel high-energy--Camara, sing-shouting hoarsely and making a racket on his self-fabricated one-string violin ("Djanfa Moja," "Deep Sahara")

artist: Issa Juma and Super Wanyika Stars
comment: In the greatly simplified rumba style of '80s Kenya, nine nine-minute songs promote the sensible life ("Utalia Na Nani," "Maria").
Roma guitar-violin-accordion postmodernists whose emotions translate better at higher speeds ("Dvojka," "Obrenovac Boogie").
Cheerful Africans and cooperative Danes re-create charming old Ghanaian style ("Mahunumu," "KK").
Swiss-Camerounian bass clarinet and trap drums join Ivoirian balafon master in jazz trio that in a narrower world might settle for a vibraphone instead ("Kalo-Yele," "Makuku," "Adjamï¿½ï¿½ï¿½")
doing his duty to Malian beauty ("Yamore," "Madan")

album: The Best of Salif Keita: The Golden Voice
comment: Two CDs' worth of his Island catalog reshuffled for credible grandeur--Soro improved, Ko-Yan almost untouched ("Nou Pas Bouger--Don't Move Us," "Tekere").
Said difference, while marginal, est en franï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿"La Diffï¿½ï¿½ï¿" "Ekolo d'Amour").
sounds more Arab with Michael Brook Frenching him than with Don Was funking him ("El Ghatli," "Wahrane")
Lebanese peacenik creates functionally peaceful three-part composition on an oud that could make Sandy Bull have a cow.
two unwesternized late-'80s CDs, eight tracks, budget-priced, so how much do you want/need? ("Tum Agar Yuhi Nazren")
Still the king of stand-up turntablism ("Left Side," "Right Side").
The pomo electro doesn't transform her into a true ingenue, and the family reunion is missed ("Pro Nails," "Get Fresh").
Love still hurts, but they understand it better ("The Heart Is a Beating Drum," "Pots and Pans")
I admit it and in fact am proud of it--the tracks I love from Skrillex's rightful heirs are the one with the novelty vocals ("I Do Coke," "Kill It 4 the Kids," "Dolphins on Wheels")
Best cameos of an albumful: Tracy Chapman, Mick Jagger, Eric Clapton ("The Thrill Is Gone," "Paying the Cost To Be the Boss," "Rock Me Baby").
Cut 1971--fresher than London, not quite as ripe as Cook County Jail ("Japanese Boogie," "Niji Baby").
Tireless teacher spurs genius student ("Riding With the King," "Hold On I'm Coming").
Cray's best in half a decade ("Living in the Danger Zone," "Drawers").

album: The Best of King Tubby: King Dub
comment: Simple suffices, 1973-1977 ("Dub From the Roots," "Keep On Dubbing").
They're only remixes, generally of songs fans already love, but they do shake quite a bit of action ("Got 2 Let U," "Pass This On")
good old dirtbags raise hell as they go there ("A Pretty Good Guy," "If I Were You")
"Bring it on get it done don't run s.o.b." explains why white guys don't like Obamacare, and sometimes wish they could ("You Can't Trust No One," "Little Victories")
Macedonian tuba funk for that once-in-a-lifetime blowout, its horns, vocals, and beats imbued with Middle Eastern quaver ("Siki, Siki Baba," "Zen Nube").
Balkan brass's most fluent ensemble speaks the language of erotic commitment ("Kalino Mome," "Sahara Dreams").
Living for the Saturday-night swindle ("Fast Food-Slow Death," "Look at That White Girl Dance").

Fine Malian singer with explosive trad drummer whose best song after "Welcome" concerns a nation ruined and whose best song after that concerns shaking that thing ("Bisimillah," "Ir Ganda Hassara," "Ayï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½")

Sorie Kondi, blind Sierra Leonean master of the thumb piano Sierra Leoneans call a kondi, transformed into a dance band by Sierra Leonean-American DJ Chief Boima ("You Wan Married?" "Without Money, No Family")
back in command ("Funke Wisdom," "Rise 'n' Shine," "Death Blow)
From Sofia and the sampled Bulgarian countryside, Gypsy ethnotechno more Middle Eastern than Balkan, more Gaby Kerpel than Shantel ("Long Song," "Myanman").
Intricate and improvisatory, griot scion reaches out to the world and back into history ("Yele With Seke Chi Intro," "N'Goke")
best-of with the bass boosted--very funktional, meine Herren ("Pocket Calculator," "The Robots")
declaiming his songpoems to (and like) a rock and roll beat ("Nelson Algren Stopped By," "Great Big Amp")

What could be bad about an Americana ensemble named after a Russian anarchist that reprises Gershwin and Mickey & Sylvia and turns "This Land Is Your Land" into a dirge? ("The Stars of Country Music Greet the Spring," "No Good Lover")
Sudanese wedding music for the Aswan diaspora--fast by rustic standards, James Brown-influenced but who isn't ("Mabrouk Wo Arisna," "Maria-Maria," "Al Samra Helwa")
The old ways are best, in sound and story ("Palm Wine Sound [Instrumental]," "Don't Worry About My Mouth O [African Message]".
Lyrics sharper, angrier, stronger, band and especially voice less so ("Carry On Pushing On," "No Work No Job No Money")
Joseph Shabalala & Co. sing the pop-gospel songbook (best cameo: Dolly Parton) ("Knockin' on Heaven's Door," "I'll Take You There)

album: Walking in the Footsteps of Our Fathers
comment: Although no angel, their paterfamilias sang more angelically than any of his heirs, who opt in his absence for practical songs about Christian agape and parliamentary democracy ("Phalamende," "Mina Kangivumanga")
Volume duly fiddled, "Fiddle With the Volume" still isn't a banger ("Love Me or Hate Me," "Random").

Cut on the fly November 9, 2016, by master songwriter Langford, three Chicago pals, and some Muscle Shoals regulars, none of whom I bet had their heads together yet ("In Oxford Mississippi," "Fish Out of Water," "Mystery")
Two enduring rerecorded highlights, one fine recycled obscurity, one excellent new song, mail-order only ("Nashville Radio," "The Return of the Golden Guitarist").
She has a small voice for a roots-targeted gal with too much pride to boop up songs that miss the bull's-eye ("Damn Love Song," "Stranger Me")

album: I've Got My Own Hell to Raise
comment: Well-culled material sung harder than necessary, which was probably the idea ("Sleep to Dream," "How Am I Different").
Vietnamese guitarist-programmer co-constructs atmospheres, from electric Miles to Chinoiserie ("Mali Iwa," "Stranieri").
He can rap, he can rhyme, and Christian ethics are a lot better than than no ethics at all--especially when they don't moralize from above ("Welcome to America," "Dirty Water")
Yo-Yo's mama ("Rip Off," "Wedlock Is a Padlock," "Women's Love Rights," "Since I Fell for You")
Exene without sensitivity, folk music, a notebook--with hard rock and a voice like a fire alarm ("Under Fire," "96 Tears")
For an ordinary soul man, he has excellent tunes ("I Can Change," "Live It Up").
A myth of conscious soul neither the singer nor his attendant rappers can quite put across ("Compared to What," "I Can't Write Left Handed")
Lost affair leaves him mooning, melodic as ever but too crestfallen to do anything about it ("The World Moves On," "The End of the World Is Bigger Than Love")
More songs about pathology and revenge ("Fight Diabetes," "If You Change Your Accent for the City People," "Pink Scrunched Up Thing")

album: Les Ambassadeurs du Motel de Bamako
artist: Les Ambassadeurs du Motel de Bamako
comment: Two discs of accomplished, formative Cuban Malian music in the evolving fusion rightly associated with the dominant Salif Keita, whose tracks outshine those of singers as top-drawer as Kante Manfila as songs ("Bolola Sanou," "Mali Denou," "Mana Mana," "Djoula")
Nigerien sisters soften Saharan intensity with an innocence that's sweetly girl-group, although admittedly less catchy ("Eghass Malan," "Tihilele")
Beats high-functional, articulation pure soprano, rhymes dancehall boom-bap once removed, best of many giggles her delight in the word "schmuck" ("Yippy Yay," "Freak," "Boom Bam")
Thinking man's romantic makes intelligent beats sound easy ("Diamond Girl," "Gibberish").
Anyone who thinks these two self-consciously childish British teengirls are a mess is a tightass, and anyone who thinks they're geniuses is a doodyhead ("Eat Shiitake Mushrooms," "Rapunzel)
Decades later, generation-gap duets are just a bunch of old guys singing--pretty good, too ("That Kind of Fool," "Rock and Roll").
Debut-album "single" plus four affectionately unfinished collectibles, the best an actual single ("Don't Look Back Into the Sun," "Mayday").
"Fuck N.W.A, put down your watergun" ("One Life To Live," "Prison Is the Death of a Poor Man")

album: I Am Not a Human Being
comment: His throwaways beat their keepers, from solitary yet, but the true classics are all in the middle and the Young Money promos are filler ("I Am Not a Human Being," "Popular," "I'm Single")

Saith Big Ghost: "Ayo I aint got nothin against Wayne but his crew is some garbage niggaz nahmean. That aint a dynasty or nothin nahmean. Thats a crew wit like 10 Memphis Bleeks namsayin." ("My Name Is," "Big Wings")
No throwaway or overreach, but after all that drama not near enough fun either ("Problems," "Mess," "Mona Lisa")
Bent sambas I expect straighten out quicker for those who understand the Portuguese four of them are written in ("Grain by Grain," "Arto Vs. Arto")
The refreshingly ordinary wisdom of Imani-from-the-block, with all too ordinary hooks to match ("Guys Like When Girls Kiss," "Cryin for the Queen," "28 Butts").
astride the world as R-rated pop staple ("Father," "Nobody Can Freak You")
R-rated concept album about clubworld "SEX," "LOVE," and "PAIN" ramped up by neither PG-rated remix hit nor modest tune quotient ("Habits [Stay High]," "Moments")
brighter than Bleach, less fly than Incesticide ("Chicago Fanphair '93," "Grrrlfriend")
something to be pissed about ("President Forever," "Birth, School, Work, Death")
Formerly high on triumph, now determined to prevail ("Everyone Alive," "California Songs")
high-grade all-star Afro-Parisian best-of medley/remake ("`Lagos Night'/`Sweet Mother'/`Christiana'/`Aki Special'/`Stella'/`Wellenga'/`Oh Death'/`Lagos Night'")
"Band of Drunks" revisited--the Jewish equivalent of nouveau honkytonk ("A Shiker Iz a Bloyzer-Shpiler [A drunk is a brass-player]," "Lekhaim, Efraim [Cheers, Frank]").
country's not his discipline, realism is ("Heather's All Bummed Out," "Dying Breed");

Mellow, grooveful, humorous beatmaster-soundscaper emerges from a bout of hearing loss with an ear-friendly bag of tricks that's never trickier than when guest rappers pay their respects and collect a check ("Blame the Author," "Look Around," "Things Are Just Props")

As experience dampens enthusiasm, they find fewer great choruses than great lines--"Every girl I ever kissed I was thinking of a pro footballer," for instance ("Plan A," "The Sea Is a Good Place to Think About the Future").
rock en espaï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿"El Loco," "Sr. Judas")
Eight drunk-sounding old son guys, one young trumpeter putting his two centavos in ("Hoja seca," "El guao").
chewing their cud for one album too long ("Oh, Yeah," "Corazon")
funny guy, but who can trust him? ("Long Tall Texan," "Don't Touch My Hat")
"Born to be the who I am," "secondary modern boy" pushes 60 ("One More Rocket," "Zazzy").
All they want is to be rock and roll's most basic bar band and rock and roll's most sophisticated bar band at the same time ("Montreal," "Death & Destruction")
in which schemes replace dreams and shadows on the wall head for a fall ("Renï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï" "Orange Peel")
Orchestrally textured, beat-driven alt-rap enlists vocoder and Satie-Shad-Kool Moe Dee collab ("Magnolia," "Gymnopedie 1.2")
Are we allowed to wonder whether she's spunky enough for a Nashville legend with a new lease on life? ("Red Shoes," "Story of My Life")
Remakes that never seem redundant from an 83-year-old who's lived clean but never been a prig about it. ("Everybody Wants to Go to Heaven," "Wine Into Water")
"You do it do it do it do it just let go" ("Johnny Met June," "You're the Man").
She sings some of these Dusty Springfield covers so torchy and tasteful you'd think they were on Dusty in Memphis to begin with ("Just a Little Lovin'," "You Don't Have to Say You Love Me").
"When I was younger I/Used to wonder why/People in the public eye/Always lose their fuckin' minds/Now I'm coming up on 35/They didn't teach this shit in Berkeley High" ("Pillz," "Oh, Baby!")
Cut circa 1990, unreleased because it seemed too loose, and better for it ("Baydikacce," "Farma").
"F yez all, F yez all, F yez all" ("St. John of Gods," "Paddy Public Enemy No. 1").
Biz Markie as postgangsta ("Flava in Ya Ear," "Funk Wit Da Style")

album: Country Music Hall of Fame Series
comment: old-timey comedian, populist minstrel, unpaid liquor lobbyist ("Governor Al Smith," "Tennessee Jubilee")
more songs about songs and songs ("Swinging London," "Strange Powers")
Rhymes that could give Eminem a hernia, music that could give Sondheim the giggles ("You Must Be Out of Your Mind," "The Dolls' Tea Party").
old dog's blues ("Satisfied 'n' Tickled Too," "Sittin' on Top of the World")

album: Shoutin' in Key: Taj Mahal and the Phantom Blues Band Live
comment: Love so much music and there's always more songs waiting ("Honky Tonk," "Ain't That a Lot of Love").
From before John McLaughlin discovered Barney Kessel and Jan Hammer discovered Jan Hammer ("John's Song #2," "Trilogy").

album: Guns Don't Kill People . . . Lazers Do
comment: Diplo and Switch attach an artist name to a mixtape--which includes obvious stuff for pop pushovers like me! ("I'll Make You," "Mary Jane," "Baby").
should have figured he'd turn fussbudget on us eventually ("1% of One," "Vanessa From Queens")
A jam band for middle-aged neurotics who gather where most of their kind gather--their living rooms ("Hopscotch Willie," "Dragonfly Pie").
On his best album in years, his two most fetching melodies power his most representational lyrics ever ("Bike Lane," "Refute")
her hopes as realistic as her words, which in today's bohemia makes her an optimist, she stumbles like Sonic Youth and strums like the Fall ("Sympathy Wreath," "Someone Wants You Dead")
dread-roots counterpoint ("Shumba," "Pachinyakare")
Complex rhymes, organic textures, well-felt soul samples, and a few deft cameo changeups render this particular lucre quest so entertaining it's almost interesting ("Corniche," "The Sauce")
Young man with a horn leads family business toward the bigger time ("Dzumbus Funk," "Romano Bijav").

Adding "guitar, accordion, piano and drum kit, giving a decidedly contemporary sound that's both danceable and radio-friendly"--in other words, completing their evolution into a damn fine tourist band ("Caje Sukarije (Beautiful Girl)," "Zivot Cigana (Whistle)")
1963-66 Studio One ska/rocksteady--gems you'll play again amid curiosities you'll be glad you heard once ("Who Feels It Knows It," "Bend Down Low," "Hooligan," "Let Him Go")
Nice guy finishes first ("Grenade," "Lazy Song")

Sung offhandedly and observed at, yes, leisure, the pleasurable escape of going to museums and looking at art--Calder, Copley, Michelangelo ("Jobs I Had Before I Got Rich and Famous," "Calder's Circus")
soul ii skank ("One Love," "Be Thankful for What You've Got")
Chris Goss still ain't Eric Page, but his songs beat Peter Bruce's, and Ginger Baker makes a difference ("Ants in the Kitchen," "T.U.S.A.")
the best Cuban American Texas music Nashville can capitalize ("All That Heaven Will Allow," "There Goes My Heart," "I Should Have Been True")
Saying in so many words what his less-gifted, more-pretentious contemporaries think it's cool to camouflage ("Waiting on the World to Change," "The Heart of Life").
Grammy-crushing craftsmen can be damned good at saying something in 80 words or thereabouts--say 61, or 116 ("Love Is a Verb," "Speak for Me")
"I hope it's not too late/Searching for time that has gone so fast" ("Ever Present Past," "Nod Your Head").
FDR fireside chats bookend bluegrass good guy Del McCoury's concept comp about slicker greed (Del McCoury Band, "Moneyland"; Dan Tyminski, "Carry Me Across the Mountain").
your living room has a computer, theirs has a synthesizer ("I Eat Dinner," "Love Is")
Great old songs they didn't write, dubious new ones they did ("Seven Joys of Mary," "What Are You Doing New Year's Eve").
Too much too soon, and also too late, a syndrome that cries out for professional advice ("Cupcake," "Food").
Barely 30, she's still occasionally entranced by the magic of metaphor, and already speaking so plainly sometimes you can hardly believe it's art at all ("If You Ask," "Monday Afternoon")
Missy-of-the-Year jump start, '70s-funk cruise control ("In My Business," "Top Billin' ").
Reformed Oklahoma art teacher nails rockabilly originals like he's writing haikus ("North Side Gal," "Signs & Signifiers")

album: More Songs About Buildings and Cows
comment: Bluegrass with attitude--radical, maybe even lesbian attitude ("More Man," "Travel and Toil").

Vocal-performance-with-guitar cycle about online dating--sometimes harrowing, sometimes excruciating ("Attraction Is Ephemeral," "I'm Not Into Being the Woman You're With While You're Looking for the Woman You Want").
Live-to-a-single-mike barroom renditions of barely finished new songs buttressed by audience chorales open up a new frontier in for-fans-only at just the wrong time ("The Cell," "Bucket")
blues riffs (and tempos) as punk noise ("You're My Wife," "Me and J.G. Ballard")
Even if Teddy's not fully himself, Harold's not half Jerry Butler, and Sharon Paige is Sharon Paige ("If You Don't Know Me by Now," "To Be True").
Pretty much past her prime, but not so's she's ready to admit it ("He's in the Ring," "Call the Fire Wagon," "New Orleans Stop Time").
Pronounced as in "internet," not "inane," a word I guarantee was known to this more verbal than musical MC back when he was making his bones on a premature mixtape ("Yap Yap," "Tweakin")
They [heart] Philly gurls' cheesesteaks--eat them too ("Philly Gurls," "Diana [Heart U]").

Too bad Savannah's jazz-steeped master lyricist--"Blues in the Night," "One for My Baby," "Autumn Leaves," on and on--never mastered lounge piano, because as a big-band singer he can't resist period smarm, cute, or boilerplate ("G.I. Jive," "I'm Gonna See My Baby")
"Turn the rap game into WCW" ("Blackout," "Run 4 Cover")
Sometimes calibrating love takes more brains than condemning consumerism--usually, in fact ("Gimme Sympathy," "Satellite Mind").
Like Vampire Weekend, only as synth-dance rather than indie-rock, they convert a quality liberal education into thoughtful, anxious, faux-lite pop ("Kids," "Time to Pretend").
amandla ("Izinziswa," "Mfaz Onga Phesheya")
If you go to all the trouble of cooking crack, you might as well get your chortle on about it ("Hanna Montana," "Versace," "Bakersman")
Their farewell to DIY is slightly less hooky and more thug, and it makes a difference ("You Wanna See," "Chances")
now imagine a tuneful weed who covers Phil Ochs and gives Jack Straw the business ("Jack Ass," "Scrabble")
The cleverest, tenderest, and most rakish relationship delineator of his generation comes up with a bunch more ("Jules," "Wanderlust")
not enough novelties ("Dang Me," "You Can't Roller Skate in a Buffalo Herd")
Millennial guitar master enlists graybeard backup legends to deploy songs that often prove a shade-and-a-half too atmospheric even so ("Don't Tell Our Friends About Me," "Seven")
Frankfurt "Quartett" does Piazzolla with more dramatic dynamics and less loco pizzazz ("La Resurreccion Del Angel," "Tango Del Diablo").
When world death threatens, don't expect El-P's beats to lift anyone's spirits for the struggle ahead ("Brothaz," "Murs Iz My Manager").
Alt-rap against monetarism, with beats to match ("What About Us?" "Welcome to the World").

Whether the character of the conflicted lifemate is the "real" Josh Tillman, as we are assured, or a subtle fictionalization, as is my default assumption, quality time is not much in him ("I Love You Honeybear," "Strange Encounters")
his best since Before and After Science ("Heaven," "J Breas")
There are cornier ways of keeping it old-school ("Everyday It's 1989," "I Love to Move in Here").
The 18 to Wait for Me's Play--only not by as decisive a margin, these things are subtle (too subtle) ("The Broken Places," "The Day")
live Harvard '71 and Berkeley '73, back when Jonathan thought cute was pretending he couldn't spell "girlfriend" ("A Plea for Tenderness," "The Mixer [Men and Women Together]," "I'm Straight")
Still anxious after all these years--at a level of articulation so developed I can't tell you why they don't just move on already ("Sugar Boats," "God Is an Indian and You're an Asshole")
Brooklyn jazz and rock saxophones, bass, and percussion unite an extended family of Ethiopian and Malian scales and sonorities--especially Ethiopian ("Hello Bolly," "Ethiofreaks")
Not Hamada the Japanese folk ceramicist, hamada the rocky desert plateau--only this being Norwegian trumpet, chillier ("Cruel Altitude," "Friction").
Vocally and compositionally, greatly enhanced by the cameos of the many luminaries who admire her ambition and range ("Givin Em What They Want," "Dance Apocalyptic")
Superb beginning to end, duh--but inexcusably lacking both "Little Rootie Tootie" and the Johnny Griffin "In Walked Bud" ("Jackie-ing," "Off Minor").
Zimbabwean-Norwegian quintet come this close to rising above exceptionally agreeable dinner music ("Nhemamsasa," "Hondo")
Without Bjorn and John, here comes prettier and deeper living-room cabaret than Keren Ann, Sondre Lerche or Jose Gonzales ("This Is What I Came For," "Le Petit Coeur").
Platinum role model can't help helping others, so she tries to help other girls avoid this mistake ("Eight Easy Steps," "Doth I Pretend Too Much")
One of those guitarists whose songs aren't quite sharp enough to make you love his grizzled handshake of a voice--but believe it, they're getting closer ("Dirty Old Buffalo," "50 Years")
Imagine an Elastica devoid of soul, but relaxed about it ("Take Off Your Clothes," "Jetsetter").
New York 1967--hungry young Irishman spouts blues poetry in a roomful of session pros ("T.B. Sheets," "Brown Eyed Girl," "The Back Room")

Introducing the concept and smoking his other five other copyrights with a jauntily repetitive original called "Broken Record," he proves his mature mettle by covering the great American songbook with more panache than Linda Ronstadt if not Joni Mitchell ("They Can't Take That Away From Me," "Makin' Whoopee")
Borscht Belt hip hop from Ice Berg and Dr. Dreidle, who sold their Chevy to the Levys but the Levys can't drive ("Town Car," "Double Dutch Lunch").
Is it that he knows less about himself than he does about the world, or that he won't reveal it? ("Dance Music," "Hast Thou Considered the Tetrapod?").

Four great songs, all of which address mortality directly instead of implying it the way the nine merely ambitious ones do ("Estate Sale Sign," "For Charles Bronson," "Sourdoire Valley Song," "Beautiful Gas Mask")

"They got a loophole in Davos / They got a giant needle / If you can pay the price / They'll let you ride a camel through the eye"--which is why "Evangelical Hypocrites" could give a shit about the "Next Mass Extinction" ("21st Century Pharisees," "Next Mass Extinction")
and a damn fine formula it is ("Agony," "Oh Nina")

album: Geoff Muldaur and the Texas Sheiks
artist: Geoff Muldaur and the Texas Sheiks
comment: Old man's blues revived jug-swing style ("The World Is Going Wrong," "Under the Chicken Tree").

album: Maria Muldaur & Her Garden of Joy
artist: Maria Muldaur & Her Garden of Joy
comment: "Good time music for hard times," jug re-revival division ("The Panic Is On," "He Calls That Religion").
jazz and only jazz--deeper, funkier, and further out than Ask the Ages ("Black and Black")
Carnivalesque as sonny idea, but remember--one nice thing about rock and roll is you don't have to like flutes ("Mona," "Flor Na Paul").
He needs his ka drummer and his diaspora brass, but the heroes are guest co-tenor Pharoah Sanders and trap drummer Hamid Drake, Yanks both despite their sobriquets ("Gwotet," "Ovwa").

His Romeo and Juliet thing is called "Shakespears on the Low," but I keep thinking Stendhal--The Red and the Blue, as fucked up and tribal as ever ("GBKW [God Bless Kanye West]," "One Uh Those Days," "1000 Suns")
all-over-the-place pop genius, scattershot Rasta crank ("The People's Court," "Letter to Congress [Is It Because Wi Blakk]")
Gangsta shit finally beneath him, he bids to become pop's scariest party animal ("Shake Ya Ass," "Big Truck Boys," "Family").
his beats are supernatural, but he rips pussy linings, which whatever his physical deformities just isn't very nice ("Bouncin' Back [Bumpin' Me Against the Wall]," "Big Truck Driver")
confessions of a mama's boy, tales of a hustler, lies of a mortal man ("Book of Rhymes," "Get Down")
Reflections of a bigshot who, as he mentions several times, is damn big ("Daughters," "Accident Murderers")
Girlish insecurity ripens into womanly insecurity, which involves more bluster ("Take Me to a Higher Plane," "Do-Wah-Do").
Living for sex gets less dreamy all the time ("Wedding Crasher," "Used to Be")
Love in the time of fake empire ("Fake Empire," "Mistaken for Strangers").
Even after loss transmutes into pain sweet pain, it has a way of reverting to the same old same old ("I Should Live in Salt," "Don't Swallow the Cap")
Poker-faced folk joker models hippie drag in Cali and Oregon, then returns to Brooklyn, where she belongs ("Do It on a Leaf," "I'm a Shark").
Slow is beautiful ("Loyalty," "Sincerity," "Satisfy").
2000's not quite compelling Senegal-only, its lead cuts ready to be toned up for the nice people at Nonesuch ("Bird," "Ba Tay")
