Stew solves the song problem, but not the what-it-all-means problem ("Bermuda Love Triangle [The Waterbed]," "Is This the Single?")
his best in a coon's age, and a touch too artful all around ("She's Not for You," "Don't Give Up," "American Tune")
Stardust for swinging lovers ("Moonlight Becomes You," "Please Don't Talk About Me When I'm Gone")

album: You Don't Know Me: The Songs of Cindy Walker
comment: He owns the title tune now too ("Don't Be Ashamed of Your Age," "Dusty Skies").
Great that the countrypolitan schmaltz is magically excised--now if only he wasn't still trying to sing over it ("I Let My Mind Wander," "The Party's Over").

Only the song about songwriting rises above Billy Joe's "It's hard to be an outlaw who ain't wanted anymore," but a few come surprisingly close ("The Songwriters," "Hard to Be an Outlaw," "The Git Go")

They do enjoy themselves, but although you'd think Willie wrote the buoyant one about the world going to pot, instead he wrote the lugubrious one about dreams going to die ("It's All Going to Pot," "Missing Ol' Johnny Cash," "Live This Long")
chestnuts roasted in an open studio, Pamper demos-style ("A Moment Isn't Very Long," "Home Motel")
Beats of course, songs usually, singing barely--especially sincere-type singing ("Anti Matter," "Everyone Nose [All the Girls Standing in the Line for the Bathroom]").
Doowop neoclassicism so loving and exquisite it lacks but one crucial virtue--innocence ("My True Story," "Ting a Ling")
The kind of young band that's doubly convincing on tunes it can't quite handle ("Open," "Don't Like the Way")
Compulsive craftsmen have feelings too--they're just nervous about letting them show ("Miracle Drug," "Come Crash").
not techno and proud ("Regret," "Young Offender")
They haven't slowed down, the world's speeded up, but though it's good they're more together, it's bad they're more dead ("Human Being," "You Can't Put Your Arms Around a Memory/Lonely Planet Boy").
Late soukous for Americans, somehow whole despite mbira, jujubeats, and circular breathing ("Midi Passï¿½" "Mwana Congo").
Nothing makes a formalist bare his heart like a 12-step program and some marital enlightenment ("It's Me I'm Worried About," "Cheaper Than a Shrink").

Nearing 80, Asante palm-wine guardian relaxes with some musicians he knows and demonstrates his less-gentle-than-they-sound guitar tricks for posterity ("See Wo Nom Me [Tsetse Fly You Suck My Blood]," "Efie Ne Fie")
More like the Strokes than the Strokes were ever like Television, with simpler riffs, cheaper laughs and the occasional soupcon of LCD Soundsystem ("You Made Me Like It," "Cult Status").

album: Rhythm of Healing (Supreme Sax and Penny Whistle Township Jive)
comment: think late M.G.'s, trying to consolidate what they'd accomplished--with the Bar-Kays in the house ("Mazuzu," "Marabi Kwela")
Vinyl-only EP exploring the musical question, "What to do, what to do, elegiac raveups or peculiar songs?" ("Losing Feeling," "You're a Target").

album: White Trash, Two Heebs and a Bean
comment: growing in wit, growing in wisdom ("Liza and Louise," "Please Play This Song on the Radio")

album: So Long and Thanks for All the Shoes
comment: "All Outta Angst," so "The Desperation's Gone" ("Monosyllabic Girl," "All His Suits Are Torn").
"I define success as not working/And I live like a king" ("Creeping Out Sara," "My Orphan Year").
great masters trade fours (Rancid, "Don't Call Me White"; NOFX, "Olympia WA")
Conscious punk aspiring to art-rock, and not ruinously ("Don't Give Up," "Scratch Your Name").
On the brink of a poetic breakthrough, gentle sweety-pie with a Hennessy habit isn't ready to assume the burden, not quite yet ("Yesterday," "Casket Pretty")
Three fine Long Island witches, whose words ace their music, sing more and rap less ("Things I'll Do," "The Three Amigas").

Never much shakes with songs per se, they put their minds into an entreaty their South needs, their hearts into their South's African-American repertoire, and their guitars into Will Shade's greatest hit ("Prayer for Peace," "Stealin'")
Henry Cow meets da funk on da Lower East Side ("Sad," "Saturday Morning")

album: Nublu Orchestra Conducted by Butch Morris
artist: Nublu Orchestra Conducted by Butch Morris
comment: Improvised big-band tone poems grow tunes and timbres from funk to serialism ("Downstairs," "Sciubba Diving").
Love man projects minimum modicum of empathy with his salable burr yet somehow sounds cuddly even so ("Another Time," "Lyk Dis," "Fkku")
Perpetually PO-ed alt lifers get a grip on it ("I Want Results," "No Fly List")
The words of the prophets are clear, people--so clear ("Curly Locks," "Throw Down Your Arms").
Will Sheff should stop worrying about what a star he is, or isn't, or doesn't want to be, or . . . --normal obscurity is within his means, I swear it ("Lost Coastlines," "On Tour With Zykos").
Transylvanian laments and jumping dances via hot violins and a cymbalon that sounds like a player piano ("Csabai [Mezï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï" "Cigï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï")
Weaker than his legendary final album, but way more alive than his rumored one ("Pop Shots," "Dirty Dirty").
The new kids have Rhett feeling down ("Moonlight," "The New Kid," "Bloomingtown").
Not weird enough--indulges the Jean Michel Jarre tendencies built into his DNA ("Americans," "Inside World")

album: Between My Head and the Sky
comment: Still sui generis and still not repeating herself, which means among other things a little too much piano etude ("The Sun Is Down!" "Between My Head and the Sky").
OK, OK, a class cute act ("Blue Boy," "Consolation Prize").
reconstructing kitsch for the music of it ("Moon River," "A Shot in the Dark")
the finest anger money can buy ("Shut Up," "Come Dig Me Out")
music machine with its works on the surface, all the better to delight and annoy you ("Dad, There's a Little Phrase Called Too Much Information," "Hair Dude, You're Stepping on My Mystique")
Blind pop sexpot for Jesus ("I Love the Way," "I Know Who You Are").
"toye": juju-highlife as four psychedelic suite-jams ("Logba Logba"/"Edumare da Mi Lihun"/"E Se Rere"/"Prof Oyewole")
Regina Carter and David Sanchez help more than they should have to ("In Flight," "In Walked Bud").
dancehall crossover at full-bore integrity ("Gimme the Light," "Get Busy")

album: Crooked Rain Crooked Rain: LA's Desert Origins
comment: You have to care even more than I do to sort this expanded edition out, but you won't turn it off ("Unseen Power of the Picket Fence," "Fucking Righteous").

artist: Grand Peeples and the Peeples Republik
comment: Steals a world-class hook from Bob Dylan, who had it coming, and nails two protest songs out of four, which is better than Dylan has done in quite a while ("The New Brownsville Girl," "This Could be a Long Night," "More feor Us, Less for Them")
pure art-rock for art-pop people ("I Hear They Smoke the Barbecue," "Worlds in Collision")
still rockin' (again) after all these years ("Down by the River II," "My Friend Is a Stooge for the Media Priests")
Tuneful of course, but even if all this convolution is easier for him, it isn't for us ("High as a Kite," "Somerville").
sane weirdo exploits mad genius ("Secret Laboratory [Scientific Dancehall]," "Inspector Gadget," "African Hitchiker)
dub for laughs--Newcleus's munchkins, Selassie's brother, Scratch's cock ("Small Morsel," "Messy Appartment")
Surrounded by such coequals as Tunde Adebimpe, Sly Dunbar, and Hamid Drake, he--uh-oh--behaves himself ("Orthodox," "House of God")
Music is their native language, English not ("Amsterdam," "Objects of My Affection").
They want more than only memories--a human touch to make them real ("Building a Wall," "Vulnerable").
In pop, when the production's solid and the voice a little less so, the songs had better be on the money ("Got My Own Thing," "Table for One").
surrealism in African American life, middle-class cutup division ("Ya Mama," "If I Were President," "It's Jiggaboo Time")
less subtle than the American Clave versions (I count five repeats), but not so as newcomers could tell ("Return to Love (Regreso al Amor")
exactly the live testament you think they deserve ("Manta Ray," "Wild Honey Band")
Folk-leaning guy and pop-leaning gal sip iced tea on the veranda of their platinum-plated studio ("Killing the Blues," "Please Read the Letter").
more sampling, less singing--please ("Fantasia's Confidential Ghetto: 1999/Once in a Lifetime/Coconut," "The 9:45 Wake-Up Dream")
the concept's an excuse to do originals, the best of which stay on concept ("Iris Chacon," "Let's Take It Easy)
The demure femme-punk sexpot trick ("Shut Up and Kiss Me," "Matthew Modine").
Sans their famed debut EP, San Francisco weirdos prove it's not so hard to make entertaining straight-ahead guitar rock--only now try and imitate it ("Truckin' - Slow Version," "In Frisco").
Beth Gibbons' solipsistic melodrama remains an indie meme as her guys corrode their electrodes toward something more outgoing ("We Carry On," "Machine Gun").
Punk-rap not Afro-punk, heavy on the verbiage and nothing like "emo" ("Out of Category," "Low Light Low Life").
Hooky pop cheer fails to modulate unbearable falsetto anxiety ("I Think I'd Like You Better if I Loved You," "I Heard It Was a Beautiful Party")

album: The Best of the Early Years
comment: Roots of the mecca of tourist music, roughly replicating the '20s 40 or 50 years later ("Olympia on Parade," "When the Saints Go Marching In").
porn now an annoyance, funk still a surprise ("Loose!" "Pheromone")
Viva Las Vegas and later for Viagra--but not never ("Guitar," "The One U Wanna C").
"Old Faithful's just a fountain/Compared to the glory of true love" ("She Is My Everything," "Some Humans Ain't Human").
With so many ears of corn in his bag, he feels no need to put all his chestnuts in the fire ("The Bottomless Lake," "Unwed Fathers").
seven worthy remixes, two cultural criticisms, four us-against-thems cum me-against-thems ("Air Hoodlum," "Gett Off My Back")
mbube harmonies sweeten mbaqanga beats--jaunty always, inspiring sometimes, intense never ("Ubani Oku Holayo," "Nginethuba Lami")
they think they can they know they can ("C'mon N' Ride It [The Train]," "Get On Up and Dance")
real Intelligent Black Woman, expedient Gangsta Bitch ("Coochie Bang . . . ," "U.N.I.T.Y.," "Black Hand Side")
Masters of unreality ("Feel Good Hit of the Summer," "Monsters in the Parasol").
seminal DIY, bullshit included ("Rocket #9," "The Sun One," "Big City Blues")
makes a lot more sense if you're already feeling down in the mouth ("Packt Like Sardines in a Crushd Tin Box," "Knives Out")

album: Only Built for Cuban Linx . . . Pt. 2
comment: Noir is beautiful ("10 Bricks," "House of Flying Daggers," "Ason Jones").
scattershot rads in the U.S.A. ("Harry Bridges," "Burn")
What if a Clash record fell in the middle of a stock exchange and nobody could hear it? ("Radio Havana," "It's Quite Alright").

album: In the Grace of Your Love
comment: Posers have real lives too--really--only it's really hard to care ("In the Grace of Your Love," "How Deep Is Your Love")
womyn's heroyne yndulges hyr ynner gyrrrl ("Lucystoners," "Johnny Rottentail")
Indigo Girl's solo sober Southern identity ("Rural Faggot," "Let It Ring").
Four forlornly sexy, gutsy songs that somehow sound better individually than as part of a whole that maybe just isn't one ("I Is What I Is," "Posted by Anonymous")
Blessed with the New York heart and attitude of Patti and David Jo, cursed by lesser talent, night thoughts, and Gotham's rising rents ("Add Value Add Time," "Revelations of a Stamp Monkey")
A career's worth of demotic artsong bedecked with occasional guitar-piano and a whole lotta Antony falsetto ("Smalltown," "Street Hassle")

Hard to sustain an eclectic array of guitar-band instrumentals over a full album unless your listeners' eclecticism contours just the way yours does ("Game Is Rigged," "Flatbush and Church Revisited").

album: We Belong to the Staggering Evening
comment: Struggling artist realizes he has more money than the strugglers he writes about, and writes better as a result ("Valentine's Day in Juarez," "Broken Parakeet Blues").
eternal sleep ("Man on the Moon," "Nightswimming")

Second-generation sambista gathers all-female ensemble for rock-tinged, salt-flavored reflections on her artistic heritage that can now be downloaded free from her website ("Mama-Me," "Sonï¿½ï¿½ï¿" "O Que Me Arde")
He says his piece and gets out, as rare a thing in a preacher as in a rapper ("I Used to Think I Was Run," "Home Sweet Home").
everything you need know of a first-rate rapper and his second-rate crew, cameos unfortunately excepted ("Woo Hah!! Got You All in Check," "Everything Remains Raw")
Avant-guitarist to the cult stars constructs power trio that can play every genre he's interested in, with--what else?--mixed results ("Party Intellectuals," "Break on Through").
better his enlightened-bourgie Smokey than D'Angelo's pomo-new jack Marvin ("Like a Woman," "Billy Goat," "The Grass Is Green")

album: Action Packed: The Best of Jonathan Richman
comment: miniaturist under the magnifying glass ("Monologue About Bermuda," "Closer," "You're Crazy for Taking the Bus")

album: No Me Quiejo De Mi Estrella
comment: Digs Leonard Cohen, digs his wife more, is so big in Spain he's learning the language, and--one more thing--will never own a cell ("Here It Is," "You Can Have a Cell Phone That's OK but Not Me")
high-texture also-rans process rock and roll readymades through art school sensibilities and infernal machines ("Time After Time," "Not Fazed")
So much more provocative as an android than as a human being ("Phresh Out the Runway," "Diamonds," "Numb")
like an up-and-coming Steve Earle, without explicit leftism or explicit substance abuse ("The Wedding Song," "Desperate Times")

album: The Day the Earth Met the Rocket From the Tombs
comment: David Thomas and Peter Laughner rehearse and play out, rude and alive respectively ("Raw Power," "Never Gonna Kill Myself Again")
no, not as good as the Bush Tetras--better, which is the least we should insist on ("Purely Evil," "Zero Point")

album: What I Like About You (And Other Romantic Hits)
comment: sweets from our Sweet ("Talking in Your Sleep," "What I Like About You")
The snot-rock of their dreams ("Accelerator: I'm Ready," "The Banana Question").
Not-actually-Hootie was made for country, where cornballism comes with the form ("All I Want," "While I Still Got the Time").
Franchise-holder as franchise, his beats stronger young-and-thug than grown-and-numerological ("Drink, Smoke and Fcuk," "Chi Hung").
Snacks meaning tasty bites and tastier beats that don't add up to a full meal ("O Day/Party People," "Put Your Guns Down").
stolider than touristic ecstatics would prefer, but the great track is godlike ("Hazir Hain Hazir Hain")
Adele and Gaga watch your backs, lest she take art-rock pop ("Cheerleader," "Dilettante," "Cruel")
they go their own way, they know whereof they speak, they sample Whitney's mama ("Shoop," "Whatta Man," "I've Got AIDS")
Post-rock cornetist gets up with three Brazilian co-conspirators, two of them percussionists ("Just Lovin'," "Rio Negro")
Moroccan club sophisticates combine authentic Araboiserie with Eurodub and "I Wanna Be Your Dog" ("Marrakech X-Press," "Hel Aeynik").
Fiddler/violinist to the stars straight-talks lissomely about love and loss ("The Littlest Prisoner," "Sacrifice")

album: Who Is Jill Scott? Words and Sounds Vol. 1
comment: Too classy for me, I figured, but she's nicer, funnier, and sexier than that--and too young for me isn't her fault ("Exclusively," "Love Rain").
A little writing help from her friends ("8 Minutes to Sunrise," "Daydreamin'," "Good Morning Heartache").
MCs all secretly believe they can do it on their own, but even the smart ones are a little too full of their own words ("Let 'Em Come," "Try Dying")
it's Memphis, it's the '80s, and darn it, Big Star lives ("Machiavellian Eyes," "Judy [She Put the Devil in Me]")
direct from Dakar, Islamic dynamics in the secular flesh ("Bour," "Dieylo")
Aided by several North Mississippi Allstars, NYC-based preacher-activist activates protest soul ("Burnin' and Lootin'," "Resist")

album: The Curse of the Selby Tigers
comment: whatever exactly they're venting about, they've got that punk mad-funny-fucked thing down ("Dolph Indicator," "Punch Me in the Face [With Your Lips]")

He'll never be a melodist if he isn't now, but he is a lyricist--a wordsmith who loves several uncles, hates "pro-life" death-trippers, and can afford both his wife's thing for home improvement porn and the right sidemen ("Uncle Mike," "Tongue and Groove," "South Dakota Lady")
Wage servitude and the righteous haters who are stuck in it--the lowdown ("The Drudge," "Wonderful Waitress," "Cook and Clean").
Identifying more avant, but cutting a funkier path on the longer ones ("Cuttin' Out," "Hollis")

from Pakistan, released September 11, sister and brother qawwali singers with more spirit than shame and an American collaborator helping them take their bhangra and chela technopop ("Jewleh Lal," "Laglan")
Persian classical meets Persian folk halfway, more entrancingly than any techno meld for sure ("Rain," "Festive Occasion").
Bill and Elvin's excellent jazz record ("Little Rock")
atmospherics for an oxygen-depleted biosphere ("Uncle Herbie's Dance," "Who Are You")
Femmenoizetoonfrom Ohio--less surprising than prime Breeders, every bit as catchy ("Holidazed," "B-Side Radio").
"Faced with a dodo's conundrum"--he said it, I didn't ("Girl Sailor," "Australia").

Not a band, of course--a shell company for a less boyish and supple James Mercer, who keeps things simple enough only on his memoiristic, hot sex, and feminist numbers ("Mildenhall," "Rubber Ballz," "Name for You")

album: Osaka Ramones: A Tribute to the Ramones
comment: Temporarily unannoying J-altpop post-geishas chirp the classics ("We're a Happy Family," "Blitzkrieg Bop")
Hundreds of young bands still make their generic stabs at short-fast-catchy, and every so often a good one gets lost in the crowd, on a major especially ("Never Gonna Die," "Astoria").

album: Rivers: From the Congo to the Mississippi
comment: With foundation help he deserves, hard-traveling Minneapolis soukous guitarist makes something varied and delicious of the kind of world-music amalgam others turn to goo ("Ndombolo," "Yeke Yele")
English DJ runs Colombian salsa through Jamaican dub--spare, soulful, beats first ("Deja [Mary]," "In Beats We Trust")
Philosophical fictions and fantasias by a stolid-sounding guy who wishes everyone would play his songs ("San Francisco B.C.," "Aloysius, Bluegrass Drummer").

album: The Rat Pack Live at the Sands
artist: Frank Sinatra, Dean Martin & Sammy Davis Jr.
comment: master singer, underrated comic, disruptive symbol ("Dialogue [Track 15]," "Medley: Drink to Me Only With Thine Eyes/I Don't Care If the Sun Don't Shine/I Love Vegas [Paris]")

album: Country Gentleman: The Best of Ricky Skaggs
comment: intensely sweet until he started to repeat himself, and also after ("Heartbroke," "Don't Cheat in Our Hometown")
get off on running a scrap-metal bottleneck right across a song's clavicle ("Sawdust," "Kerosene")
Hating the class system and making it sound like hating everything ("Pubic Hair Ltd," "Jobseeker")
The unrelenting futility of life in five unrelentingly tuneless tunes ("Britain Thirst," "I Can Tell")
Lounge r&b for the age of techno constructivism and Moog retro ("Hilary, Last of the Pool Sharks," "Dun Deal [Wrestler's Rematch]").
hooked on sonics ("Geek U.S.A.," "Today")
Surveying the world from a temporary star ("Then the Morning Comes," "I Just Wanna See").
pure as death and taxes ("Summer Cannibals," "Wicked Messenger")
Many interpretive singers have superior pipes, and some equal brains, but few match her quality of belief ("Are You Experienced?" "Smells Like Teen Spirit").
blues his religion,  his therapy, his metier ("Winsome Smile," "Dust My Broom")

Updates of "Beer Run" and "Ballad of the Kingsmen," Jerry Jeff Walker cameo with patter, too many redundancies, and three or four definitive renditions ("Alright Guy [Hill Country Goodbye Story] Alright Guy," "Precious Little Miracles," "Can't Complain," "Too Soon to Tell")
Four more young white guys riding g-g-b-d down the fast, flat driveway to moving out of your parents' house ("Answer to Yourself," "More or Less").
Neotraditionalists from Mexican-Caribbean Veracruz reclaim son jarocho's urgent cries and dedicated guitars from the tourist restaurants ("Cascabel," "Buscapies").
the diligently realized sound of exhaustion ("Sympathy for the Strawberry," "Rain on Tin")
the five per cent nation of let's-slow-it-down-a-little-right-now ("Disseminated," "4 out of 5")

Studio-recorded before he'd refined his crowd-pleasing wiles in the world marketplace, this dabke for dummies lacks a subtle but crucial quantum of give ("Hafer Bidi Gabrak [I Will Dig Your Grave With My Hands]," "Hot Il Khanjar Bi Gleibi [Stab My Heart]")
Tel Aviv DJ crew throw a multicultural rap/R&B party that's hottest at its most Arab ("El Nur," "Exotic on the Speaker").
Blueprint free-associates at his own risk, RJD2 distracts on principle ("Fuckajob," "The Jerry Springer Episode").
hear them earn their miserabilism ("Ty Cobb," "Blow Up the Outside World," "Jesus Christ Pose")
they can score my horror movie anytime ("Two Masks," "Call & Response")

At her best here, she sounds like what I think she's aiming for, which is the Joni Mitchell who so wanted to be a jazzbo--not the lyricist prime Mitchell was, obviously, but hey, neither is Mitchell. ("Good Lava," "Ebony and Ivy")
Their squelchy electrobeats are as funny as their laughing-gas sex rhymes ("Backyard Betty," "Top Billin' From Far Left").
For the mountains above and the mud below--especially the mud below ("Comin' Round," "Take a Load Off").
A bigger heart than her piano-playing New York City counterparts but a slightly smaller talent, a problem that could prove chronic or lessen with time ("That Time," "Another Town").
If you start them up, well, they'll never stop, never stop, never stop, never stop ("Shotgun," "Tear It Down")

artist: Peter Stampfel and the Atomic Meta Pagans
comment: Polyphony spins dizzily awry as fearless leader plus ad hoc nonet reel off protest songs, pop standards, banjo improvs, nursery rhymes, etc. ("This Is My Country," "Blue Moon," "Cumberland Mountain Deer Chase")
"way over a century of knowledge of American music, way over a century's common ground," but also, "I enjoy the possibility of going nuts" ("Bar Bar," "Ghost Train of Freak Mountain").
the new originals are precious, the remakes worth the reminder ("Demon in the Ground," "We're Still Here").
All-star songwriting crew works changes on the political truths and homilies this rights standard-bearer has been nailing for half a century ("MLK Song," "History, Now," "Action")
if Jews for Jesus could see the hussy now ("Don't You Hear Jerusalem Moan," "I Got Jesus Looking After Me")
No government "Bunk Beds" for these payers of dues and bills--they're too long on both cold-eyed perspective and human connection ("Paper Rock Scissors," "Something for Nothing")
The perils of romance among the disaffected classes ("One More Night [Your Ex-Lover Remains Dead]," "Reunion").
Turns out the problem wasn't ska per se--it was No Doubt ("Bubble Pop Electric," "What You Waiting For?").
almost hooky enough to reconcile me to a world that needs Marxist background music ("Tone Burst," "I'm Going Out of My Way")

album: Cobra and Phases Group Play Voltage in the Milky Night
comment: Yeah! appropriate that vibraphone! and definitely that Glasstinato! ("Blue Milk," "Blips Drips and Strips").

As with most new-prog succes d'estimes, these bari-sax patternings avec Laurie Anderson cameos are more original than compelling, but they're also more compelling than most ("The Stars in His Head [Dark Lights Remix]," "Red Horses [Judges II]")
"We haven't done this together since we recorded it 22 years ago--most of the band weren't born--me wife was only one--" ("Reason To Believe," "Handbags and Gladrags")

album: It Had to Be You . . . The Great American Songbook
comment: he'll do anything to make her come--even hold her hand and gaze into her eyes ("Every Time We Say Goodbye," "The Nearness of You")
Punk as kids expressing themselves turned punk as gateway to history--and maybe adulthood eventually, but not yet please ("I Heard You Wanna Beat Me Up," "No Way for a Slave to Behave").
more-Brit-than-thou San Fran mopesters cross the sainted Only Ones with the accursed Spiritualized ("All Mistakes Are Mine," "Hydroplane")
Narcissism repeats itself ("Between Love and Hate," "What Ever Happened").
You know how it is--the gym does more for your wind than for your jump shot ("You Only Live Once," "Ask Me Anything").
Consciously good-humored Atlanta-to-Philly Sugar Tongue Slim cajoles seriously conscious Philly beatmaker ("Hold On, Here It Go," "Do It Right")
Acerbically, vulnerably, neo-soul ingï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿"Bust Your Windows," "Fear").

After 50 albums, many unlistenable not just because they're out of print, "uncategorizable" trio drop what Pitchfork's smartest designates their last and friendliest record ("Ben's Radio," "The Imam")
alt-rock road dogs unleash country hoo-haw ("Good Livin'," "Hangin' Out With Me")
he's so great with the help he should hire some lyricists ("Dinosaur Act," "Knowing People")
It isn't that she completely sounds like a pop star, it's that she completely identifies as one ("This Is Why We Can't Have Nice Things," "Call It What You Want")
Self-starting, insecure eroticist negotiates the tricky web of pathways between love and sexual autonomy--tries to, anyway ("Weekend," "Doves in the Wind," "20 Something")
Never Before Available Covers of 25 of Your Favorite '60s Hits! ("Harlem Shuffle," "Downtown")
Inuit woman channels deep-nurtured throat-singing into sometimes startling, sometimes disturbing, sometimes merely arty avant-shamanism ("Caribou," "Umingmak")
Two Europe-based Argentinean expats yank Astor Piazzolla toward jazz and electronica ("La Yumba," "DJ Peron").
problems in the interrelations of guitar dynamics and racial pride ("My Soul's in Louisiana," "Saint Martha Blues")
Colorado bluesman finally figures out how to split the difference between gravity and taking yourself too seriously ("Yell Your Name," "Blind Piano Teacher")
Never a tunesmith, always a master of blues atmospherics, he knows just how to deconstruct the folkie-penned sexist classic. ("Hey Joe [B]," "Sunday Morning [A]")
a singa with attitude might put some there there ("Metal Baby," "Is This Music?")
One-man hook machine puts some rings on his formal merry-go-round ("Look to the East," "Tokyo").
As with Mulatu Astake, a European challenge lifts an African icon's game ("Against the Wall," "Sinuhe").
Speed-rhyming Santa Fe supernerd drops science, literature and his home-ec homework over jacked beats from the classical canon to the Doors to Hernando's Hideaway ("Androids' Alphabet," "WWIII").
enthusiasts (in the religious sense) of despair (ditto) ("Accelerator," "Gone")
to quote the ever clever Ian Dury, there ain't half been some clever bastards ("How Can I Sing Like a Girl?," "I Can Hear You," "James K. Polk," "XTC Vs. Adam Ant")
Catchy facts marshaled to fortify innocents against Christianist anti-empiricism, and marred by progessivist didacticism as a result ("Why Does the Sun Shine?" "Why Does the Sun Really Shine?").
More brains than Justin, which is saying a lot, and more talent than JC, which isn't ("She's Gangsta," "Make a Baby")
Seventeen songs in 33 minutes by Cleveland Voidoids/Fugazi fans who still read the newspaper ("Beans and Rice," "Art Project," "Paint Me a Picture").

album: Time Is on My Side--The Best of Irma Thomas Volume 1
comment: betta than Etta? ("Two Winters Long," "Some Things You Never Get Used To")

album: The Best of Rufus Thomas: Do the Funky Somethin'
comment: Rock's most literal link to minstrelsy ("Walking the Dog," "Do the Funky Penguin [Part I]," "Somebody Stole My Dog").
He's always better when you listen to the words, and he's not making it any easier ("Internet Is Just Bad Pot," "Hell").
hymns laced with standards and bent quietly into cocktail-piano wassail ("Silent Night," "Jingle Bells")
Wiser than her ex, nicer, subtler--but, admittedly, less dynamic ("Beauty," "Give Me a Sad Song").

"Finding themselves lost in unknown territory, the group eventually discovers the existence of what they describe as 'spirals'--portals leading to different worlds within . . ." ("ITMOI-3," "ITMOI-5")
Art-punks thrash around their garage-rock town ("From: Skulls," "Better Safe Than Safari").
Just to prove he's lost neither knack nor professional standing, an enjoyable EP no one expected or, I admit, needed ("Broadcast Live," "Ain't Gonna See It Comin'")
Intelligent black man goes straight conscious while wisely ceding the EP's most intelligent rhyme to Killer Mike ("40 Acres," "Black Man")
She's freaky but I like it"?? Dude's more confused than he wants you to think ("My Love," "SexyBack").
Any stroke can stretch an orgasm, any sound can state a beat ("2 On," "Wildfire")
respect for a lover of popular song ("Stairway to Heaven," "Sly Cigarette," "Fourteen," "Bye Bye Blackbird")
Conscious anti-gangsta talks the walk ("How to Get Ass," "American Nightmare").
just like you they are lonely too ("Silly Ho," "Unpretty")
Ali Farka Tourï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½"Su Wililï¿"'s beat isn't African--it belongs to Bo Diddley, who figured it out in Chicago ("I Kana Korto," "Wo Yendï¿½ï¿½ï¿½")

A lively, accomplished, pointedly fresh-faced electrification of this particular Tourï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½'s upful approach to Malian gu"Handaraï¿½ï¿" "Hendjero Moulaye")
The easier, more worldly version of his father you'd expect, more interested in pleasure than edge ("Fafa," "Sarama").
I ask you, how much do words matter with John Hurt? (OK, a little) ("Indï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿" "Djonkana").
A Malian "blues" guitar record where producer Ballakï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Sissoko's ko"Mbalimaou," "Sina Moussou Djougou")
Filling their shoes and standing that tall ("Don't Think Twice, It's All Right," "You Didn't Have a Good Time").
dope jazzbeats and goofball rhymes from the well-meaning middle class ("Check the Rhime," "Buggin' Out")
fighting sensationalist obscurity with philosophic subtlety, which I wish could work ("Jam," "Crew," "The Hop")
Four tracks not market-friendly enough to convince me "PolyGram" offed him for being a "fucking nigger" ("Divine Comedy").
Illbient slimmed into smoove groove, a conscious maturity move less escapist than you'd fear and less vital than you'd hope ("Tribal Drums," "Hey Love")
Leaning harder on his ladies' auxiliary than Leonard Cohen, he continues to mutter that it's a bummer out there, and half the time prove it ("Lonnie Listen," "Nicotine Love")

Adding "Greener Than the Grass (We Laid On)" to the kiddie-porn Greatest Hits, a boon; replacing the rape-Gothic "No Man's Land" with "You Are So Beautiful," an obscenity ("Would You Lay With Me [in a Field of Stone]," "The Man That Turned My Mama On").
It's never too late not to get above your raising ("Love's Gonna Live Here," "Lovesick Blues").
they want you to know they were gurls, leaving the grrrl question open ("Latex Dominatrix," "Dime-a-Dozen")
refuse and resist and revolt ("Burn Baby Burn")
Attention Amon Tobin: when a beatmaker's hip-hop bid peaks with an instrumental, there's probably a piece missing ("Keman Rhythm," "Straw Man").
Coltrane's soulmate plus Murray plus Blythe ("Bessie's Blues")
Know how to do that roiling-bashing-chiming thing, topped off by an especially gritty-declamatory-delighted singer ("I Like the Way You Are," "Happy")
what shall it profit a great white reggae band if it should gain the world and sell its own soul? ("One in Ten," "Rat in Mi Kitchen")
"Everything is just wonderful here in my dreams, here in my dreams" ("Just a Stranger," "Killer")
The original Ke$ha makes her bid with even more family money behind her, which cuts her crassness the way wealth does sometimes ("MC's Can Kiss," "Difficult").
clever, nerdy, well-put alt-rap propaganda trumped by imaginative, disgusting, facetious vegetarian propaganda ("The Drive-Thru," "Opening Act," "I Wanna Go Home")
"This THEY you're screaming about, please elaborate," "punk/indie/whatever" designated drivers demand ("Porch Life," "Ballad of the Designated Driver")
beatwise, Classical 101 meets Hip Hop 101; rhymewise, Twin Cities whiteboys moralize sincerely and fantasize boastfully ("Almost There," "Never")
just handsome and mellifluous enough to snag more top-drawer songs than he deserves ("Life Turned Her That Way," "Somebody Lied," "Rockin' Years")

artist: Stevie Ray Vaughan and Double Trouble
comment: Elmore James with chops--too many sometimes ("Boot Hill," "Close to You")

artist: Stevie Ray Vaughan and Double Trouble
comment: live and unfledged, 4/1/81--blues as a barely controllable torrent of electric sound ("Shake for Me," "Tin Pan Alley")
dance music from Jimmy and Nile ("White Boots," "Hard To Be")
Showcasing the saxophonist more than the bandleader, the James Brown fan more than the Franco wannabe ("Cheka Sana," "Nakobala Yo Denise")

album: Blow It Out Your Ass It's Veruca Salt
comment: two catchy-not-poppy A's, two sludgy-not-grungy B's ("Shimmer Like a Girl," "I'm Taking Europe With Me")
TIYL Velvets, Television, Taking Tiger Mountain (by Strategy)--that is, roots music, Lower East Side style ("Thieves Oh Glorious Thieves," "Needle to the Heart of the Matter").
Veteran folkie adds period pop to Bessie-Jimmie-etc., a welcome move in itself and because it suits her lean voice. ("Cheer Up! Smile! Nertz!," "Baby Rose")
singing the good songs as hard as the great ones, more Johnny Cash every time out ("The Lie," "Poison," "Johnson to Jones")
Bitterly weary, which isn't always an advantage ("Missing Link," "Nothing at All," "Join the Club").

album: Waco Express: Live & Kickin' at Schuba's Tavern Chicago
comment: Old songs for the long haul and damn the consequences ("Plenty Tuff Union Made," "Blink of an Eye").

Live covers of rough-cut country chestnuts of varying sheen, plus, er, a Jimmy Reed, a Pink Floyd, two T. Rexes, and a narsty Christmas ditty of their own devising ("Merry Xmas to Me," "20th Century Boy")
jape, jape against the dying of the light ("Four Mirrors," "So Damn Happy")
his mother died and he's gonna ("White Winos," "Bed")
if he's not really a singer-songwriter, how come he always writes to the tune of his own voice? ("Cigarettes and Chocolate Milk," "One Man Guy," "Greek Song")

album: Rufus Does Judy at Carnegie Hall
comment: A guy for whom well-made pop songs have serious disciplinary advantages ("Puttin' on the Ritz," "You Made Me Love You/For Me and My Gal/The Trolley Song").
With Lucy an equal and Martha fitting in for once, both sing more winningly than ever before on record, and the covers they choose are choice ("Lullaby," "Runs in the Family")
prime collaborators, could use a libretto ("Russian Dance," "Crossroads," "That's the Way," "I'll Shoot the Moon")
Shtick fights funk to the death, yielding both a circus spiel with some laughs in it and a battlefield habanera worthy of Motï¿½ï¿½ï¿½"Hoist That Rag," "Top of the Hill").
Intelligent black rapper keys showcase to intelligent white comedian, which would be cooler if the two gents were equally inspired ("The Kramer," "The Opening Title Sequence").
What if an overrated singer-songwriter was so damn understated he found true love and/or Jesus and nobody noticed? ("To Save Me," "Oh Lonesome Me").

I enjoyed this punky Atlanta Pylon derivative so much more when I realized that the raspy female voice and the grave female voice emanated from one woman in anxious dialogue with herself ("Super Low," "Reservoir")
Montreal 1977-the old man shows off his second drawer and takes some standards to school ("Kansas City," "Nine Below Zero").
Musos with a right enact an Americana songbook that makes room for Lindsey Buckingham and Lee Ving as well as Roger Miller and Robert Earl Keen ("Feelin' Good Again," "Not in Nottingham")
the multiculti drum trip of Mickey Hart's interviews, with a secret ingredient--jazz ("Art Blakey," "Elvin Suite")

"A joke a stroke of genius/Probably somewhere in between" is tuneful enough, finally, but make that second line "Or only a waste of time?" and we might believe he's got some brain left ("Bug," "Poor Lenore")
Finally, Suicide influencees that rock--Francophones, mais oui ("L.L. Romeo," "T.R.O.U.B.L.E.").
If coming leaves your penis feeling that bad, fella, remember that they're not called narcotics for nothing ("Wicked Games," "House of Balloons/Glass Table Girls")
Including a "Snatch It Back and Hold It" that incorporates "Papa's Got a Brand New Bag" ("Scratch My Back," "Little by Little," "Happy Birthday").
Get this while you can from the mixtape man no matter how much of it is destined for the real album (Kanye West, "Can't Tell Me Nothing"; Bentley Feat. Pimp-C and Lil' Wayne, "C.O.L.O.U.R.S").
Sign spotted on church in the wild: Death Grips--Be Like Them ("New Slaves," "Hold My Liquor")
On their 2009 debut, before Billy Easter got distracted, her frisky girlpunk band honors several girlpunk foremothers, most auspiciously Kleenex ("Lower Leg," "Wymmin's Final")
Falling-apart love songs for a broken world ("Body Talk [Part 2]," "Slow Fade").
two cans of creamed corn beyond the great songpoet of the actually existing lower-middle class he's too modest to be ("Po' Po' Baby," "Great Day," "Nowhere Tornado")
realist defiance grinding sadly down into realist bathos ("Casino Queen," "Box Full of Letters")
Full-on Radiohead electronica Americanized with aw-shucks diffidence, red-blooded guitar, sharp tunes, and exceptionally dull poetry ("Standing O," "One Sunday Morning")
As hooked on sonics as Yankee Hotel Foxtrot--song sonics as opposed to electronic sonics or Americana sonics, and also as opposed to songs ("EKG," "Taste the Ceiling")
Grime godfather's first DIY album is his best ever even though he seems incapable of rhyming about a life beyond music, if he has one ("Laptop," "Back With a Banger")
A rich guy can hook like crazy and rap enough to pass, and not only that--a rich guy can care about your humps and the planet at the same time ("I Got It From My Mama," "Over").
Her band jams for real as her songs bewail the artist's plight or just stay out of the way ("Honey Bee," "Real Love").

When your classic hit DLs over six million domestic and its worthy follow-up barely clears 35 thousand, you're right to figure there's a differential, but believe me, it's less than 17,500 percent ("Happy," "Marilyn Monroe")
Poet's "industrial punk-hop" picks up big-time with just a little help from Sirj Tankian, Zack de la Rocha, or Bad Brains ("List of Demands," "Talk to Strangers").
at four tracks in three years, she's not gonna pick a title song called "Going Strong" ("Fading Fast," "Aren't I True")
Not a good sign when the three really good ones are about booze (if you count the one that's really about stardom) ("All Jacked Up," "One Bud Wiser").

album: Live at the Roxy, London-April 1st & 2nd 1977/Live at CBGB Theatre, New York-July 18th 1978
comment: First Cockneyfied punk aspirants, then art-rockers in utero--the madness to their method ("Mary Is a Dyke [1]," "Mercy").
No grail for any but the staunchest believers, but give them credit for not losing interest ("Love Bends," "Doubles & Trebles")
More anxious than ever, and they don't like postmodernity much, yet somehow they find electronics musically mellowing ("Blogging," "Harpooned," "In Manchester")
a genius even when that's all he's selling ("Jungle Fever," "Fun Day")

Two Too Much Joy vets, one now a reality-show producer and the other a Real Networks VP, lay some noisy desperation on capitalism, soft sexism, and other facts of postmodern life ("This Song Is a Commercial," "Janie Jones").

artist: World Saxophone Quartet and African Drums
comment: most prefer their Africa less hectic, their jazz more straight-ahead ("The Holy Man," "Metamorphosis")
The auteur provides the guacamole-canoli-parolee on this Ghostface album in disguise, but Jadakiss himself sums it up: "Crack spot stories/To Allah be the glory" ("Drivin Round," "Take Notice")
Their roots alt-country, their sonics arena-drone, they subject five pieces of Americana history to the treatment for Record Store Day ("Poor Ellen Smith," "Lavender Blue")
great-not-grand beats, worried raps about the ultimate value of the Wu and all its holdings ("Iron Flag," "Dashing [Reasons]")

album: The Best: Make the Music Go Bang!
comment: Like so many bands and the occasional couples, they didn't know when to quit ("Adult Books," "In This House That I Call Home").
The best songs come from the best albums, an inconvenience ("Grass," "Making Plans for Nigel," "Dear God").
femme-punk self-definition, by now a trope among many others, done with spunk, funk, and downtown noise ("Bang," "Mystery Girl")
I dig her new Middle America affect, but still don't wish she was my girlfriend (or daughter) ("Phenomena," "Turn Into").
Compelling sound, constricted souls, Kool Keith, and cash flow ("Mosquito," "Sacrilege")
The whole Nuyolatino empanada ("Guajira," "Tu Casa, Mi Casa").
Way more fun than most bitch-ass motherfuckers ("Calling All Zones," "Hanh!").
a honky tonker with a grudge, not a stud with the rhythm and blues ("The Heart That You Own," "The Distance Between You and Me")
hey Mr. and Mrs. Tambourine Man, play that feedback for me ("Some Kinda Fatigue," "Upside-Down")
Christian lesbians from Florida go upside your booty with electro bass from the U.K. ("F----- Up," "Leather Jacket").
Conscious rapper will rock your sister's monkey--if she likes her ("Hey There Girl," "Monkey").

album: A Society in Which No Tear Is Shed Is Inconceivably Mediocre
comment: 16-year-old Brazilian lo-fi adept explains why he's about to kill himself and demonstrates why he shouldn't have--conclusively, I hope ("Estrela, Estrela," "Katie Don't Be Depressed").
mean length of Harvest track not counting six-minute opus: 3:14; mean length of Harvest Moon track not counting 10-minute opus: 4:37 ("Old King," "Harvest Moon")
folkie and proud, he's earned one of these things if anyone has ("World on a String," "Like a Hurricane")
Booker T. as first refuge of a patriot ("Differently," "You're My Girl")

Anything but "predictable," these political ditties rank among the strangest songs of his career, as in "Hope that was confusing, looking like a bright light/Blinding you forever with its power" ("My Pledge," "Glass Accident")
His politics have never been clearer, but they have been terser ("Leave the Driving," "Devil's Sidewalk").
Assassinated by the Russians in 1979, Afghan rocker was too gifted vocally and melodically to sink into schlock ("Dar Kunj Dilam Eshqi Kasi," "Uoba Darta Rawarem")
Pygmies and babies sing the African diaspora that is her life ("Whatdidusay?" "Zap Bï¿½ï¿½").
thumb-piano extravaganza from an appointed guardian of Tanzanian tradition ("Nyangawuya," "Munyamaye")

For non-Lusophones, the wittiest moment of the avant-garde jingle writer's five-song rejoinder to the haters who Feicebuque-shamed his Coke commercial is the Microsoft fanfare that announces the enterprise, and he knows it ("Irarï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï" "Zï¿½ï¿½ï¿½")
putting the mean fun back in being unrepentant and existentially pissed ("Seminole Bingo," "Rottweiler Blues")
And before that it'll nickel-and-dime ya a little besides ("Life'll Kill Ya," "Ourselves to Know").

Where the first album of prison recordings from dirt-poor Malawi showcased solo singing whose poignancy was diminished by non-English lyrics, here there's considerable band music by inmates you just know are planning for or dreaming of the outside, and will you ever root for them (Vincent Saulos, "I Am Done With Evil"; Thomas Ganisani, "Everything Has an Owner")

Revisiting/recombining jungle's heady heyday--or, if you're neither nostalgic nor scholarly, gluing 38 minutes of electrodance dynamite onto repeated rumbling synth riffs and surgical blats of rousing high-end ("Where Were You in '92," "F--- Mixing, Let's Dance").
